There has been no complaints that I can't be heard nor do I have a problem hearing with whom I am speaking. The blue tooth is very easy to slip on my ear. Since the charger is the same one I use for my phone I don't have to use different chargers.

    Rating: 4

    2012-08-24: I have been using this headset with my Samsung Exhibit II Android phone, as well as previously with another cell phone.It works okay. There is a volume up and down switch, a power switch, and a control button to answer or redial the last number called. That's it - anything more complex and you have to use the phone directly.I keep the volume on max ALL the time because it is so quiet. I can hear ok when there's no ambient noise, but often I have trouble hearing due to traffic noise etc.The main issue I have is the ear buds (the rubber piece around the speaker that holds it in your ear) tend to fall off if you aren't careful. Several times I've put it in my pocket with my wallet only to pull it out later without the ear bud. Another time it fell off while in my car's cupholder. Usually I could find it, but not always.The ear HOOK stays on - it's the piece that goes around the ear - but you can't really use this without the ear bud also. It came with a couple different shaped ear buds (for different size ear canals), but all are now gone.Unfortunately, Samsung no longer covers this under warranty. When I first called they said they would replace the whole unit. Instead, I switched to another less comfortable ear bud. When that one fell off, I called back but now they won't replace it, and said they don't sell replacement ear buds. So the headset is now useless.This would be a nice headset if the volume were louder, the ear buds stayed on better, and you had more control over the phone from the headset.

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2012-08-29: Jawbone are by the best bluetooth out there so therefore i purchased the icon hd. I specifically purchased from here because of the retail packaging. However when I purchased this item it was clearly a used product resealed in the packaging. Thankfully i took pictures and opened a return claim.     Rating: 1

    2014-04-13: I had high expectations for this bluetooth, especially for the cost. I had to find a small plastic container to place it in while not in use, so it would not be squished in my purse. My family and friends often complain about how well they can hear me while I use the bluetooth, but it happens randomly. The piece that is supposed to fit in your ear and keep it in place will start to turn after multiple uses, so I stopped using it. Like I said, I was expecting better, but found that it has not exceeded a standard bluetooth that is cheaper.

    Rating: 3

    2014-02-20: I am not a big cell phone headset user-maybe a couple hours a week tops. I previously owned a Jawbone ICON, and when it met its premature death (they are definitely not Rottwelier resistant), I wanted to replace it with the same model. This appeared to be the updated version of my previous unit.=== The Good Stuff ===* This unit has one button, which seems to do what I want it to do whenever I press it. It also has a little slide switch for ON/OFF, which again does exactly what I would expect it to do. For my use, there is no need for the "press the big button three times while holding the little button" gymnastics that other headsets seem to require.* I find the sound quality to be at least as good as my Verizon cell connection. The noise reduction seems to work reasonably well at not picking up ambient noises, and the earpiece volume is more than sufficient for my needs.* It comes with a variety of earpieces, one of which works well in my ear. My ear canals are evidently on the small side, and this is one of the few headsets that both stays in my ear (without the hook) and is comfortable to wear, at least for an hour or two.=== The Not-So-Good Stuff ===* I hate the retail packaging. It takes some effort to break into the thing. But even worse is that the hard plastic shell is useless for storing all the extra ear pieces that come with the headset. Instead there is a cardboard box that really doesn't stay closed on its own.* The case is also useless as a storage container for the headset. Instead, I use an old prescription pill bottle, which works pretty well and protests the headset from damage in my briefcase.=== Summary ===I have found Jawbone ICONs to be rock-solid, relatively low cost headsets. They pair easily with my iPhone, and the sound quality is fine for my uses. All the functions I care about (easy to pair, one button call/hangul, on-screen battery meter) all work well with no fuss, and I have never looked up anything in the manual. It doesn't have (I assume) all the latest, coolest features, but I don't really want them anyway.

    Rating: 4

    2013-08-13: I read a lot of reviews on this before I forked out the cash. Previously I owned the original Hero Icon and it worked great for more than a year before the switch stopped working and the battery life conked out.Other reviews said that it has better battery life and better sound. I sort of agree on the sound quality. It is a bit louder and clearer and my contacts claim they can hear me better. I have to disagree on the battery life however. Seems identical or a bit less than the original Icon Hero.Otherwise still the best bluetooth I can find. Stays on the ear nicely, lasts all day, good sound, works flawlessly with my Galaxy 3S.

    Rating: 2

    2012-08-05: I purchased this headset about 2 weeks ago and so far I really like it. Some reviews mentioned trouble getting it to pair with their phone. I have not had any difficulties with that at all, in fact, as soon as I turn my headset on it automatically is detected by my iPhone4 (as long as the bluetooth is turned on) and is connected.I love that I can stream my music thru this headset. Whether it's iTunes or Pandora, the sound is good. I recently had to participate in a conference call using the headset and I was able to hear everyone on the call pretty well. Honestly it's hard to be able to hear everything on a conference call to begin with, so I was happy with that.I like that it fits right into my ear, but also has the over the ear hook thing. With my previous headset I was always fighting with the hook getting tangled in my glasses. :o) There are multiple pieces to fit into your ear which I think one of those will work for most people. I haven't had it fall out yet. :o)I would definitely recommend this headset. Well worth the money and it also charges up quickly which is great.

Still searching for a bluetooth solution that works or is at least not too frustrating to use.

    2014-07-08: Great sound, easy to pair, easy to use for a great prices

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-04: About a month ago, my old Jawbone 2 Bluetooth headset finally died. Over the last month or so I have tried four different headsets until I finally found one that met all of my needs. I am including my brief opinions about each of them for comparison, and to hopefully help some of you narrow your selection down, if you are considering any of these.MOTOROLA H720PROS: Easy to use, flip to talk makes answering calls easy. Comfortable.CONS: Floppy feel. Noise canceling does not work very well.MOTOROLA HX550PROS: Flip to talk makes answering calls relatively easy. Its Comfortable. Noise canceling works very well while on calls.CONS: Noise canceling does not work for voice commands...so forget about using Siri while driving. The compact nature of this headset makes it more difficult to flip open than the H720.PLANTRONICS M165PROS: It looks good. Deep sleep mode means you don't need to turn it on and off every time you want to use it.CONS: Noise canceling not nearly as good as either the HX550 or any of the Jawbone headsets.JAWBONE 2:PROS: Noise canceling works very well, both for calls and voice commands.CONS: Hidden buttons are hard to use. Plastic cover over buttons eventually fatigues and cracks. Turning on headset requires holding hidden button down for three seconds, followed by another three seconds to connect to the phone, causing missed calls.JAWBONE ICON HD:PROS: Noise canceling works well, both for calls and voice commands. Single multi-function button is MUCH easier to find and use than on the Jawbone 2. Power switch is easier to use than the hidden button on the J2. Time to connect to an incoming call from power-off is about 1 second, so no more missed calls. 10 days of standby time, so probably won't turn it off anyway. "mytalk.jawbone.com" provides an easy to use interface to the headset. Downloadable voice personalities are fun. Ability to reconfigure multi-function button for volume control or enabling/disabling Noise Assassin is nice.CONS: Slightly less comfortable to wear than HX550 or M165 in-the-ear, but not bad for short duration. Would probably use over-the-ear hook for extended use.UPDATE (2/4/2014):I have been using the Jawbone Icon HD for over two months now and love it. This is the standard by which all other Bluetooth headsets should be measured. Absolutely no complaints at all...small, comfortable, easy to use, and superb noise canceling for both voice commands and phone conversations. This headset costs about twice as much as most entry level headsets, but you truly get what you pay for in this case. Many of the high-end headsets cost about twice as much as this one, and I can't imagine being any happier with them. Excellent value.

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-30: Even though it received very high ratings, I had a difficult time getting it to fit my ear and also had a lot of comments from people I was calling of "echoes or feedback". I tried all of the fittings and really was not able to make it perform for me. I switched to a Motorola Oasis and it fit and performed much better.

    Rating: 2

    2013-07-30: I have never had a "perfect" bluetooth device but this one is working as good, or better, than any of my previous.

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-03: I was glad that after using one of these for two years and totally wearing it out, I was able to buy the same model and keep on as I was accustomed to. It works great, price was right, and I'm hoping for a few more years.

  • B00B45TMTK

    $B00B45TMTK

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2014-06-07: I have been through so many cords in my house. Always the same problem: either they only work for a short period of time because the tiny wires inside break, or they simply do not work straight out of the box. I am sure everyone else out there can say pretty much the same thing.So, I was skeptical about these, but honestly, there isn't a cord on the market that does not raise my suspicions in regards to its quality.I was pleasantly surprised at these as soon as I opened the package because of the weighty feel of them. I do know that I am personally responsible for damaging a lot of our cords (there are 4 of us in my house who all use the same type of charger cords, so when the cords no longer work, it's hard to tell which one of us is responsible for breaking it) because I have a hard time grasping the part of the cord where it is wide and flat--I don't know what it's called, but the part you pull on when you are trying to unplug the device--that part is usually where the wires inside break. I have bite marks on that flat part I just mentioned on my cords from pulling with my teeth in an attempt to not pull on the cord itself, which would risk damaging it. Crazy, right?! Well, these cords have an extra heavy duty feel to them, and that wide part? Well, it is bigger! A lot bigger!! And I can actually unplug my phone without pulling on the cord or using my teeth!! WOO HOOO!!The only problem I have is that they are so heavily made, that they are thicker than any other charger I have ever used and I don't have a single device that can be charged without removing part of the case because the cases are made for the standard Apple charger size.I am thinking I will purchase the adapter thingy that you use for lifeproof cases, which will solve my problem there.Thank you for such a great product!!

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-04: Five white and five black Velcro cable ties are in this package. I use them for so many different things. Of course, keeping my computer cables neat is the first thing but I use them to corral the cords on my sewing machines when I transport them to class.Then there are the cords running from my lamps and landline phone and clock radio. They too get a Velcro cable tie. The tie makes a 2” diameter circle at the largest and will keep two cords together at the smallest.If your cords are having a “wild party”, coral them with these Velcro cable ties

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-06: I purchased these because my granddaughter and wife are hard on cords. I do not blame the product that my cover prevents it from charging -- only the Apple brand fits in there, and none of the non-Apple ones do. I think this is an excellent value. I didn't give it 5 stars only because it charges about 75% as well as the more expensive Apple charger. You'll like it.

    2014-01-03: I was impressed with the quality of these cables. They all work perfectly and hopefully they will continue to do so. I had previously purchased Lenmar cables and was very impressed at first, but they stopped working after about a month.

    Rating: 5

    2014-01-04: I managed to break 3 Apple cables 3 different ways within 3 months. It must have been their time:>) I also managed to crack the housing on 2 Belkin cables. I needed replacements and I needed cables that would put up with everything! These cables are tanks! They are well built and meant to LAST. Really, these things have tolerated all kinds of crazy shoving, weather and temperature changes that go along with camping, dogs, and, well, life! That said, the Apple connector plastic end…not the metal but the plastic shroud is slightly larger than the Apple brand shroud. It works perfectly with all my leather cases for my iphone and iPad. One silicone case I carry strictly for grip while camping just needed to be filed slightly to make room. I used a round metal craft file to make the tiny bit of extra room I needed for the connector. That little bit of extra plastic, which makes the cable that much more indestructible, makes it just a tiny bit too big to fit through the hole to plug the phone in while it is in the case. Just check your current case while an Apple connector is in place. If there is a bit of room around the plastic shroud you should be fine. Good luck!

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-23: I guess I must be hard on cables. Mine seem to quit working much sooner than I expect. I keep buying cables that SAY they work with iPad 3, but when they arrive my iPad says it is not compatible and will not charge my device! I can't recall how many times this has happened since I got the iPad 3. Those other cables work fine with the iPad 2, but not the 3.I just got these cables today, so I can not yet speak to the longevity, nor to the companies 'Lifetime' warranty, but I can say that it IS charging my iPad 3!!! I was a little confused with the description because it stated that the cables would work with iPad 3, but then it said it would not work with Retina display?? I thought all iPad 3 had the retina display? Mine does. I do not have the 8 pin connector of which they speak. I have only the 30 pin that looks identical to iPad 2 connectors.Anyway, I am very pleased with these cables so far. I have only tried one of the three. It appears to be well constructed, heavy duty and extra long. Most importantly, it IS charging my iPad 3! Now if they honor their lifetime guarantee, I should be set for life - no more searching for iPad cables YEAH!I will update this review if anything changes, or when I need a warranty replacement. THANK YOU FRIENDLY SWEED!

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-26: If you've read the product description you'll know all about how these cables are Apple certified and all that, so I won't repeat what is already there.Here's the issue, the older version of this cable had end caps that were a little loose on the plug and would wiggle a bit. The end caps were also fatter than the Apple 30-pin connector cable that comes with your iPhone, iPad or iPod Touch. Some people (me included) were also having a loose plug issue where the 30-pin connector was not staying in the device securelyTo address the problems, The Friendly Swede had new and improved cables produced to replace their original cables. Sadly, I do not notice any difference between these and the cables I already had. My video demonstrates the issues that I had and the issues that still remain.I like the cables. They seem to be well made and are generously lengthy which comes in handy for me. But I dislike that I have to remove the case on my iPhone in order to charge it. Also, the 30-pin connector is not as secure in my iPhone and iPad as the original Apple connector. I'll think my devices are charging and I'll notice eventually that the connector loosened up on me and in fact the device was not charging.I was provided a complimentary set of cables for testing and review. I agreed to provide a fair and honest review. If you have any questions, please leave me a comment and I'll answer if I can.

    Rating: 3

    2014-05-19: I've had my iPhone 4s for about a year now, and the only charging cable I had was the short, fragile, skinny white one that came with it. It works fine, but it was always such a hassle never being able to talk on the phone or browse while it was charging because of the shortness of the cable. It never even dawned on me to look for a cable long enough to allow me to use my phone while charging. What a difference! The cable is much thicker and, I assume therefore, much more durable than the one that came with the phone.This package of cables comes in beautiful pink, purple, and turquoise blue colors. I gave the purple one to my granddaughter who is always losing her charger, kept the pink one for myself, and gave the turquoise cable to my husband. He loves the fact that this cable is bright enough that he can find it in his truck and also will be much less likely to leave it in hotel rooms or on the train.Finally, with that all said, it works exactly as it should. A great product.

    2014-02-22: I received these as a replacement to the formerly available ipod cables that were pink purple, etc. Those cables were thin and eventually failed as the wire would pull away from the 30 pin connector. These are a lot thicker in construction then their previous cables.The cables don't crimp, which is a plus. The 30 pin connector is bulky and doesn't work with some cases. The 30 pin connector is where these cables fail. On an ipad 2, iPhone 4S, ipod 2, 3 and 4, these cables do not "click" into the device. I know that you may be thinking that well apple doesn't have the side buttons to release the cable.     2012-12-27: I am pleased with this produce. It was purchased for a teenager and we didn't want to extend our contract. This phone was just as described and I would order again from this seller.

    Rating: 5

    2014-07-06: Was VERY happy with it for the first 4 months of owning it, and couldn't imagine a better phone. I could do my emails, read texts, and play music at the same time. I could GO ON THE WEB and stay in a phone convo at the same time. Just was amazing and the phone didn't limit what I did.The first issue I encountered was the battery. It barely lasted 8 hours, and that's with background syncing and all that stuff backlight all that turned down. You'd be lucky to get 1 hour at best if all that was on. I got the extended battery, and when it helped, it somehow made my screen go nuts. No joke, put the old one in and the device screen works and never an issue. The extended battery, it scrolls, clicks n things, and the landscape mode didn't work. Motorola tech support recommended a full reset, so I had to set up everything once more.The next issue I had was the music player integration. I can BLUETOOTH myself MP3 songs that AUTOMATICALLY are stored to the 8GB factory included SD card (finally), but they do not have any sort of identification. It says the track name- but with the track number, they are only in numeric order for example 01-"Only Time" The album names for everything that is Bluetoothed over is Bluetooth. It doesn't drag over the album name, and the artist simply reads unknown. I tried the USB with the same result, so i guess it's not all the bluetooth.And while the ANDROID 2.1.1 Android operating system is a joy to use, you cannot save APPS to your SD card. This leads to small lagginess, such as Angry Birds, takes literally 2 minutes to fling the next bird. As far as I was told, processor speed has nothing do with this, and as this was a premium phone, I'd think it had a good processor in it.Overall:It wows, but it could be better. Do I recommend it, yes, somewhat, if it can have it's issues fixed. I guess if you don't mind the SD issue it'd be a perfect phone, but unfortunately I decided it was something I didn't want to use and upgraded.

    Rating: 3

    2012-03-28: The Good: Excellent design, lots of power, superb features from Google, amazing cameraThe Bad: App store is still young, processes running in the background kills battery life, keyboard is a bit cumbersomeGoogle as been known for revolutionizing the internet and now they are with their Android phones. The Motorola DROID (A855) is the newest and most advanced phone on the market right now, and this bad boy does an awful lot. A lot of people are going to compare this phone to the iPhone, but the DROID trumps the iPhone in features, and freedom. I will discuss, first, the tech specs and compare them to the iPhone head-to-head so you can see how powerful the DROID truly is.Techno BabbleThe DROID has a 550 MHz processor, and to be specific the Arm Cortex A8 processor that is also present in the iPhone 3GS by Samsung. The 3GS is clocked only 50 MHz higher and can be overclocked to 800 MHz. To compare that the original Xbox has a 733 MHz processor. So can the DROID be overclocked to this as well? Most likely. With a monster processor the DROID can multitask and has one of the first actual mobile OS (besides Windows Mobile 7). This also means maintaining processes running in the background to gain battery life, uninstalling apps (not just deleting them), and a lot more, but we'll get to that later. The iPhone however can not multitask due to the OS running on it, and the processor is only used in games.When it comes to graphics the DROID still hasn't been pushed to its limits. There are very few 3D games on the Android market, but as of right now the iPhone stomps the DROID in the graphics department. The DROID has a 200 MHZz PowerVR SGX 530 GPU. The iPhone has the same, but due to the slightly better CPU is can currently outperform the DROID. The iPhone has been on the market for quite some time, so there are bigger better games available. The DROID should start getting the same quality soon. They both have 256MB of RAM, so under the hood they are pretty much the same.The DROID has a slightly bigger screen sizing in at 3.7' and the iPhone at 3.5'. Does 2 millimeters matter? Yes it does. There is a good 2 millimeters on the top of the iPhone that could be screen, but for some unknown reason it's not. The DROID has a higher resolution of 854480 and 265 ppi (pixels per inch). The 3GS has a 320480 resolution with only 163 ppi so the DROID has double the resolution of the iPhone. That is great for people wanting to watch high-res movies on their device.Both devices have the same input such as the 3 axis accelerometer (tilt sensor), digital compass, Multi-touch display, proximity and ambient light sensors etc. The DROID is a bit heavier than the 3GS, but only by 1.2 oz. The DROID wipes the floor with the 3GS' camera. The DROID camera is 5MP compared to the 3GS 3MP. The DROID has dual LED flash, and geotagging and it can even run higher than 30 FPS. The 3GS has all this except the dual LED flash and this is a huge plus.When it comes to storage the DROID wins with its external memory option. You can insert up to a 32GB micro-SD card, but you're stuck with the 3GS' internal memory and have to pay a huge price for more. The DROID even comes with a 16GB micro- card when you buy the phone. So when it comes to comparing junk under the hood they both have the same hardware, but the DROID has the extra tidbits that push it over the edge.GUI: Graphical User InterfaceThe DROID has an excellent GUI and the whole marketplace is run by the community. There are programs such as PandaHome, OpenHome, GDEHome etc that allow you to change "themes" for a small price or for free. These also change icons, clock widgets etc. The DROID has a great interface that is more like a computer that gives you a desktop, then a slide up menu where all your apps are stored. You can drag and drop as you see fit. The iPhone, however, is plagued with the mundane Apple OS that only show apps in a grid format with a black background. Sure you can change your "wallpaper" but this is only when the phone comes out of sleep mode so it's rarely seen. This makes every iPhone look the same so the DROID wins in customization by a long shot. There are four touch buttons located at the bottom of the screen which are your back button, menu, home, and search. You will use these buttons a lot so Motorola and Google were smart to put these here.Apps: Who's Better?It all comes down to the apps. Who has more right? Well the iTunes marketplace has hundreds of thousands of apps that the DROID doesn't have so the iPhone wins there. However, the Android market is ever-growing, and thanks to the user run community a lot of great apps are showing up that the iPhone can't run. These include a lot of customization apps and loads more. Apps are easier to run on the DROID since there is no iTunes type program. The app store is run off the phone, downloaded from the phone as well. If you don't want an app anymore you go to your settings and uninstall it. Google also allows you to refund anything you buy within 24 hours and Apple does not support this. While iTunes may have more stuff, Android has better customer service and a better community and setup. There are really no "hardcore" games for the DROID like there is for the iPhone, but it's getting there. You do not want to get a DROID for a gaming system just yet for sure; stick with your iPod/phone.Features: Welcome to Google TownThe DROID has a lot of little things going on in it. You can do everything a touch screen phone can do, but it also has a slide out QWERTY keyboard. The buttons were a little flat and the top row is hard to get at if you have big fingers, but it works well. If you tilt the phone sideways you can type with a landscape keyboard or use Google text-to-speech. I found this feature extremely useful when typing long messages or writing reviews for apps. Since this is a Google phone you get all their awesome apps such as Google Earth (yes it's in 3D and you can see every detail), and Google maps. Switch to your "car app" and press navigation. Speak your selection (i.e. Phoenix, Arizona) and Google will give you directions for a car, bus, or walking (God forbid you walk that far!). Press get navigate and the phone will speak you the directions. It doesn't update in real-time, but it does update as you drive down each block.Google Sky is a fun app that lets you point your phone in the sky and it will show you, in real-time, where each constellation and planet is. You get plenty of excellent Google apps such as Gmail, YouTube (yeah Google owns YouTube), and Google Goggles which allows you to take pictures of products or objects and the phone will scan it and search it for you. There's even a Google search bar on the desktop with a text-to-speech button next to it. Brilliant. There are plenty of other apps such as the Amazon store, eBay, Bank of America, MLIA, FML, and even ShopSaavy. This app allows you to scan a barcode and it will tell you where you can find it cheaper online or locally. Of course you have all your social networking apps like Twitter, Facebook, and MySpace which run great.When it comes to things like ringtones, pictures, and videos, so the DROID delivers. You can store any MP3, or picture and set them as wallpapers, notifications, or just ringtones. Mount your SD card via USB and just create the folders. No having to sync with a program on the PC. Total freedom is what Google gives you and this is what I love.Problems: It's Not PerfectThere are some issues with the DROID, but not many and they are minor. The biggest one is the running processes in the background that can kill your battery even in sleep mode. You have to get the Advanced App Killer app and every so often check everything you don't want running and kill the apps. Another problem I ran into was that since most of the apps are user made they can be glitchy and screw up your phone so watch out and read reviews before downloading anything. You could say that the major issue is the app store. There is a lot of apps, but some of it is junk. There aren't any excellent games available, and the app store doesn't have any sort feature except Top Paid, Top Free, and Just In.For a $550 phone (if you pay for it without a plan) the DROID delivers and trumps the iPhone in every direction except the apps. The DROID is a very advanced phone, and is for people who love using their phones constantly and make it a part of their every day life. With a sleek design, excellent features, sturdy hardware, and monster processing power the DROID should be the #1 phone in 2010.Update: 10/15/2011Now after I have had this phone for 18 months I don't like it as much. The phone started having issues with serious lag, slowdown, and just hardly responds anymore. The touch screen lost sensitivity after about a year, plus the hardware is ancient compared to what is out now. Due to that all the apps are now optimized for higher end phones so the Droid is left in the dust.Overall the phone just doesn't really work anymore internally. It won't come out of sleep mode some times, won't answer calls, turns off randomly, and the internet is just impossible to surf due to the now weak processor. Hardware wise it has stood the test of time with many drops, slides, fumbles, and kicks. Not a single crack or anything, but thankfully this phone is now discontinued. If you have the original Droid you are probably finding the same problems even after a factory reset. The phone was great 22 months ago, but now I just absolutely hate this thing. If I were to amend my score I would give it a 4/10 now, but of course that's unfair and should be remembered for how great it was at the time of release. Did I also mention that the appraisal price for the phone is about $20 now-a-days?

    Rating: 2

    2013-10-23: I bought this to replace my current phone because it was damaged. I got this in really great condition. This phone was just way to slow for me, couldnt complete simple tasks. So i sent it back.

    Rating: 2

    2014-03-18: THANKS SO IT TOOK SO LONG FOR THE REVIEW, I THOUGHT I DID THIS ALREADY BUT I SO LOVED THIS PHONE BUT IT OVER WITH NOW, I HATED TO LOSE IT

    Rating: 5

    2011-11-05: Compare this case to OtterBox, and see what you get. Oh that's right! They don't make a case for the HTC Thunderbolt fitted with an extended battery, and for under $40? I work in a corrosive environment, so I figured this would offer the best protection while at work, and on my off days I can peel the rubber off, and use the inner case for regular day to day protection from the dings and scratches that may occur when I slip it in my pocket. The package included a screen protector which I have to admit I have not used yet, since I already had one on my phone. Only thing "negative" about this case it that it does make the phone feel much bigger, but it's understandable considering how thick the rubber around the phone is. Over all I'm happy with this purchase, and if your looking for something that may save your phone from a drop, this may do it... but as a disclaimer I have not been daring enough to try it lol

My only minor complaint is how the rubberized portion of the case picks up lint & dust from my pockets. High quality construction, well thought-out protection & perfect fit make this a winner!

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-24: Bought this case/ Holster combination to replace the same case after I trashed the holster clip.PROS:Rubber case fit well around all necessary ports on the phone.Metal 'holder' fit well around the rubber case. Looked quite good.Kickstand worked well enough to support the phone on my desk either vertically or horizontally.Holster had a locking mechanism that I had to use at the end of it's life due to the spring wearing early.(See CON).Phone assembly fit well into the holsterMetal backing held in the rear camera lens cover.CONS:Holster clip popped off a few times. Granted there was some pressure on the holsters due to my leaning against something.The little rear camera cover hole did not retain the camera cover worth a hoot. Ended up just cutting that off anyway.Given that I bought this twice, I did buy another Seidio for my Galaxy Note II that I just got a few weeks ago. GREAT COMBO.

    Rating: 4

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-02-28: I wasn't sure if this power bank would be good quality, as RavPower sounds like some Chinese knockoff brand. I was pleasantly surprised. It actually is good quality. It worked perfectly on vacation with my iPhone 5. I did need to bring my own lightning USB cable, since it does not come with one, but that was ok. My only complaint is that the button to turn on and off the battery is pretty easy to activate accidentally, so its best to keep it in the included pouch when not using it.

    Rating: 4

    2014-03-04: Cell phones and tablets have become very popular in the last decade. Everyone either has an Android or Apple device, and many times we aren’t within range of an outlet to charge our device. Fortunately RAVPower has made the RAVPower Luster 6000mAh External Battery to suit the common person whom requires a little extra charge for their smart device.Inside the packaging is the Luster External Batter, a micro USB charger, a carrying bag, and an instruction manual. RAVPower has not only made a compact power bank but an aesthetically pleasing one that comes in four colors: Black, Blue, Gold, or Pink. I chose Black, as it is what I prefer most of my electronics to be.The coiled micro USB charger can be stretched to 24 inches, but I could only personally stretch it to 20.5 inches before the coiled wire became resistant to stretching. It is great that this only includes one connector, unlike the larger versionRAVPower Deluxe External Battery Charger 14000mAh. The larger version includes several unneeded connectors, which are prone to losing. Because this version has no connectors, the chance of an important connector isn’t as great. I wish they would also include an AC charger, but I understand they did this to cut costs.This also includes a cloth mesh bag, which not many power banks include. This is great, as it keeps the power bank and all of its contents from being lost or damaged. It is a feature that all RAVPower “Deluxe” brand power banks possess, which adds sophistication that I personally love.The power bank itself is very small (3.9 x 0.8 x 1.6 inches) and is very light (4.3 ounces). It can easily fit any pocket, purse, or back pack without irritating the user. It has a mat black (in my case) finish, with a silver button, a ring of silver at the top, and gray faces for the front and back. The front has the RAVPower logo, a button to activate the power bank (quickpress) or flashlight (3 second press), and under the silver ring is a place for up to 4 blue LED indicators to light up (Listed below).4 Lights On = 75-100%3 Lights On = 50-75%2 Lights On = 25-50%1 Light On = <25%I have seen the indicators blink, and can safely assume 4 solid lights on is fully charged. These LED indicators are somewhat difficult to see in light, as they are under the silver coated plastic. On the top is one 5V 2.1A USB port, one flashlight, and one micro USB port to charge the device. I like that this uses a micro USB cable to charge the device, instead of proprietary charging, as most Android devices require to be charged by micro USB. On the bottom are the specs for this power bank:RAVPowerSeries/Model: Luster/ RP-PB17Capacity: 6000mAhInput: 5V/1.5A (Max)Output: 5V/2.1A (Max)Made in ChinaI then tested this using Kindle Fire 1st generation, running stock Kindle Fire’s modified android OS, with a 44000mAh battery. I tested this with my tablet idling, running no applications or processes. My results are below:7:34pm 7%9:00pm 61%10:00pm 97%In 2.5 hours, my Kindle went from 308mAh to 4268mAh, or 3960mAh total, averaging 1584mAh. These are amazing results for such a small charger in such a short time.3960mAh / 6000mAh = 66% efficientThe total efficiency is around 66% efficient, which is great for an external battery. This is as expected from a company like RAVPower.Overall, I recommend this power bank to any individual needing a compact power bank to charge their device, and is why I give this product 5 out of 5 stars.Pros:+ Compact and light; Can easily fit in any pocket, purse, or back pack without irritating the user.+ Aesthetically pleasing power bank that comes in four color colors (Black, Blue, Gold, or Pink).+ Multifunctional button to either activate power bank or flashlight.+ Uses micro USB instead of proprietary wires. Most android devices require micro USB charging.+ Includes one coiled micro USB wire. Does not include unneeded connectors, such as the larger versionRAVPower Deluxe External Battery Charger 14000mAh.+ Includes cloth mesh bag to keep the power bank and all of its contents from being lost or damaged.Cons:- LED Indicators are somewhat difficult to see, due to silver coated plastic.- Does not include AC charger.I was provided a sample in exchange for an honest and thorough review.

    Rating: 5

    2014-02-01: This battery pack has enough energy to power any mobile device through the day.Having a 6000mAh battery places this battery pack in the middle of the road. Inside is enough power to charge most cell phones multiple times. I use it to charge my Galaxy Note 2, almost getting two full chargesThe size is very portable and can be easily slipped into a pocket or purse.The design is plain and simple, with a single led for a flashlight. In the hand, it has a nice solid feel, nice and sturdy. The size is similar to a pack of "Tic-Tacs". The input/output ports and light are on the same end, with the specs on the other side.Packing a flashlight and sizeable battery power is the perfect for the person on the go. The flashlight is powerful enough to assist in finding your car keys or other small task.Just plug your phone into the charging port and press the silver power button, then watch you power bar fill up. There are four blue LED power lights hidden underneath the chrome collar that show the battery life. This battery will do the job to charge whatever you throw at it, and does it well.CONTENTS:RAVPower Luster 6000mAh Battery PackMicro USB CordMesh Carrying BagFEATURES:Battery Capacity: 6000mAhBattery Type: Li-ionInput: DC 5V/1.5AOutput: DC 5V/2.1ALife Cycles: 500+Charging Time: 5 HoursDimensions: 3.9 x 0.8 x 1.6in (99.1 x 2.0 x 40.6mm)Weight: 4.3oz (121.9g)Warranty: 1 YearPOWER LEVEL INDICATOR:4 Lights: 75-100%3 Lights: 50-75%2 Lights: 25-50%1 Light: 0-25%I was supplied a free sample for the purpose of review and evaluation, and promised an unbiased review.

    Rating: 4

    2012-10-13: The RAVPower Dynamo-on-the-Go is a deceptively small power bank. It measures less than 3 3/4" x 1 3/4" x 7/8" and weighs about 5 oz. but can fully recharge most cell phones two or three times and my iPod Shuffle at least five times. It will also recharge a Kindle or even an electric shaver, really any small electronic device that one of the seven included tips will fit OR which has its own charging cable that fits a USB port.Remember to take the right connecting tips or cables and to push the power button once to start charging a device. It will stop charging automatically when the receiving battery is fully charged or thirty seconds after it's disconnected.I charge the RAVPower Dynamo-on-the-Go with a USB wall converter but it can also charge through a laptop USB port. There's a four-stage LED capacity display initiated by pressing the power button.In addition to the seven adapter tips, two cables are included, one 7" long and one 28" long, plus a thick velveteen pouch that is intended to hold the power bank although I use it to store the extra tips and cable. The Dynamo very sturdy and I have dropped it on the hardwood floor without damage.The LED flashlight is a nice bonus--perfect for finding keys in a purse or to use in an unfamiliar hotel room in the middle of the night without having to turn on a light.The Dynamo-on-the-Go is a necessity for traveling and to keep in the glove compartment but it's also handy to have on hand when you forget to charge your cell phone or MP3 player overnight and need to charge it on-the-run. It's nice not to have to worry so much about having a full charge and I highly recommend these for peace of mind as well as convenience.A sample was provided for unbiased review.EDIT: I used this as both a flashlight and to recharge my little MP3/radio to get the news for a week while the power was out after the hurricane a few weeks ago. This proved so very useful to have on hand.

    Rating: 5

    2012-10-31: great product. I was debating between a bigger battery (& a separate plastic back cover, and a separate phone cover) for my Galaxy S3, or, buy this one. Bought this one, as I don't need to use it everyday, so my phone can stay slim and very pocketable. And keep the RAVpower in my bag for emergency use.The two cables supplied with the RAVPower are pretty good, and I use them both for different charging locations (e.g. hanging off of the monitor's USB port for charging phone while on desk).I would like to see the unit charge my phone faster if possible. For my use case, if I could connect the unit to my phone for 1-hour, I would like to get a 60-70% charge on the phone if possible. that would go a long way.Good quality product, small and sleek.cheers

    Rating: 5

    2013-03-07: This is a superb charger pack. It will recharge an iPod 3 to 4 times from a dead state and the same with my cell phone. It will not, however, fully recharge an iPad from a dead state but its still a respectable charge. Includes a flashlight that requires the on button to be pressed for for about 3 seconds which pretty much eliminates accidentally turning the light on and running the charger down. The pack takes a while to charge but slower charges usually mean that the internal batteries will have longer lives. As with all battery packs, it's good to occasionally fully discharge them, then give them a full, uninterrupted charge. Excellent value, respectable capacity, compact size.

    2012-10-15: I bought the N7 and then had to have a case shipped ridiculously fast due to my inability to maintain electronics without dropping them (thank you Amazon prime!). I chose this one based on the excellent reviews and was startled (happily) to see how inexpensive this gorgeous-looking cover was. Now that I have received it, I can say it is well-done! High quality, a nice trendy color (I got the blue) that I can't possibly misplace (ok, I probably still can) and looks like it cost a lot more than it did.Most importantly, I can now leave the safety of the couch with it, without fear that I'm going to destroy my new N7. I love the on-off magnet, but have noticed it doesn't work ALL the time when closing it. Sometimes it stays on after I close the cover if I'm not careful about how I do it. I leave my screen on for 2 minutes rather than the default, so battery can be a slight concern if you have your display set to stay on longer. Slight. Not enough for me to deduct a star, and this thing turns right on the second I open the cover and that's really the magic for me. The rotating thingamajig works great, and I was able to rotate and prop my N7 and read an entire book yesterday without hand cramps, which is another big plus for me. The tab holding the N7 in place doesn't bother me at all, and while the N7 can shift around a tiny bit, it's not a concern to me as the slippage does not interfere with my viewing of the screen, the camera or any of the access points.My only issue at all is the placement of the power button on the N7 itself, slightly to the back of the machine, which makes finding it by feel while in a case a bit obnoxious for the clumsy people. I don't think a case could accommodate that design "feature" without leaving it susceptible to scrapes and damage to the unit, so no stars off for that either.Overall, I wasn't expecting it to be as beautiful and functional as it is, due to the really affordable price, and I'm thrilled with it.

    2012-09-10: For $20 I have no significant complaints. I'm somewhat disappointed with the low angle and somewhat flimsy support in portrait mode. You cannot clean that glue with alcohol or goo gone, I am not sure what the adhesive is. Takes a lot of work. The lens cover is not recessed like the OEM design, it's actually sticking out, so when you put your phone on the table, the lens are the first ones to get the hit. Incredibly stupid. The color is way off, and the metallic type at the bottom does not look like the OEM part at all. It's bad, poor quality, pathetic excuse for an iPhone back.So that's the product I got from ShopCellParts. Try your luck with another seller, maybe you'll get the right stuff.

    2014-03-31: This magnetic clip works great with my note 3! The top part slides in like a bobby pin and the bottom part sticks to the side of your phone. I have taken out the bottom piece before and it didn't leave any residues. This package also comes with several 'sticky tabs' for re-sticking the bottom piece if one ever decides to remove it, and later decide to use the clip again. The reason I rated this 4 stars instead of 5 is because the top piece sometimes slides around. It doesn't slide a lot, but it once in a while I can see that it had moved. One thing I would mention is that the phone will no longer lie completely flat if the front cover was folded open and tucked to the back. I used to like to take notes like this, but now I have to leave the cover open on the table instead of tucking it behind the phone. I wish Samsung had made a built-in magnet, but they did not so I deem this product as an adequate replacement of what should-have-been. Also, the bottom piece sticks out the side just a little bit, but it doesn't look bad at all nor does it get in the way of normal phone use.

  • B00IPDRRXC

    $B00IPDRRXC

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2014-03-30: This is a very nice charger. It is hard to get too excited about a charger because, well....it's a charger. This is nicely made though. The body is solid and the 30 pin connector locks in nicely to the iPad. I've had some cheaper adapters which connect but fall off easily. Not so on the Xmit.Like many modern adapters this product has a head which plugs into the wall, along with a USB port so you can attach the included USB to 30 pin cable. You can, of course, substitute a different cable to charge a device with a different adapter, such as a Lightning. Of course, always check your specs to make sure you use the an adapter with the right power levels for your device.The cable itself is very nice. Decent gauge cable, and, at 4 feet long, better than Apple's skimpy cables.There is also a little bump on the 30 pin end so you know which end is up.The available colors are a nice feature to me, so you have something a little distinguishable from everyone else's white, or sometimes black, cable and charger.I really like the cable and charger. At close to $35, I think its a bit over-priced, so I rated it 4 stars as opposed to 5.

    Rating: 4

    2014-05-15: This works well and the cord is a good length. Nothing much to say about something like this...it works just like all the other ones. I wish the adapter was sideways to better make use of outlets, though. That'd be my only complaint.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-02: In my mind, the Apple chargers that come with the various products have always been fine with me because I didn't really feel a need to try otherwise. Not to say that the cables and charges didn't break or stop working but because I buy Apple products with enough frequency that I would just get a new cable or go to the Apple store for a replacement.That being said, this Belkin MIXIT charger has really beautiful design. The cable itself is long, sturdy, and shiny - not at all cheap looking. It may seem pricey but I think it's on par with Apple products and you'll get a better construction. At 10W, it is capable of charging both the iPhone and iPad well.

    Rating: 4

    Rating: 5

    2014-03-26: I don't know why Apple devices come with such short cords, but it was nice to get this one with a four foot one. I have used it to charge an almost dead iPad 2 in about an hour. I charged my iPhone 4s in 30 minutes from 12%. I think it looks cool, too, different from the white chargers I got from Apple. It does not look cheap. Good design.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-14: Not much can be said of the MIXIT other than it works.It is a detachable USB wall charger with a 4-foot USB charge cable for the iPhone 4 and 4S, meaning the wall charger can be used to charge anything with a USB connection on one end including a Nintendo 3Ds, Sony PSP, other cell phones, etc. It charges my iPhone 4S in decent time like any other USB charger but seems to be a little quicker and doesn't seem to wear out like the others.There are a LOT of third-party USB charge cables that do the EXACT same thing and some for significantly less but, where the MIXIT differs is overall quality and versatility. I've had many chargers just wear and/or stop charging altogether whereas, after a month on the MIXIT, there seems to be no change in the products performance or charging capabilities.The price may seem a little steep but this sucker will last longer than those cheapies that you find at every gas station. Recommend this as the end-all solution for iPhone 4 chargers.

    Rating: 5

    2014-03-28: My Gen 1 iPad's charging system was getting a bit tired and upon the kids recommendation I selected the Belkin MIXIT Home Charger with 4-Foot 30-Pin Cable for iPhone 4/4S, iPad 3rd Gen and iPad 2 (2.1 AMP/10 Watt) to use with my old iPad. Sure enough the kids were right. The Belkin iPad charging system works very well to charge my iPad.Recommend.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-15: This has lasted longer than the much more expensive iPhone Charger from Apple. It isn't bending or fraying like the Apple brand does.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-21: My The original cable and charging black that came with my iPhone 4S were both beginning to get rather worn after 3 years of non-stop use. The two things I really like about the cable are that it's extremely sturdy and it's 4 feet long.Overall, after a month of use, I'm still very satisfied with my Belkin MIXIT Home Charger and cable.     2011-08-02: I ordered these screen protectors as a stop-gap method for protecting my iPhone screen until I received my Otter case. These protectors would also be good for use on an iPhone if the thickness of an Otter case will not fit into your method of carry. They are a little difficult to line up properly before attaching them to the glass but it can be done. One must be careful to avoid trapping air pockets under the protective sheets while installing them and also make sure the glass surface is completely free of any small dust particles as these will form an air gap bubble under the sheets. The little lint cleaning cloths that come with them are nearly worth the purchase price. The lint cloths can be used even after you receive whatever kind of protective case you are going to employ and will not scratch the surface glass of the iPhone.

    2012-03-12: I did not have much success with this product. The price is certainly good, to the point where I'm not even sure how they can get them to my door for the amount of money paid, much less manufacture and package them. I'm pretty sure these are drop-shipped direct from China, because mine took about four weeks to arrive. (And speaking of dropping, I dropped my phone twice in that span - you might want to order ahead if you know you're going to be getting an iPhone and decide to purchase these covers. But, keep reading.) The instructions for application were cryptic at best, but once I figured out how to remove the plastic sheets from the cover on both sides, I was okay. The lint-free cloth provided, however, did not do a very good job. I screwed up my first cover by pulling off the plastic too soon. The second one had too many dust particles and a bunch of bubbles. The third one was serviceable, but it wasn't completely sticky at the bottom. After about two months, the non-adhesion area grew to about one-third of the surface of the phone. I pulled it off and went withBelkin Clear Screen Protector for Apple iPhone 4S (3 Pack). If you get lucky and get a sticky cover and get the dust off your phone, these will probably work. Still, you'll have to get lucky, so I would say if you're a gambler and don't mind waiting a month for your product to arrive, these are fine or at least, give good cost performance. Otherwise, try the Belkin or something else.

    Rating: 2

    2011-01-26: For the price and s/h free I have no complaint! The tricky part is this film has 3 skins in one, you have to be a bit tactful to peel off till the last skin. In order to do a good job, I choose a dust free environment (not bedroom cos the flying dust will stick on the adhesive skin). I wipe off my iphone 4 with alcohol and eye-glasses cleaning cloth, once I peel off the skin I place it on my iphone immediately. It comes with 2 small labels to avoid leaving finger prints. Pretty effective. The size fits on my iphone well. I'll buy more for future use.

It did not effect the brightness or colors of my screen in any way.I was able to install it without any bubbles except for two tiny little ones that don't bother me at all. The plastic is thick enough to feel durable, yet still responsive. The cutout at the top is wide enough for both the camera and the speaker. Overall, I HIGHLY RECOMMNED this product. The price is fantastic, and prime shipping cannot be beat.

    2014-03-21: This case is one of the more costly units available, but it is well worth it. Unlike other water resistant cases this one adds the minimum amount of bulk to the overall size of the phone. I was initially concerned about how the finger print recognition would perform with the case on the phone. However, I can report that there is no difference in how it works. Purchasers should take care to thoroughly clean all surfaces of the phone prior to putting it into the case as this can have a detrimental effect on performance. Pay particular attention to the display, the home button, the camera lens, and flash. Anything left on these surfaces will effect performance. The only negative comment concerns the screen protector that comes with the case. It is not the anti-glare variety and this is quite annoying. The manufacturer should offer a choice of an anti-glare screen protector as you cannot leave any other screen protector on the phone and use their case. However, the this is the only negative I have found.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-28: My teenage son has a penchant for damaging his iPhones (yes plural) so we insisted that he house his iPhone 5S in a sturdy, protective case. This case is not cheap, but it does the job of protecting an iPhone 5S from just about anything. And it looks very cool, so he likes it. Recommended if the price does not put you off. RJB.

    2013-08-05: Imagine wrapping your iphone in a truck tire!. I've been concerned about dropping my new iphone 5 and damaging it.     Rating: 5

    2013-01-28: I've been using the Griffin Survivor Case for several months and my overall impressions are quite good. The case is very durable and easily withstands everyday (and not so everyday) drops and bumps. The touch screen is very responsive and is an improvement over the iPhone 4 case. It attaches to the outside of the silicone cover. This makes it easy to remove and clean. The removable clip is more durable and has a better over all design then the previous model. On the downside, the case does make it hard to hear the speaker. The silicone cover does a nice job of absorbing shock, but it also tends to stick to your pants pocket when removing it. Also, aftermarket headphone plugs may not fit into the narrow access port designed in the plastic case.I use my iPhone 5 frequently in rugged situations in the wilderness. Despite a few shortcomings, this case more than meets my needs.Pros:1. touch screen is very responsive and easy to remove and clean2. case can take a beating3. case is relatively water resistant and keeps out most dirt and dustCons:1. case make the speaker a bit hard to hear2. silicone cover makes it hard to pull out of your pants pocket3. headphone jack requires a narrow shaft on the plug

    2013-04-23: I have a new Iphone 5. And bought this case as a back up case, just incase (pun). I could not pass it up as I got a super deal here on Amazon.Have not used it because I have one of those LIFEPROOF $100 cases I am using now, that's 100% waterproof. But I did try the Griffin case out and for the average Joe who likes a BELT CLIP case that's rugged it's YOUR case.I'm on a boat all the time, it rains, splashes, etc. So I'll keep using the Lifeproof (way too expensive case) because I have too. But for the average person. The Griffin Survivor is fantastic!MEN, don't do phones in their pockets. WE use belt clips. Especially MEN doing stuff, rather than sitting behind a desk.And it's hard to find cases with this kind of protection with BELT CLIPS. But if you're wet, or gonna get really wet and want a industructable $30 belt clip and a $60+ waterproof case...Go with something like Lifeproof.

    Rating: 4

    2012-12-20: I bought the Survivor for my new iPhone 5 because I'm a sailor so my phone gets exposed to rain and spray, and because I have been known to drop things. Although I did not drop test my phone or dunk it in water, examination of the case convinces me it will be good protection. There were mixed reviews about sound quality -- I can report that sound is fine - mic, earphone, and speaker phone. No problem, sounds like without the case. I had no problem using the touchscreen through the case window. The case is also more comfortable to hold than the bare phone. I like it a lot. This case is, however, a bit bulky: 3/4in thick, 2 7/8 in wide, 5 7/16 in long. Not huge, but a bit big for me to carry in my pocket or on my belt at work. The belt clip provided is secure, but not easy to use. I bought an incipio case for weekday use, and will use the Griffin on the weekends. It takes about a minute to put the case on.

    Rating: 4

    2013-07-03: I hate this case but it's good for what it is... it's just too much for me. if you play football with your phone then it's ok. The flap over the camera is a pain it the butt. It feels poorly made - the rubber flaps have little extra bits on them. The cover gets an 'oil spill' like effect to it on the face cover. It's huge. I just don't like it. Back to my old case.

    Rating: 3

    2014-07-10: This was a great case I still use it after about a year of having it still working great

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-11: This is a seriously protective case for the iPhone 5! Though, I would never put it to the test like Griffin does!The case consists of 4 parts:1. A plastic shell for the bottom and sides of the phone. This has holes for all ports, speaker, etc.2. A thick rubber cover that locks over the plastic shell and provides tight fitting covers for all ports, camera, etc. This covers the bottom, sides, and provides a raised ridge of rubber above the screen.3. A plasic screen cover that locks securely onto the rubber shell. This does include a screen protector.4. A clip on rotating belt clip. The clip pops open and locks in a position to provide a stable "landscape" stand to watch videos, etc. The belt clip also locks in the closed position if you wish to keep the jaws from opening and getting caught on your pocket when sliding it in, should you not want to clip it.This case is very substantial, once on the phone you cannot see the clean lines of your iPhone 5 any longer, but you know that the $800+ investment is quite protected from damage and the elements. I wouldn't call it water-proof, but I would say that it protects against small amounts of spillage and major dust.The only con I have found is the plastic screen protector is raised above the screen and it takes a bit to get used to what is needed for touch controls with it on, especially if you are used to using the phone without a cover or a screen protector. But once I got used to it, it hasn't been a problem.So far, no one has complained they can't hear me with this on, and I have had no problems hearing callers when using the phone in regular mode and with the speakerphone.I highly recommend this case to protect the investment in the iPhone 5. They don't call it the survivor for nothing!

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-09: The screen corners weren't able to touch like full use of your iphone =hard to play games and the such, and back cover camera piece broke off the 2nd day.

    Rating: 3

    2013-04-19: Five star quality case.Great cost.Huge!Buttons don't always line up. You need to push on the case a little to have them line up. The clip covers the charging hole, so you can't use the clip stand while charging the phone. This case is a lot bigger than my wife's cell phone case! Still have not decided if I like the clip on belt.Easy to take the font face off for cleaning. Unlike same iPad case that we own, the back camera flap swivels down. The iPad case folds and will not hold in place. This is a big positive! Clip allows phone to face in our out on your belt.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-08: The first thing youll notice about this case is its a big one! huge! definitely provides the drop protection.Well thought design but seriously flawed.The black tape that covers the ear piece, speaker, and mic ports make the phone pretty much useless.The camera cover on the back covers up the noise cancelling mic and every now and then when covered you will hear a static on your phone. That basically the mic not knowing what to do in louder situations.So, remove the tape, open the camera cover when talking, and you have a perfect case.

    Rating: 3

    2013-05-11: I've had a Tune Belt arm band for my iPhone 4 and used it for years while running. I was very pleased with it. I purchased this unit after updating to iPhone 5. I also have a BodyGuardz screen protector and my second biggest issue with this case is the plastic screen cover will stick to the face of my iPhone. This makes taking the iPhone out of the arm band very difficult.My biggest issue with this arm band is the plastic 'O' that holds the strap. You can see it on the last product image, on the right side of the face of the arm band. There's nothing to secure that ring in place and it rotates when you try to tighten the band. This forces the band into the smaller top and bottom part of the O ring. When you tighten the strap around your arm the now smaller strap digs into your arm. If you manage to keep it in place while you tighten the strap, during your run it will rotate and slightly loosen the strap. I'm forced to find some way to sew or clip that ring in place so it doesn't rotate.This is a major design flaw and I expected better from Tune Belt.

    2014-07-09: Did not provide a secure fit when inserted into the A/C vent of my Kia Optima. This product places your phone virtually flush against the vent so in my case, I could only orient the phone vertically and as I went over bumps in the road, the phone shook and bounced eventually falling out of the a/c vent, mount and all, onto the floor of my car. For this amount of money it should be a lot more reliable and not shake and rattle as you drive. It is also a bit more difficult to both insert your phone into the car mount and remove it when you exit the vehicle, a definite two handed operation. I must say that although it looks great, is small and seems really techie I was very disappointed with it's real world performance. If you rent cars on a regular basis and want a car mount that you can take with you when you travel, then this small product may be what you are looking for as it is relatively tiny, has almost no weight and can be used for brief periods of time to hold your phone. Just remember that the phone/mount combination will fall out of the a/c vent onto the floor so don't place any hard objects on the floor that might damage you phone when it drops. Great concept, needs improvement.

    Rating: 3

    2014-03-30: I got this so I could mount my Nexus 5 in my car. I'm really picky about what I wanted.The airframe is probably the best option for a car mount for those who don't want to or can't stick a giant suction cup to their windshield or glue something to their dashboard.

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-04: I have always used the cup holders in the car to stash my device--it is quick, painless, and I can easily prop the device in the cup holder so that the screen faces me.Decided to make use of my Sprint Unlimited Plan on a recent road trip and see how the Google Maps Navigation worked. Nav worked great, but the device would heat up so periodically I had to hold the device over the A/C vents. Upon returning home, decided to look for a car mount that would keep the device in front of the vents for constant cooling.You'd be surprised how many clunky and ugly mounts are out there, but this one is simple and elegant and works perfectly. Since it is universal, any of our family's devices can be placed in this mount securely. The 4 prongs on the back can be turned 90 degrees so you can choose which way to mount it (tighter grip or more loose grip on the vents) plus the minimalistic design makes it possible to plug your device into the car charger regardless of where your charging port is located (side, bottom, top of device). Love it!

    Rating: 5

    2014-07-02: Great for my samsung phone.Since my phone gets super hot when its using google maps, plus with the summer heat it's super handy when its mounted to the air vent with the AC on keeps your phone cool, and holds it securely.You can probably do some donuts and ruin your tires before your phone falls of the mount. =)

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-20: The clips that hold this unit to the vent are short and mine failed in a very short period of time, perhaps due to the air conditioning being on for a total of 2 hours. I don't see this as an acceptable solution.

    2014-01-13: The title of this review says it all - I've not had a car dock this discreet, functional and well made before. I'm using it with an iPhone 5S with a thin case on, and it's steady regardless of the road service. Highly recommended.

    2014-02-17: Air Frame stays put does not jiggle, does not more even if pushing on phone. Limited to Vent mount only, or similar slim mount/credit card size.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-30: It works. It's slightly flimsy and it does block the air flow from that vent, but otherwise, it works like they say it does. I have a big ol' top-of-the-dash mount as well, but end up using they Airframe as it keeps the phone out of site and isn't as distracting. Probably more legal too.

    Rating: 4

    2013-12-20: Saw the Airframe in a friends car & knew it was "the one". No bulk, seemingly secure & puts your phone closer & more easily visible than the top of dash or windshield options. I recently bought the Amazon Basics holder which works great, but again the Airframe so much smaller & having the phone just above the radio superior to resting on the dash.Just search "phone holder" on Amazon & you'll see how different the design is & what I mean. It is designed to fit snugly on air vent blades & does in my car. Placing it on a blade so the bottom of the phone leans into the dash seems to keep it stable.It is relatively expensive for what it is, but the value is in the design & function.I guess durability over time will be the real test.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-04: I love this product. It puts your phone in a natural spot in most vehicles and holds it solid. It will not hold a phone in a thick case or a battery case though. I wish there was one more intermediate "click" in the rotation angle to accomodate cars with slanted vent lines.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-19: Update 07/05/14:Apparently this review has gotten a lot of views and some comments, so I thought I would update it.My wife got frustrated with another car mount that I had with clips that are more difficult to install and remove (because she thinks it's a big eyesore and she didn't want to look at it) so she ripped it out and broke it - without remorse. So, I went back to trying to make this clip work. It doesn't play well with my Sony Xperia Z with a case, so I just roll without a case now. It does makes it easier to clip in and out without using the case, and I've gotten better at it with practice. I can clip my phone in one handed now that I've gotten used to the action of the springs, you need to push up against the right side of the clip to open it up. Removing is tricky but still doable, and sometimes it does slide around on vents - though I can do it now without it completely falling off the vents.Someone, commented that they had no problem using this case with an LG G2 phone. My father has that phone so I'm familiar with it. What makes my phone any many other big android phones different is that the LG G2 has all the buttons on the back, so that means you can clip it right in the middle and you can man handle the phone without worrying about pressing any buttons - as apposed to my phone which has the volume rocker and power button taking up most of the middle of the phone, leaving only a little area in the top or bottom. I've got to feel for where the buttons are on my phone and clip it in so that it doesn't keep pressing down on the volume, and I've done this enough times now that I've gotten used to it. However, even though I've gotten better at clipping in my phone it's still wobbles when I drive since I can only clip in from the bottom or top. I like to keep my phone in landscape, for gps etc, so my phone falls over completely upside down, so I've found a work around for that as well. I've figured out a vent placement that let's me put the phone in a lopsided landscape mode where one side of the phone rests against a radio nob - it doesn't leave any room for adjustment, and the screen is very crooked but at least it's not flopping around any more.Since I have found a way to make this work, I'm bumping up my original 1 star review to a 3 star. I've had to make comprises to make this car mount work and it's not perfect, but it's ok.Original Review:At first I thought this was an awesome minimalist design. I even showed it off to friends and recommended it. However after using it for some time I have changed my opinion and decided it's terrible in practical use.Clip. The way it attaches to your vehicle is with slide on clips - they are metal clips with rubber boots on them - and you slide it onto your ac vents. The rubber pieces detached from mine after removing it from the vents only after a few times. I reattached them with epoxy. However even still it doesn't hold still. It's constantly wiggling loose. You can bend the clips a little bit to get them tighter, but that doesn't help, it still wiggles loose.Clamp. It clamps onto your phone by a spring loaded side clamps. The force of the spring is very strong. It makes sense because it has to really hold onto your phone, but it's really strong. If you have an iphone your phone is much narrower so it's a little easier, if you have an android phone and one with a bigger screen (like mine at 5") the phone is bigger so you have to really fight with the clamps to open wide enough. It's is a two handed affair to clip your phone in and out, and it's not fast and easy at that. It's a struggle each time to pull and grab and at the same time the weak vent clip doesn't hold tight so the whole thing wiggles around and half the time just pops off the ac vent.Clamp length. This was obviously designed to fit thin square edged phones (ie iphone) and not much else, because it only extends out a short length, plus it has pointy rubber hooks that are supposed to hold the phone edges, but they are too short for larger devices so it ends up only holding your phone in with pointy rubber hooks and not whole side. If you have a case, it probably won't fit or hold tight. If you have a phone with a rounded back, it probably won't hold. If you have a phone with an extended battery pack, it probably won't fit. I had a phone with an extended battery pack with a rounded back and it would go in, but one bump in the road or a turn and it would pop off and the phone would go flying into the foot well, where I have to hope it doesn't slide under my brake or gas pedal or I don't wreck trying to grab for it. I upgraded to a new phone and it's too big with a case, well it fits just barely with a very minimal case but it's a struggle and it doesn't hold very well.Narrow design. Because it only holds with two narrow clamps it may be a challenge to find a place to clamp onto your phone securely. Most android phones have power and volume rockers on the side (and around the middle or at least mine do), so you basically have to clamp onto a bottom or top edge, which makes the phone top or bottom heavy - which relating to the issue of the wobbly vent clamp - it causes the phone to tilt and move around quite a lot while driving. I have to constantly readjust the angle of the phone and I drive a prius v for goodness sakes so it's not like I'm hot rodding it.So basically I would only consider this if you have an iphone without a case or a very minimalist case. I'm way past my time to return, so I'm going to stick it in a drawer and move on to the another car mount.

    Rating: 3

    2014-01-12: I am still in awe as to how creative, well-designed, and simple this phone holder is. It's so compact for carrying around if needed and sturdy enough to hold my Galaxy S4 phone w/ TPU case pretty stable on the vent of my '05 Accord Coupe. My wife's Nexus 5 phone with case also fit just fine. There was still a little bit more room to stretch so if you have a thicker case for any of these phones (or comparably sized smartphone), there shouldn't be any issues fitting them in this phone holder.I was a bit hesitant to spend $25 when there are other holders for cheaper, but after some use I have absolutely no regrets. All the other ones on the market are significantly larger and obstructs your windshield view one way or another. However, Airframe's holder solves both issues.The only only negative is that it obstructs one of your vents so if your car doesn't allow you to close that particular vent, be cautious about heat blowing on the phone.Great product and highly recommended even at the relatively higher price point.

    Rating: 5

    2014-07-09: Functions perfectly. Very small. Does the job. All that i ask for.

I like to build stuff myself, so i created a piece to bold these two mounts away from direct cold or hot air.overall, they are good to hold your phone.

But once you do it hold it in place.     Rating: 5

    2014-02-05: The device has two slots that x-cross. One slot is larger than the other. The holder does swivel, allowing you to choose the slot that's appropriate for your vent. The blades that run horizontally on my vent do go up and down to adjust air direction. However, I have found that when I clip my phone in I don't have movement issues.The clip has tension, which will allow you to expand it to put your phone in and then pulls tight. It's tight enough to hold your phone. During the cold weather it may be good to turn the vent off (if you have the option) to avoid blowing hot air on your device.When not in use, it's not an ear sore. Also, it's easily removed and doesn't take up a lot of storage space.

    Rating: 5

    2014-03-27: This is VERY INCONVENIENT for daily use. So much so, that I consider it DOA for daily commutes.This mount has to be mounted/unmounted with my smartphone four times a day for my drive to and from work.Part of its problem is that when attached to the air vents, the weight of the Kenu Airframe and a modern smartphone pull the air vent downward, as if you wanted air to blow into your lap.But that makes it hard to see and touch the smartphone or an iPod.I have a large smartphone. Its within the spec of what the Kenu holds, but when you add on the smartphone protector, I have to work the Kenu with both hands to get the phone into the mount. And that's after taking off the silicone outer shell of my phone protector first (which has to be found and put back onto the phone at the end of my commute)This dog has fleas. And we haven't even talked about whether or not you want your vehicle's heater or AC blowing directly into your phone for your commutes.Kenu m i g h t be good for a non-smartphone or perhaps for a very small smartphone circa 2011, but the weight of most phones now will make this mount turn downard. And whether your device fits easily into the Kenu or not, mounting and unmouting it 4 times a day defeats its purpose.The Kenu Airframe is like tying your shoes with your eyes closed four times a day. You could do it. But you wouldn't want to.

    2014-07-18: This is the second phone holder I purchased. I initially bought the "Do Good Have FunTM Car Phone Mount for Windshield" on Amazon for $14.     2014-06-12: Compact, unobtrusive, fantastic gripping power yet easy to insert and remove phone..The best solution I've found for a non-permanant mount in a car…at least our cars. The best solution was to place the iPhone in between the speedo and tach in a small indent that holds the info screen. Naturally that blocked the display of information in that area. This not only solves that issue but it's so small that it's not noticeable when not using it.
