    Rating: 5

    2014-06-29: Let's face it. Our phones are way better technology than the junk in our cars. Either you have the latest, most state of the art navigation and music playing system in your car (in which case in 2 years you will laugh at it) or you don't and your phone is already better.Over the last few years I have realized that I'd much rather prefer to use my phone as a navigation tool (such as the Waze app) or a Music Player (to stream spotify or an audio book). When I do find the instance that I use my car navigation system, I am dismayed that I don't have dynamic routing, traffic reports, updated map data and so on.If you car has bluetooth, then you are pretty much set. All you need is power (an article for a future post) and a mount for your phone. I have been doing some research on phone mounts for our cars, and one that I can take on trips where I am driving a rental car around and using my phone to find my way.My research has ended with what I have found to be a fantastic solution to having visibly of my phone in a hands free configuration... so enter the Kenu Airframe.What is it?The Kenu Airframe [24.95 @ Amazon in Black and White] is a contraption that you attach to your heating/AC vent in your car. It attaches to the plastic fins, and stays secure. Then you attach your phone to it. It has the added benefit that when you have the AC on it cools your phone down, which on a hot day is necessary as the GPS can burn up the battery, heat the phone and prevent it from charging.Why did you get it?I wanted something that was easy to place my phone in for my commute every day, and have the ability to stream music or use Waze to find the best route home in traffic. I was particularly interested in something that did not attach to the dashbaord (possibly ruining the dashboard) or the front windshield (illegal in some states).I also wanted something portable that I could take on a vacation or trip.I ended up buying 3 of them. One for my car, my wife's car and for travel.How has it made your life better?It's really high quality, easy to install and remove, and won't damage the car. It allows me to keep my phone at a convenient arm's length and keep me focused on driving and not looking around for my phone.

    2014-04-03: Why is it so hard to find a high-quality, simple cell-phone holder for the car? Seems like the only options are cheapo dash-mounts, or the insane windshield mounts with the long arms.     Rating: 5

    2014-02-20: I travel weekly and drive a different rental car each week. I don't normally go to the same place so everywhere I visit, it's a new adventure. Therefore, I rely heavily on the GPS function of my phone to get my bearing. But having a mounting mean for the phone so that I can conveniently install and disconnect it has been a quest until now. I have used all sorts of mounting mean from window mount, cigarette receptacle mount, dash mount, antiskid pads, vents mount, etc... Each type of mount has pros and cons, but the biggest part is the size and complexity of the design. I have ended it up using a window mount, but I have to assemble and disassemble it to use it every time. The round mounting sucker (foot) doesn't lend itself to ease of packing, so I have to fiddle with arranging everything to fit in the case. Depending on rental car, some dc charger outlet could be very far from the windshield mount, so sometimes, my cable was too short... Since I need the mount weekly, I got a small Eaglecreek travel pouch to keep the mount, the dc charger, and a cable together; this pouch is the first to come out of my laptop bag and is the last to go back...All of that has changed since I got my hands on this Kenu Airframe. I was reasonably skeptical of its simple design and its tiny size, until I was assured by the salesperson that I can return it if it doesn't work for me. I bought it while on the road, and Bam! that was it, much to my surprise... Simple is good! Simple is effective! Simple is compact! So far I have tested it with 5 different cars, and it work perfectly every time. Since the air vent is at the front dash board below my vision view of the windshield, my phone sits exactly where I want it... and it's close to the dc charger so I can keep my cable reasonably short (less bulk in packing).I use this mount with a Sprint LG G2 and an Incipio case. The case has antiskid frame which matches up with the antiskid arms of the mount, forming a tight hold. Without the case, the phone sits deeper into the arms. So in either scenario, the phone is secured. The spring load is strong enough to hold on to the phone. Time will tell if this spring loaded mechanism holds up through frequent usage. My phone is large so the arm is stretched out to its max...To sum up, this little mount is very effective. No assembly required for installation. No fuss. Super compact. And it can be mounted vertical or horizontal by rotating the back foot... IMHO, I think this may be the best engineered solution on car mount thus far. Way to go Kenu...

    2011-10-13: I didn't buy these to take a a cell phone apart, but rather a Tablet PC and they were worked flawlessly. I couldn't be happier with the result. No scratches on the tablet and not one single broken part as I used these to slowly pry around the edge of the aluminum case to split it from its plastic underside. I upgraded the tablet with an SSD Drive to get more performance and battery life and could not have done as good a job without this purchase for sure. Worth far more than the sales price when you calculate not breaking and replacing parts due to improperly dismantling a project as delicate as a small piece of electronics that was never really meant to be opened by the consumer.

    2011-11-08: This is one of the few chargers that can charge hi-capacity batteries, so that's definitely a plus. The indicator light even turned green when it was fully charged, and I've never noticed any overcharging at all, so I suspect it's turning off the charger when the battery is fully charged - something I was unsure if it'd actually do, given the price.I haven't tried the USB output, though, so I can't speak to how well that works or if it impacts the charging rate.In the end, if you carry a spare battery, this is an incredibly useful device to have for keeping the spare charged.

They really do work, and they do deliver 2.1 and 1.0 power as they say they will do. They do the job.You wouldn't expect much QC for a $2 electrical product, but they each work just fine.They don't last forever-- about a year or two of active daily use seems about par, then they suddenly die. So do have some replacements on hand. At this price, no problem.Yes, they work with both my iPhone and iPad. Also with every other USB device I've needed to charge.The LED light that indicates you are plugged in correctly is very helpful.These are great for rental cars and travel. If you leave one behind, hey, it's only $2.I'm totally pleased with these clever little gems. No complaints. I wouldn't be without a couple, especially for travel.Hope this is helpful.     Rating: 4

    2014-01-18: Well I was very surprised when I received this very high quality stand for many reasons. What I like best is it will hold portrait and landscape many different size and types of devices. Most all of these were tested in this stand with their TPU thick covers on the device. And I tested this with several phones and also I tested this on several sixes of tablets: a 7 inch tablet, 8 inch tablet and 10 inch.Below I list in the PROS my actual test findings and more info on this stand as to the features of it:PROS:+ Phones and MP3 players (large and small) I tested and how this stand performed - First I tested my large Samsung Galaxy 5 MP3 Player with the TPU Cover on. Even at 1/2 inch thickness, this stand held my player in portrait and landscape SECURELY!Samsung Galaxy S4 with a thick silicone cover on it - fits fine. Samsung Galaxy Grand with TPU cover fits fine in portrait and landscape.+ Tablets - So I tested 3 Samsung Galaxy tablets: 1) Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 with TPU cover (thickness of 1/2 inch). This fit perfectly both landscape and portrait. Note that this particular tablet is very heavy (compared to Tab 3 line or iPads), and it fit very securely. 2) Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 8.0 with TPU cover (not as heavy or thick as the Tab 2 7.0), this tablet fit beautifully in the stand for portrait or landscape. 3) Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 (this is a very heavy and thick tablet). I do not have a TPU cover for this, so I placed it into the stand with no cover and it fit perfectly in portrait and in landscape. **If it can fit this bulky and heavy tablet, it can fit most any device with ease!+ Adjustments - There are FOUR total adjustments on this stand once you open it from the folded mode.1) Upright (tall) mode (for leaning the device more upright) - this is the top adjustment on the back of the stand -- be sure that you press this in the top groove to LOCK the stand's back for security.2) More flat mode (Lounge-chair mode for leaning the device at more of an angle backwards- This is when you want more of a backward angle when say you are watching a video, movie, this kind of thing. Be sure to lock in this on the bottom groove in the stand to make sure it is secure and stays in place.3) Device stand standard mode - This is where you stand your phone or tablet. So in the regular mode you can really fit a thicker device in this stand and sometimes I use this. But when I have a thinner device such as a thin phone, I go to locking stand mode (below).4) Locking stand mode - I advise this one for phones! To secure this mode for your phone do this: Pull down the bottom part of the stand (the part where you place your phone) until you hear it make a snapping sound. Then place your phone into the stand. You will see right away if you look on the side view that this seems to hug the table better on the bottom and it grabs onto the phone better making it more secure. *Suggestion: Use this if you have a thinner phone. For me, I use this stand for my Galaxy Player 5 which is thick at 1/2 inch deep and so I use the standard mode on that.** Front standing modes: May I suggest that you try each one of the front device stand modes and see which one you prefer and which one works better on your phone.+ Charging my devices in this stand (and using them at the same time) - For me I can easily charge my phones in portrait mode while in this stand (the Samsung phones and Samsung MP3 player). The 7 and 8 inch tablets I can also charge and use at the same time in this stand if they are in landscape mode. Yes, I was also able to charge my Tab 2 10.1 (in portrait mode) wonderfully and even got it to charge in landscape (turning it upside down). Although this is not a docking station, I use it almost like it is because of the charging ability (it has a large open part at the bottom in which to insert your charging cable into the stand/device).+ Overall quality, design and portability- The quality I found very good. The design I love because of all the adjustments and best of all all the many types and sizes this stand will accommodate!The fact that it folds makes this stand easy to fold and go and use at work, at home, anywhere! Yet for me, I have one on my bedside table and one I keep in my purse for when I am on the go!Highly recommend this stand!

    2013-02-18: Good quality. The non-slip silicone rings provide stability. In general, this product simply serves its purpose. Would be better if more height levels was provided.

    Rating: 3

    2014-06-05: There are a lot of stands out there. These are the ones you want. I bought four of them total after the first one. They fold flat. They are sturdy. They hold everything solidly from a Moto X to a Note 3. They don't skid. They lock in place and unlock easily. They are inexpensive. The ONLY thing I question is the lifespan of the silicone bands used for non-skid, butI doubt they will fail any time soon, longevity being a characteristic of silicone. Buy them. Buy several. They are as close to perfect as you will find.

    Rating: 4

    2014-01-20: My wife and I purchased new iPhone 5S phones and needed screen protectors. These were a perfect fit for this device and relatively easy to install. You will need to use a microfiber cloth to clean your phone face completely. I used the cleaner my optometrist provided for my glasses since it cleans without residue and streaks. Make sure it is completely dry and free from even the smallest dust particles. Start from one end, removing just the edge of the cover film, align the screen cover with the edges of the phone face, then gently pull of the film, applying to the phone face as you go. Once it is installed, use the microfiber cloth over your thumb to push any air bubbles out of the edge to smooth the application. Once it is completely installed pull the tab to remove the cover film from the other side of the protector.

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-16: They really make your phone into a mirror. The only cation I would ad is that it makes it a little hard to see through in direct sunlight. I ended up taking it off while on vacation but put another one back on as soon as I was back.

The in car feature is great as it stay and doesn't fall, I also love that you can spin the phone with out removing it from the clip. The long flexible extension is my favorite feature. I clamp it onto my head board on my bed to easily watch you tube videos, Netflix, Amazon instant video and send messages. This is truly a great product and I would recommend it to anyone. This would make a great gift as I might purchase another as a gift to my aunt.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-09: i tried all kinds of car cell phone holders and finally found the one that works. Where others use up cup holders, block air conditioner vents or need to be attached o a windshield, this one is attached under my car seat with its heavy duty clip, it has a long flexable goose neck so you can position the way you like and lastly, one great phone clip.     Rating: 1

    2012-05-02: I bought this product to be able to attach USB devices to my Galaxy Tab 10.1.Pro's:1. Small2. Works while the tablet is in its Gumdrop Box3. Reads USB cards4. Plugs securely into the Galaxy Tab 10.1.Con's:1. Connectivity is "iffy"2. Lacks the power sharing to operate an external harddrive without a separate power source (Seagate Free Agent Go drive 320 Gb gets its power through the USB connection and will not power on with this device even when Galaxy tab is at 100% charge and power saving is off.)3. Slow to identify a connected USB4. Plug seems to want to "hang up" a little when attempting removal from the tablet and requires care to remove it perfectly straight.Conclusion:If all I'm using this for is to connect to a thumb drive or read photos off my camera's SD card inserted into a single small SD card reader, it works OK. I think it may work with my desktop external hard drive because it utilizes an idependent power source, but I haven't tried it, yet. As for sharing files off my Seagate Go drive that runs off USB power, it doesn't work at all except to inform me a "high powered USB drive is connected and cannot run." I gave it a 3-Star rating of "It's OK." For $6.00 you can access SD memory cards and possibly large external hard drives with independent power sources (maybe). If you're looking for more functionality, you may want to keep looking.

    2011-03-16: After shopping around for some time for a car charger for my iPhone4, I settled on this model. One feature I like is the plug lights up very well when plugged in, hence you're not looking for a microscopic green light to let you know the charger is fully plugged in. The contact for the phone may be a bit large for some cases, but I've had no trouble with mine...which are the inexpensive ones. While charging, it's a good idea to place your iPhone4 in a location where it won't be moved. I've noticed that if I pick up the phone to talk or text (obviously not while driving) that the contact can come loose. Simply pressing it back in place will solve the problem. For me, that's minor but for others, it may be a deal killer...so just be aware. On a final positive note, I've noticed this charger will charge my iPhone4 very quickly and that alone is worth the price. When the battery is almost exhausted, it's back up to at least 25-30% in no time at all. It may not be the 'best' or most expensive iPhone charger, but for the thrifty, I recommend it without hesitation.

    Rating: 4

    2012-02-02: This device charges my 4S with no problems. The cord is a little shorter then I'd like, and the overall construction feels a little cheap, but what more can I ask for? It surely beats paying $35 in store.EDIT: Stopped charging my iPhone. When plugged in it shows that I'm charging, but the battery percentage doesn't rise. Still, three stars for being really cheap and working for a couple of months.

    Rating: 2

    2013-04-05: This power cord is a great replacement for the standard dual use cord that comes with your phone. By dual use, I mean, the standard cord that comes with your phone is a usb data cable with a dc power plug on the end. Sometimes I am using the phone and just one twist or tug of the line and the cable will disconnect from the dc power supply, which I imagine will cause the data cable to short out over time and also may ruin the battery. Phone companies just got cheap and decided to stop sending phones with a power cable AND a data cable separately, but in the end, you will go out and get yourself a standard power cable...like this one, which is just fine...quality-wise and price-wise. Yep. Oh, and this does have a big red light that comes on once you plug it into the wall, whether your phone is plugged to it or not, so if you are one of those nit picky sleepers that needs a completely dark room to sleep, you stick yourself a small piece of black electrical tape over the light, because it is brighter then you may think.

    2013-08-19: I received a 'for review' unit from the makers or sellers of iFLASH. I did not promise them a good review and they did not ask for one in exchange.This iFLASH may be small but at 4400 mAh it carries enough juice to fully power up an iPhone 5 (1,440 mAh) at least twice or a Galaxy S III (2,100 mAh) once with some left to spare - keep in mind that the energy transfer is not 100% efficient so don't expect three iPhone 5 charges. Small size and simplicity is what makes this model different and it can be your favorite battery pack for as long as your phone charges through a Micro USB port (or you can supply your own wire) and you supply your own wall charger.It does come with essential accessories: a charging cable that can be used to either charge your phone and charge it and a nice bluish nylon mesh bag to hold the iFLASH and the USB wire. Besides its ability to charge a phone once you plug it in - and do NOT attempt to use it with anything larger such as a tablet - the only other features are a blue-LEDs charge meter that activates once you press the one white button once and a one-LED flashlight capability that turns itself on or off if you double-tap the white button.I am very found of this model and can't think of any negatives other than the shiny white finish being a fingerprint magnet but I don't know anyone who would spend much time staring at a battery pack. So five stars it is.

    2013-09-25: Power Bank Evaluation - iFlash 4400 Backup External Battery Pack - WhiteThis is intended as a cell phone charger - not a tablet charger, since it only charges at 1 AmpmAh - 4400#and Amps of Charging ports - 1 Charging port, only 1 Amp (Instructions state that it is intended for digital communication devices requiring a DC5V input). Please be sure your device will charge using this battery pack.Physical size - Small, fits easily in a pocket, less than 6 ouncesHow is the battery pack charged - Uses included micro charger cable. No charger included, you will need your own or will need to charge this battery pack using your computer.What cords/attachments are included - a single micro charger cable is included. It is used to charge the device and can also be used to charge your cell phone. If you need something other than a micro charger you will need to provide your own cable.What other features/items are included - Flashlight- The flashlight is turned on by clicking the on/off button twice. There is a handy mesh bag to carry your cord and battery together (a nice touch).Instructions - The instructions are tiny but readable in relatively clear English. Photos make it clear.Support Information - No support information provided.Special Note - I actually received this about a month and a half before I had a chance to test it out.     2013-08-11: While a large power capacity is helpful, it does have the downside of making a powerbank somewhat heavy and bulky. This iFlash powerbank takes the slim road - very easy to carry, but it offers only 4400mAh of capacity.It is attractively designed with a white plastic case with a blue accent stripe along the edge. The on/off button is also blue, as is the charge level "gas gauge." Nice color coordination. The build quality is solid - no rattles, well-anchored ports, and nice smooth seams on the case. The corners are all rounded to make it more comfortable to slip into a pocket. Although it comes with a carry pouch, it's really not needed since the powerbank is so compact (roughly 3.75 inches long and 1.75 inches wide).In addition to serving as a powerbank, there's an LED flashlight that is controlled with the on/off switch (double press to turn the flashlight on). It's a single LED, but puts out a decent amount of light.The capacity limits the practical use of this for phone or small device (e.g., ipod, mp3 player, etc.) charging. There's not enough reserve to make a meaningful recharge of a fully-depleted tablet. But, in a pinch it can be used to restore some measure of battery charge to pretty much anything that has a USB charge cable.If you're willing to trade a large battery capacity for ease of transportability, this is well worth considering.[sample provided for review]

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-18: This white-and-blue battery offers a little bit of fun with the color and a more practical 4400mAh charge, about enough to charge my iPhone 5 once fully, with about half a charge remaining. Not a lot, but enough for most situations. It is an attractive option for anyone who rarely needs to recharge but who wants the security of having extra power nearby. The construction is solid and smooth. I can't believe I'm saying this about a battery, but . . . I love the way it feels in my hand because of its rounded, glossy case.I am so dependent on my iPhone that I cringe when I see the battery depleting with no options in the near future to recharge, and that's why I never travel without an external battery. This iFlash battery's capacity is too small for power-hungry devices such as the iPad. It's best to purchase this only if you want to use it exclusively for your smart phone. For tablets, you would be better off with an 8400mAh external battery, although the trade-off is a larger, heavier power source. This iFlash is sized perfectly to stash in a handbag or briefcase.This iFlash battery comes with nothing more than a blue mesh pouch for storage and a USB charging cable. You will have to supply your own device-specific USB cable to charge your device. You may want to get an extra but short smart phone cable to keep in the pouch; otherwise, you may find yourself in need of a charge without the ability to do it. Charging the battery takes a few hours and can be done at home. I do my charging overnight, although it takes much less time than that. But charging my phone takes just a little more time than it would plugged into a wall. My iPhone 5 went from 14% to full charge in about an hour and a half.Because of the price, this external battery would make a great stocking stuffer, particularly for teenagers and college students. The white version looks more girly than the black one, but it has the advantage of hiding fingerprints better. (Note: I received a sample for review.)-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann

    2013-08-05: When I first tried out an iFlash battery pack, I had no idea of its capabilities. I've since tried out several of them and have come to appreciate how well they perform. They are right up there with the best of them and I've discovered that they are quite impressive in the power department. This particular battery pack is more user-friendly, especially if you only want to have a battery pack on hand to power up your iPhone or iPod. This unit also comes inblackif you prefer.There are several ways to charge the iFlash including through your PC, an AC wall charger, or even a car charger. I usually charge this type of battery pack by plugging it into my PC and leaving it overnight. You will of course, have to provide your own USB cables, which usually isn't a problem. This is a minimalist unit for those who don't want all the extras that sometimes come with the battery packs.When I test any battery pack I usually use my iPad to see how well it performs. It's rather informal, but is quite telling. Can this battery pack cut the mustard?iFLASH Performance:Start: 75% (4 LEDs)15 minutes 79% (4 LEDs)30 minutes 83%45 minutes 87% (3 LEDs)60 minutes 90%75 minutes 94% (2 LEDs)90 minutes 97%115 minutes 100%The the performance was really impressive for a 4400mAh battery pack. Mind you, I didn't sit on it watching it every second as it charged, but was quite surprised at how hard to work to try to get my iPad back up to snuff. My iPad was 75% charged, but that last 25% can pull a lot of power from a battery pack. If the 4400mAh iFlash can chug away powering up an iPad, no doubt it will keep your iPhone or iPod in business.This is a small, sleek unit and could easily be carried in a purse, knapsack, or briefcase. The top of the battery pack has the four blue LED indicators. Beneath that on the front side is the small LED flashlight, and one output port. I suspect that LED flashlight would be able to stay on for more than 200 hours continuously given the power of this battery (just a guess). It's small, but would be great in emergency situations. On the right-hand side panel is the micro 5-pin input port. The power switch is conveniently on the top face.WHAT'S IN THE BOX:~ Power Bank 4400mAh~ 70 cm (27.55") Micro USB 5-pin Cable~ Quick start guide~ Blue mesh travel pouch with an iFLASH logo on a red tagSPECS:~ Weight: 4.1 ounces~ Input: Dc5V/1A~ Output: Dc5V/1A~ Output: Charging speed for mobiles: 1000mAh/hours~ Input charging time: 5 - 6 hours~ Recycling time: > 500 times~ Six month limited warrantyPOWER INDICATORS:~ One LED light on: <25%~ Two LED lights on: 25% - 50%~ Three LED lights on: 50% - 75%~ Four LED lights on: 75% - 100%Sample provided for review.

    2014-04-02: In my tests of this unit, it has a low cutoff current, which means it will charge my tiny Zip Clip fully without shuuting off too early. The built-in light works well.     2013-07-12: If your recharging needs are minimal, the iFlash 4400mAh backup charger is definitely worth a look. I tested the charger with my Samsung Android cellphone (1800mAh battery) and my Kindle Fire HD 7" tablet (4400mAh battery), plus my wife's iPhone 4 (1420mAh battery), and it worked fine with each of them. With most cellphones, a fully charged iFlash 4400 should be able to provide at least two full recharges. For 7" tablets, about one full recharge is the limit. The iFlash 4400 will work with larger tablets (typically around 6000mAh battery), but it won't be able to provide a full charge.The iFlash 4400 is packaged with the charger, a USB cable with a micro-USB plug, and a carrying pouch. The micro-USB plug will fit a majority of mobile devices currently sold in the US, but for others, you'll need to provide your own cable and plug. You'll also need to provide an AC wall charger or vehicle charger to recharge the iFlash 4400. (The user guide shows the required input as DC5V/1A. I recharged it with two different AC adapters, one with 0.85A output, the other with 2.0A, and both worked okay.) The iFlash 4400 can also be recharged from a USB port on a computer, but at a slower rate.The iFlash 4400 is one of the smallest and lightest mobile chargers that I've seen. At 3.9"x1.8"x1" and weighing only four ounces, it's small enough to carry in a pocket, and the smooth curved edges won't poke a hole in it. The built-in LED flashlight is a handy feature, as is the automatic shutdown after the unit is disconnected from a mobile device.Summary: If your cellphone only needs to be recharged once or twice a day, the iFlash 4400 is an excellent choice based on capacity, size and weight, and price. It can also be used for recharging small tablets. It's a very handy little device to carry around for those times when your cellphone battery is dying, and an AC or vehicle charger is not available.A product sample was provided by the manufacturer for review purposes.

    2014-01-09: I've had one of these on my phone for over a year now, after having had a less-protective case on it and a small drop broke the screen. After fixing it (new screen) I purchased this Acase hybrid to protect it, as I just could not bring myself to put one of those gigantic "otter-brick" things on my phone, and I've been VERY impressed. I'm no butter-fingers, but I have dropped my phone a couple times since putting the Acase on there, and nary a scratch! It does a great job of protecting my phone, without making it huge like the other brands.I been so pleased with mine, that when I recently bought galaxy s3's for my twin daughters, I ordered 2 more of these cases, before the phones even arrived, and told them "I don't ever want so see your phone without this case on it."Last shot- At under $10 a pop, this is really a no-brainer.

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-04: This case is just beautiful! The picture does it NO justice. This purple is amazing. Looks metallic. I LOVE IT!     Rating: 5

    2013-06-02: I love this case so much that I bought it in Black on Black, originally had the Black and Grey one, but the two tone was really bothering me (personal issue).Pros:- This was even cheaper than the black on grey one I originally bought by $5-It's the same exact thing as the other one I bought, I was afraid that due to the difference in price it might have been an inferior model-I love the rubber insert and the statin plastic/rubber outer shell-It's one of the few cases in this price range that offers a 2 piece kit- and surprisingly enough it was one of the few slimmer cases that has exposed rubber corners, the others had plastic covering the corners, which to me is illogical since the sides can take an impact, its the corners that need the most protection.-I also love the fact that it grabs onto the very tiny lip on the front of the screen for a secure fit.-It also creates a nice lip on the front of the device, should it land face down, it should take great force to actually have the ground make contact with the screen (as long as it is a flat and even surface).- Having tested it with drops (accidentally), it has done its job more than well. 3 out of the 4 times it fell it landed on the corner, but the sound of the impact was so faint that it took a second for me to register what it was. The slapping sound of my phone's back hitting the ground was much louder. To me that meant that the rubber absorbed the impact and neutralized the force. Mind you those drops weren't more than 3-3.5 feet high (since I'm not a tall man myself at 5' 5")Cons:-It doubles its mass and volume, so if you're looking for something with a smaller footprint yet good shock protection look for TPU gel cases , they'll be half the thickness, and usually clear or frosted. I've gotten used to the weight and added size.-The satin texture of the plastic piece, somewhat bothers me, but then again my sense of touch is rather sensitive.With that said I bought this case since I liked the grey version, and I bought that one since my father has the Otterbox Defender for his iPhone 5 and I hated how much bulk that added to the device, it literally took a thin phone and made it 2-3x thicker and added 25% to its length. I wanted something that looked good and offered decent protection without the absurd amount of bulk. This met and exceeded my expectations.

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-18: I've had this case for 6 months now and it has been solid since day one! Perfect price and durability

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-28: I currently use it. over time it gets dirty, but hey, its a case. Works as described. No issues encountered so far (1 month) Perfect price. No complaints what so ever.

    2012-10-15: I've owned a couple of Superleggeras with my old S3 since last August or so. The Superleggera on the other hand - the buttons work like a charm - and still do on the S4 version.As a few have noted, the paint on the back can come off but only if you keep cleaning the case or are pretty rough with it. The white one I wouldn't bother with as that does discolor very quickly, but the black worked out fine.My advice if you want it is - buy two (still less than an Otterbox).     2013-07-02: Pros:-Such a deal. This case looks and feels like much more than the price tag would indicate. You definitely get more than you pay for.-Sturdy.     Rating: 5

    2012-01-30: I'm a product designer and I do not understand the logic of this dual case design. The best designed silicone case I've seen fits perfectly, provides a good non-slip grip, and allows the S2 to fit snugly into my Seidio cradle. What makes it the "best" is that rather than cut-outs for the volume-control and on/off buttons there are 3-dimensional nubs that make pushing those buttons significantly easier. Just the effortless ability to turn my S2 on and off makes the case worth more to me than the 8.95, free 2-day-delivered price, I paid as an Amazon Prime customer. I also found that wrap-around silicone case forms an edge bumper that provides cushioning on all sides. More importantly, its raised, wrap-around front edge creates a bumper that keeps the screen from coming in contact with a flat surface, even if it falls face down. When I snapped the form-fit plastic shell over the silicone case, all it did was make my S2 thicker, wider, heavier, and worst of all slippery. It also no longer fit into my cradle. The manufacturer's screen-protection description is also a bit misleading, as the case comes with only one screen protector sheet that, if I'm lucky enough to put it on bubble free, I'll have to replace every few months at a cost as high each time, as the case. I left it off.

    Rating: 4

    2013-07-07: A quality alternate shock resistant case for Galaxy S3. Outer hard shell, inner soft glove design fits exceptionally well. Main difference between Otterbox Commuter and this is that outer shell grabs like claws at the corners, with spaces in between, instead of being continuous, leaving those areas covered only by inner soft glove. Good case for the price!

    Rating: 4

    2013-06-06: Acase Galaxy S4 Superleggera PRO Dual Layer Protection Case for AT&T;, Sprint, T-Mobile and Verizon Samsung Galaxy S IV (Galaxy S4, Blue)I hope someone reads this as I've spent considerable time in preparing and revising this review! lol! If you have read this review and find it helpful, please so indicate! Okay, I know it's the 1,037th review posted but maybe you will benefit from it. lol!This is an 'initial impressions' review - 5 stars! Very nice, I got the blue, it's sort of a saturated dark blue, and more attractive than the image depicts. Though polycarbonate, it has a subdued 'glow' on the back as if it were metallic.*Important* - Pressing power button and volume controls happily require little effort, similar to bare phone pressure, despite presence of rubber protectors. I really like this about the Superleggera Pro!I must say that it's superior to Otterbox Commuter S4 with reference to pressing of these controls. Though the Otterbox Commuter button pressing functions are much better for the S4 than for its predecessor for the S3, Superleggera is still easier.However, there are no covers for the earplugs or charging port whereas the opposite is true with the Commuter, which helps keep out dust and debris.Otterbox Commuter probably gives slightly better protection, though it is somewhat 'harsh' (for lack of a better word) to hold as it's a harder plastic shell. The Superleggera Pro seems more comfortable and 'feels better' to hold, though the back and sides can be described on the 'slippery' side - it is more likely to slip out of one's hand than the Commuter. Would suggest you get a firm grip on it.Superleggera Pro phone side panels show some 'flex' to absorb impact whereas Otterbox is quite solid and hard on sides with little to no flex.As to price - Acase clearly costs less than the Otterbox.Unlike the Superleggera Pro, the Commuter does come with a screen protector - and it's excellent! If you apply it correctly you will never see any 'bubbles'. In fact, to the untrained eye, it is difficult to discern the protector at all! It's great!Overall, I would rate the Superleggera Pro higher than the Commuter due to ease of pressing power and volume controls. It's also easier on removal and installation if you want to change batteries or case to another, and I just like it's feel in the hand better...it's also seems a little less bulky than the Commuter.So the question is: "Which is 'better' for you"? That's a subjective call and you will likely be happy with either, or consider getting both! I have both and intend to keep them!This review will be updated as appropriate.

    2012-07-16: This is my first Galaxy S3 case I got. I wanted a case that was cheap enough where I wouldn't feel bad buying. The purpose is to find a well respected case brand that can offer great protection (from my 5 year old) after which I may change into a better case in the future as more manufacturers make cases and the selection is wider.First impression: Felt just like an Incase case with the smooth matte finish. Very sturdy and protects the phone well. This pretty much doubles the weight of the phone and so the phone feels sturdy and protected in the hands. I can definitely feel it in my pocket now. The buttons are cushy and easy to press. I wouldn't be worried if I dropped the phone.Things I notice of why I am only giving it 4 stars: As mentioned by another reviewer, it does collect pocket dust easily and is not easy to rub off with your hands. Maybe a cloth will help. The silicon on the two sides of the case where the buttons are easy to move around. This is the nature of soft silicon, but it would have been better if that area was a little stiffer instead of moving around. It would have been nice if the silicone was built with out a separate mold. I hate lines. Another thing is that the silicon at the top of the case does not look as clean and smooth as the bottom. I'm not sure why, maybe a molding issue, but it doesn't bother me all that much.I think it's a great deal for the price. Will have to see how the case holds up after a few weeks of use. Hopefully the paint won't peel like my Incase did (iPhone) awhile back. One note, another reviewer said they didn't get the "Acase" logo on the back of their case, but mine had it. No big deal for me.

    Rating: 4

    2013-10-29: OK, I almost forgot I owned this case, because I have so many cases for my phone, but this is a pretty reliable case. It's affordable, & it will take a good hit or two. I have yet to give it a true battle of abuse, because I rarely try to drop my phone. However, if it were to drop, I think it could handle the bumps and bruises necessary to survive. What makes it a good case by far is the infamous matte finish, which is a gift & a curse for a lot of people. Just something to think about when it comes to possibly leaving marks/scratches. If you're looking to make a good investment in a case & don't want to spend a lot of money I would definitely recommend this case.

    2013-01-19: My wife has an otterbox commuter for the same phone and her's is marginally better but not by much. This has nearly identical protection and style as the commuter case. One last thing, this case has very slight notching at the top and bottom for the speaker and push button.     2012-10-30: I bought this case for my wife's GSIII after she dropped it one day getting out of the car and I had to give her "the look." The look that says, "I love you, but if you're going to have a nicer phone that me, it had better stay looking immaculate!"Over the years, I've sampled a modicum of cases on various smartphones. One of my favorites was a Seidio Active Case for my EVO 4G. This case reminds me a lot of the Seidio, but with two main differences: the soft-touch coating hasn't shown any signs of wearing off after 3 months of use (my Seidio had shiny plastic spots showing within 2 weeks where the coating had rubbed off), and the Acase was less than half the cost.I bought this case after reading high recommendations from folks at both SlickDeals and XDA-Developers, and I couldn't be more pleased with how it's held up. The design is simple but elegant. I really like dual-layer cases like this with a shock-absorbing inner layer, but the trade-off is generally that they add bulk. They GSIII is already a large phone, but this case didn't feel like it made it over-sized or ungainly. It's about as thin of an addition as I could have hoped for while still providing the protection of a two-layer case.One of the best pieces of news is that even though the silicon covers the volume and power buttons, they are still very easy to push while the phone is in the case. One of my main gripes with my Seidio cases has been having to struggle to press the buttons through the case, but that's been a non-issue with the Acase. Reviews stating as such are one of the reasons I opted to purchase this case to begin with, but I was still pleasantly surprised when I tried it in person and realized just how little the case impeded button presses.

So beware if you're buying this for a female. Great for me because it used to be a hassle getting the Galaxy SII out of my pocket while I was sitting in my car.     2012-07-09: The Samsung Galaxy S3, or Ice Cream Sandwich, is due out this week and I received a Superleggera PRO in the mail this morning and put it through its paces. I'm very rigorous when it comes to testing and this case lived up to everything it claimed. AT&T;, T-Mobile, and Sprint are providing the smartphone, but if you want protection for your phone at a very reasonable price I'd highly recommend Acase. The Superleggera PRO is a dual layer protective case with a rubberized silicone case and a polycarbonate snap-on case.Peanut butter. You can't get much greasier and grimy than a peanut butter smear, which went directly onto the polycarbonate case. Yes, it did settle in briefly, but when I took a damp cloth it readily wiped off without leaving a residue. Needless to say, my fingerprints did not show up on either case. Acase's "anti-fingerprint" claim surprisingly passed my test as did the "anti-scratch" one. Writing utensils, fingernails, and drops didn't scratch it, let alone dent it.Newstribe calls the Galaxy S3 the "most powerful smartphone in the world," but it will be useless without adequate protection. The silicone rim is slightly higher than the phone so when place on a table it is less likely to scratch your screen. The dimensions of the phone are136.6 x 70.6 x 8.6 mm and the lip of the silicone case raises it up sufficiently. I like the double layer "armor" and the sleek black look. If you prefer another color this case comes inwhite,purple/black,blue/black, andred/black. Simply click on the color and you'll be taken to the order/description page. This case is an excellent, sleek product that lives up to its description. Highly recommended.Sample case courtesy of Acase.

    Rating: 5

    2012-07-14: I've used several different smartphone cases over the years, and this one is definitely one of the sturdiest and most impact resistant that I've come across. It has a very innovative design - it's essentially two cases, snuggly wrapped around each other. The "inner" case is a rubberized silicone sleeve that looks like a swimming bodysuit. It's very easy to put on your Galaxy S3 smartphone. The outer case is hard polycarbonate case that's a bit trickier to put, but otherwise very well built and it gives you the sense of sturdiness and protection. This dual layer approach to smartphone casing is meant to give an increased impact-resistance, and a much more protective case than most single-layer cases. If you are clumsy with your smartphone, then you should definitely check out this particular case.The case is fingerprint-proof and scratch-resistant, and it has all the appropriate openings for the headphones, camera, and the charging dock. The volume control is covered with the rubbery case, and it somewhat diminishes the sensitivity of those buttons. The texture of the case feels really good in your hand and it provides you with a solid and comfortable grip.Overall, this is a very nice looking and well-designed product that will give your Galaxy S3 smartphone additional protection, and provide you with a peace of mind while using it in all sorts of situations.

    Rating: 5

    2012-07-25: The new S3 is so light and wafer thin that there's not much to hold on to. I've already dropped it a few times trying to pick it up quickly but not touch the screen until I was ready to answer the call. This case fills out around the phone and gives you a very tactile sense when grasping it. You really feel like you can grip it securely as you use it and put it down, either face up or down, and feel like it won't break. The only down side is that now it doesn't fit the belt clip pouch that I bought for it. that pouch, bought on Amazon, is made for the phone without a case on it. It also will not fit in the charging dock, also purchased her on Amazon, because the case makes it too thick to fit in the slot. However, I would give up both of those things for this case. The case is far more critical for me than either of those two things. I'll just have to find a bigger belt pouch, and I've purchased several wall chargers on eBay for three bucks each, so I just plug the phone in and I don't use a dock. The dock was nice because I work at home and it provided a nice stand for the phone so that it was upright, rather than laying down on my desk. But, not a big deal. I would buy this case again. I have a white S3 and I can tell that this case will get dirty and scuffed because it's also white, but I'd recommend it.

    2012-07-25: This case is fantastic. It easily allows for all buttons to be pressed while still covering them.     Rating: 5

    2011-10-31: 4 1/2 starsPros - Perfect fit, good quality, good price, good protection with soft silicone + hard outer shell, doesn't add too much bulk to the phoneCons - covers 1 of the mics on top, magnet for lint/fuzz when carried in pocket, screen protector is NOT for att version but it still fits if you want itPersonally, I like the added thickness because the phone is extremely thin and hard to manage sometimes. The only major problem is that it covers the mic on top. I had some problems with people saying they were echoing one speaker phone and worse voice quality from my end. To fix the problem, I took the case off and marked it about where the mic should be. I used a small drill and made a small hole with my hand. Unless you stare at it and see the rough edges, the new hole looks like it was always there.tl;drPerfect case with some work but screen protector has a cutout for the home button on international versions.

    2012-12-25: Bought for spouses S3 along with two others to try. First to arrive and nicely packaged. Was easy to get on phone and the dual rubber-hardback cover seems secure. I like that the corners especially have both the rubber under cover and then the hard cover over the top. Have not tested a drop onto an overly hard surface, and hopefully won't need to but would think that it would provide reasonable protection from a waist-high drop. Overall a nice case and buttons work perfectly through the case.A FEW THINGS TO NOTE1. A few scuffs show up from regular use, but nothing of great concern2. Provides a nice lip for screen protection3. Even though it fits over a screen cover, the flexible rubber moves around enough with regular use to eventually push againt the edges of the cover and peel it up4. A little difficult to get off on a regular basis but shouldn't be a problem if you don't need to constantly access your phone's innardsOverall a well made cover that promises adequate protection during daily use. Wouldn't throw the phone against the wall, but keeps mind at ease knowing a drop from a table probably won't kill the phone.UPDATE 18Feb2013Phone dropped out of wife's bag onto tarmac in parking lot, probably a 2'-3' drop ... landed on edge and then face down. I could barely detect where case had hit the ground, but I think it was the bottom left corner as that's the only area I found a very tiny scuff. Phone seems unperturbed. Case has a decent lip on it which also seems to have protected the screen. (I did put screen-cover on a while back which also probably helped) So overall, the case did it's job. One thing though, the white sure does start looking "off-white" after many jeans pocket visits.

    Rating: 4

    2013-01-16: this case looks like the seido case, but it is cheaper. I think it is a great case because it has the rubber and the hard case. The buttons and holes line up great. The only thing I think will be a problem is the bottom and top rubber part. They do not have a hard case to cover it so that rubber might tear after awhile if you pull it out of your pocket a lot. Overall, the case keeps the phone slim still, yet provides really good protection for the price you pay.

    2013-08-24: this case is very nice adds extra protection to your phone and the color with the red and black looks really good buy this case!!!

    Rating: 5

    2012-08-04: The Samsung SIII has a plastic cover that is somewhat slippery to hold. I was looking for a case that had a better tactile experience as well as one that would protect such a high-priced phone. This case fits the bill perfectly. I've had phone cases in the past that were slightly misaligned with buttons and sensors, but the designers of this case (and the phone itself) did a good job in avoiding that problem. The openings in the silicone are nicely formed, some are even beveled, and give complete access to the ports and sensors they're protecting. The soft silicone inner case also has raised sections over the buttons on either side of the face that fit in slots on the hard shell and follow the line of the outer shell. The silicone is very soft and allows a good feel of the mechanical buttons they're covering, which respond with minimal pressure. The edge of the silicone reaches over and sits a little proud of the phone's face all around and the outer plastic shell curls over the silicone to make a nice pressure-fit grip on the phone, also making sure that the plane of the phone's face is inset below the case edges - a preferred protection. When calling, the case is practically imperceptible.If you install a screen-protector sheet on the phone's face for full protection (not included with this case - I always recommend Skinomi products!), the silicone is soft enough to not disturb the edge of the sheet, but may lift it if you're not careful when putting the cover back on after installing the sheet.The outer hard case is thin and light, and has a matte finish that feels like most modern plastics, cool to the touch but not slick. I have the white case and it can smudge a little bit after awhile. (Finger skin oils don't go away, do they?) But it's easily cleaned. The full case adds a little width and a little thickness to the naked phone, as real protection should, but the weight added by the case is just enough to make the phone feel more substantial in the hand, but never heavy. The phone's incredibly light already, and so is the case.With this case, the phone still fits easily in my shirt breast pocket or pants pocket. I don't like belt packs personally, but as others have mentioned here, I'm sure you'll have to check specific interior sizes on packs to see if the phone + protective case will fit inside.Overall, I'm very happy with this case. Because I got the white SIII - I've always misplaced black phones - and the white case, I can't help thinking the combination reminds me of a Star Wars Storm Trooper. Yeah, I know, but it's fun. Right?

    Rating: 5

    2012-09-26: I bought three cases at the same time. Gave this one to my son. Its two-piece design makes it more bulky than a TPU case, but it also provides an additional layer of protection. From that standpoint, it's great. But it also makes it more difficult to pull in and out of a pocket. Otherwise, it's a good fit, and all the holes line-up. You could do worse.

    Rating: 4

    2012-09-04: The Acase Samsung Galaxy S3 black case is lightweight and thin yet provides about as much protection as one much heavier. I really like the two layer approach with a soft rubber first layer that gives excellent access to all ports and buttons and wraps around the screen to offer protection while the phone is screen down. The second layer is is a hard smooth plastic that offers good impact resistance along with an easily cleanable surface.I feel the need to again mention how accessible the ports and buttons are. I have never had an issue adjusting volume or plugging in USB/headphones.I recommend this case to anyone who wants a good layer of protection on the Galaxy S3

    Rating: 4

    2012-12-12: I usually don't write case reviews because of how fast I go through them, but this one really surprised me. I wasn't sure what to expect, but it seemed popular and was only like $15 or something like that. That being said, I love this case. I have a small crack on the bottom corner of my device, and this covers it, which is huge plus for me. But overall, the case is just a joy to use. It doesn't add too much bulk, probably less than half of what you'd get with an Otterbox. The matte finish feels amazing , but it does seem a bit slippery. I'm a fan of matte finishes, so that's not something that bothers me. The lip on the front is nice. it's not obtrusive, and definitely protects the face of the phone. This case just feels great. Get it.

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-30: I've been a fan of the Acase Superleggera Pro line for a few years now. First used one with an Iphone, now a Samsung S3. It does add some thickness to the phone but does not make it bulky by any means Best features (not in any particular order): easy to install and remove; does not interfere with any buttons and ports on the phone (volume and power buttons are covered but the case does not in any way hinder them...they remain responsive); provides a nice "grip" on the sides (it's a smooth surface but not in any way slippery); and provides great protection from falls (I've dropped my S3 from as much as 4' and the case provided good protection from the fall; no damage whatsoever to the phone or the case). Only one notable negative: Not very screen protector friendly (just like many phone cases out there). Tends to lift the edges of screen protectors after just a few days. Overall, a great buy.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-06: The case is exactly as described and I love it. I was worried when I selected it because of the description but this was unfounded. The inner rubber cover fits like a glove and the outer hard shell snapped right into place. It perfectly matched the color of my phone to the original color. If you have this phone, this is the perfect companion.

    Rating: 5

    2013-05-04: I didn't want to give this product a one star rating but was given no alternative course of action by amazon.After just 4 days of use, the white finish started to wear off on the back near the logo.I thought that this is a good product and I just happened to receive a defective one, however I've since done a more thorough search of the reviews and found a few others who mention the same problem.Normally, I would contact the seller and give them the opportunity to make it right. But because this was fulfilled by amazon I am not being allowed to.I have to return the product and wait on my refund, while I would have much rather the seller just send me an immediate replacement. Because of the inconvenience I will not purchase another Acase Superleggera Pro Hybrid White, nor can I recommend it to any of the many people I know who own a Galaxy S3.

    Rating: 1

    2014-01-16: UPDATE 5/8/2014: This case is still going strong. I noticed some reviewers are reporting that the case is slippery. I can only assume they received a different case than I did. This case is simply not slippery, I mean it can sit on the dash of a car and not slide around. I have devised a test to demonstrate this level of grip. I will post a picture of it sitting on a piece of paper at an angle to see how steep of an angle is required before it starts to slip. I imagine it is more than 45 degrees. For the price, I can't recommend this case enough.I am reviewing this case as I bought it. It paid $3.99 for the black version.This case is somewhere between a silicone case and an Otterbox, while being cheaper than both of them in some cases. This case has a relatively grippy (not sticky) inner silicone shell. On top of that, you get a rubberized plastic piece that covers the corners, sides and back of the phone.Around the screen, the case has a raised edge. This way your screen can't make contact with a surface if you set your phone face down. The back is soft touch covered plastic and feels very high quality. It is just the right balance of grip and slip. I need it to slip into my pocket, and I don't want lint from my pocket sticking to it. With silicone cases, it is hard to get the phone in my pocket because they're almost sticky. They also attract lint which is annoying. This case won't slip out of your hand, but it isn't as sticky as silicone. It also covers the camera nicely, so it doesn't touch the table when you set it down screen up.With the soft touch plastic covering the corners and a layer of silicone to absorb shocks, I can confirm that this case can easily handle drops from chest height (4-6) feet. I wouldn't see how high it can go, but it definitely protects your device from accidental drops. The silicone case also slightly covers the edge of the phone screen bezel, so no dirt gets in between the phone and the case. It also helps protect the screen because even gorilla glass breaks easily if you hit it on the edge. With this case, it is covered. The buttons and everything work just fine. My normal power plug and headphones work great too.For anyone who doesn't want the bulk of an Otterbox, but still wants some good drop protection, this is a great case to consider. It also costs a fraction of the Otterboxes for the Galaxy 3. For $3.99, It's a case everyone should have. I had this in my cart for a long time, and it used to cost $15. I thought I'd wait and see if the price would go down, and now I got it for $3.99. For those familiar with Otterbox, this case is of equal build quality. The protection is reversed though. The hard plastic shell goes around a shock absorbing silicone layer.I highly recommend this to all my friends. Two of them bought a case as soon as they heard the price. I missed that soft touch material featured on droids. Now, I can have it again for under $4! If you're even considering it, just buy it. Amazon's return policy is ace, so you can always return it if you don't like it. Seeing it in person, it's hard to imagine that it cost $4. It is a great case for an unbelievable price.

    Rating: 5

    2012-07-19: I purchased this case for my S3 because of the look and the price was pretty hard to beat, I was expecting to get a case that would work until I found a better one. The case fits perfectly on the phone and it feels like its very protected, only problem i have found is the black rubber is a lint trap but thats an easy fix. For the price i have not seen a better case out there and I would highly reccomend this case!

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-13: It took me a lot of research on the internet, websites, real mobile phone stores and even more research and reading reviews on many cases. Some helped but all pointed to the same brands (Otterbox for ie.) for a good protection with energy absorption. Got to even think on a D30 case that crossed my mind, but it's too ugly.I was looking for a case with good/excellent shock absorption since the screen on the S4 is around $300 ! (You can get a Nexus 4 for that). It looked like this was a good one, good big pictures and nice description on the item.The case is made out of 3 materials divided in 2 parts:- Internal soft rubber just like a Otterbox, very little difference on thickness as this is thinner- Outer solid plastic shell with really soft rubberized feeling like on fancy electronicsThey fit PERFECTLY between themselves and working with the phone:It's 1/4 of the Otterbox price and I thought the soft rubber internal would be trash on the sizes and fittings for the buttons. What an excellent surprise to see that the side buttons simply fit PERFECTLY. Otterbox must learn with Acase!The thinner rubber can make the phone+case VERY thin. It's totally worth to wear it on the phone. With the otterbox it's just too big, too sturdy. When showing the phone had to take it off but with Acase it's perfectly slim and fits nicely inside the pocket.The outside rubberized finishing is like the fancy electronics and as stated leaves no fingerprints marks for a lot of time, but if you eat something like fries then it stains just a little bit - a wet damper can easily clean it.Got so happy about it that bought a second one as a gift!

    2012-08-10: To be honest, I wasn't really expecting much from this case but was I ever so surprised!!I have had the S3 for a couple weeks and had a horrible experience with the Otterbox Commuter. That case was very difficult to install and then once it was on the phone, using any of the buttons was nearly impossible. I tried several different commuter cases from different vendors and all had the same design flaws.So then I went to the VZW store here in Austin and purchased a Incipio Dual Case. This case was easy to install but the buttons felt "mushy" and the case barely reached around the edges. The lack of coverage on the front caused my expensive screen protector to lift on the edges. Furthermore; when I pulled the phone from my pocket, there was a high chance the case would slip off a corner.I thought I was stuck with the $29 Incipio when I stumbled upon this case. Again, just being honest but the name "ACase" screams cheap Asian junk. However; this was certainly not the case (no pun intended).This case wraps around the phone perfectly. The rubber is not so stiff that you can't press the buttons and not mushy like the Incipio. It doesn't have a tactile feeling but you can still tell the button was successfully pressed.Installation and removal is a breeze.The finish seems to be ok. I can't talk about the longevity of the case or the finish but it seems to be pretty good. My only negative point would be the seam that goes the entire way around the plastic. Its not very noticeable and doesn't really bother me much.Also keep in mind, I would consider this case to be more on the gold side of yellow.The case seems much smoother than the Incipio but not nearly a slick as the plastic feeling Otterbox. All connectors and holes in the case are perfectly aligned and allow ample access.Incipio goes back to VZW and with the money I saved I will purchase another ACase in a different color.***08/23 Update***I rarely take the time to review much less update a review however; I do feel compelled for this product.After a few weeks of regular usage, the case is still in pristine condition. Its holding up perfectly and looks just like Day 1.I did have a drop to wood floor from about 4 feet and absolutely no damage to the case or device.My screen protector has a few scratches but the case has none.I noticed that pocket lint does attract to the black rubber but its very easily removed with a swipe around the bezel.

    Rating: 4

    2012-09-06: I'm a huge gadget junkie, and when I bought the Samsung Galaxy S3, I had to find a nice looking white case to match it. I must say I'm quite pleased by this case. It's a two layer case. First part is a rubber case that fits around the phone. Then, the white hard plastic part slides over the rubber case to hold it on. Much better protection than those 3 dollar plastic cases that spli apart when you drop your phone. I've had my case for over 3 weeks now, and it still looks brand new. I was a little skeptical about a white case, thinking it would stain and get dirty, but it hasn't shown the first side of any sort of stains or scratches. I get compliments all the time on it. Go ahead and get this case if you have the white samsung galaxy s3. Trust me, looks great. Make sure you get a nice screen protector too.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 5

    2012-10-15: I just got the S3 and spent hours researching cases for my amazing phone. Obviously the first choice was to look at Otter Box, but most of the complaints I read about it was that the buttons were stiff. One of my criteria was to keep the phone a sleek as possible, but still give it drop protection and I also wanted it to be able to slide in and out of my pocket easily.I opted not to go with a screen protector on this phone because I did not want to distort the beautiful display in any way or risk leaving a sticky residue on the phone if I wanted to remove it. This phone has the 2nd generation Gorilla Glass installed and is designed to be durable from daily use. Like most guys we keep the phone in our pocket so it is pretty safe from getting scratched up unless you keep your keys in the same pocket therefore no screen protector is needed. Now for the ladies like my wife that put the phone in their purse, you may consider a screen protector of some sort.The case comes in two pieces. The phone fits into a rubber piece and then you slip on the plastic cover. The plastic cover has a little bit of grip to it, but if you want grip for it to not slide on your dash you can flip the phone over on it's face since the rubber insert is slight raise on the edge of the phone. All of the buttons are easy to press and the the charging port and headphone jack are easy to get to.What also drew me to the phone was the blue color. In the right like it tends to look purple like some people say, but it is blue and looks great!

    2012-11-12: After doing an extensive googling, I could identify this item. It not only is sleek, but is also robust enough to absorb the initial shock when dropped containing my brand new Samsung Galaxy S3. I know how brittle the phone is, so had to be extra caring while choosing the case. Since the prices of the phone has recently been slashed down - didnt want to lose the edge by buying an expensive one. The black cover snugs around the white phone and the contrast looks adorable. The first rubber protection layer not only gives a cushion effect on hard landing but also provides the necessary grip to the slippery phone surface. The second hard case shields the phone from crushing force if accidentally applied. The pores and buttons are well placed and volume bar or lock screen button cover makes it more convenient to use. Will highly recommend it to any new buyer, Apart from the fact that it collects a bit of dust, which is quite a negligible factor in this discussion, I can simply point to nothing else as its negative point.

    2012-07-19: I have been Otterbox Commuter case user for past 3 years with 2 other phones. One of the reasons I avoided Otterbox was the problem with hard to press power/volume buttons. This case definitely does not have that problem and buttons are fairly easy to press, but avoid accidental presses. This case does not come with a screen protector, but I bought one separately. I liked it that the USB and audio ports does not have rubber/silicone flaps (I found it to be more annoying than protection in my older otterbox cases).

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-29: When it comes to drop protection, I've no doubt this case is top notch. I felt like this thing could hit my tile floor in the kitchen without any issue (and that floor has claimed many, many dishes/glasses/bakeware over the years).The trouble is, the matte, slick surface of the back of the case. It's very slippery in the hand. I felt much more of a tendency to drop the phone with this case on it then without a case, defeating the purpose of the drop protection in a lot of ways. The bulkiness and weight of the case also made holding the phone a little more cumbersome and awkward.If they had used a glossy material on the back, it might stick to your fingers a little better like regular TPU does. Even the glossy back of the naked S3 sticks to your hand pretty well.I also didn't like how the silicone material collected dust. I know this is typical behavior of silicone, but it will always be an annoyance. I prefer the properties of straight TPU. No dust collection, slick in and out of pockets, yet sticks to the hand. The amount of protection of generic TPU cases is nowhere near what you get with this Acase case, that I'll admit.I appreciated the protection it offered, but I returned it. Too slick, bulky and awkward. I am using a Kay's Case Slim soft case I got from Amazon. Again, inferior drop protection, but stays in my hand a LOT better, making me much less likely to drop the phone in the first place.

    Rating: 2

    Rating: 5

    2013-03-21: This case is a great low-cost alternative to some expensive options; however, after a few months (even weeks?) use, I noticed dirt accumulating on the sides where I would hold it. Maybe I needed to wash my hands more, but after a few times of cleaning the case, the dirt began to stain it. I suppose it's expected, though, for such a cheaper option. All in all, however, the case fits and protects very well.

    2013-11-06: I'm not gentle with my iPhones. I've dropped them on concrete, asphalt, wood floors, and tile. In spite of that, I managed to keep my iPhone 4 alive for 2 1/2 years with an Incipio case. I finally had to part ways with it though when I crushed the screen.When I buy a phone case, I want it to protect the phone. If it cannot survive the occasional unexpected drop, it's just a decoration. These phones are not cheap to replace, so I wanted something that will give me a shot of making it through another 2+ years with this one.Pros:- It fits the phone very well. It's snug, so I have no fear of it coming loose, sliding off, or popping out.- It's a good material blend. The base is a firmer plastic while the bumper has a slightly softer rubber feel to it. Both are solid. Together they give a little extra grip to the hand.- If you like the color that you've chosen for your phone, the clear cover showcases it nicely. And it doesn't obstruct any ports, lenses, or buttons while it does it.- It has a bumper that is raised above the edges of the screen.Cons:- While the bumper is a few millimeters high, it's not as high as the Incipio case that I had for my 4. I wish it were just a little bit higher. It will still help protect the screen from occasional drops (and has so far), but a few millimeters can make all the difference if it ends up landing face down.- The case scratches quickly and it shows since the case is clear. That doesn't bother me personally at all, but I know some people will consider that a negative.Ive dropped the phone a few times already and everything is safe and sound. I'm very satisfied with the case so far and would definitely recommend it if you want something simple but effective!

All around the edges, around the buttons, large bubbles that are very noticeable and take away from the design of the phone.I have tried LIVVITT products three times now and I have not been satisfied at all. Is it so difficult to get a clear case without any of these issues? I guess it is. Returning my product for the third time. I would suggest looking for another brand.

It hasn't stayed on my phone long enough to find out) if dropped and you won't feel bad if your baby destroys it. And if they're just a tad older, they'll love the colors (it'll just be obvious you hate your kids.)

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2014-04-21: Car chargers do not have a lot to distinguish themselves from one another. They either work or they don't. And I have purchase a couple that have not worked. This one works well. It charges quickly and it has a low profile that does not stick out from the port and get in the way of anything else.The cord extends well so it should be usable by either person in the front seat.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-10: I was nervous about getting a lightning car charger for my iPhone 5S because I have read so many reviews online from individuals who say that various chargers, despite claiming to be "Apple Certified," really don't work. When I had the chance to try this particular charger, I was optimistic. Ultimately, I am very pleased. After about a month of daily use, I have not had any problems with this charger at all. It connects every time. I've never had any warnings or error messages.There's actually a lot to like about this charger. The coiled cord makes it easy for storage, which is a big plus. And I also appreciate the light on the base, which shows that the charger is working (so I'm not persistently checking my phone to verify that it's still charging). All in all, it's fast, and the pivot at the top of the cord makes it easy to plug in. The only con, and it's not worth subtracting any stars, is that I wish there was a USB port for additional charging. Still, this one worked great for me, and it is easily recommended.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-24: The Mfi Rapid Coiled Car Charger is a nice, functional unit. It will charge both iPhones and Ipads. The cord is a nice length - not too long and not too short - about 12 inches long when coiled.The unit features a blue LED light to reflect that the unit is receiving power (not that the iPhone or iPad is charging). A nice aspect of the product is the offset power cable which swivels to feed the cable lengthwise to the power plug or perpendicular to it.The only thing that would make the charger nicer is if it had an auxiliary USB outlet to allow a second cable to be run off the jack (Apple plug or otherwise). Otherwise, it is a nice, simple charger that works.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 1

    2014-05-14: This car charger does the job. The form factor is compact, so if you're concerned about your charger sticking out of the port, that's an argument in its favor. The cable is nice and stretchy. Recommended. Read on for a brief rant about these devices in general.A brief rant: my concern with this charger (and so many others) is that it sucks your car battery's juice even when you're not using it. I bought a charger with an off switch which eliminates this problem in theory, but in practice you always forget to turn it off. Pulling the charger out of the port seems like a good solution, but you quickly forget to do it. I am surprised that no one has come up with a car charger smart enough to turn itself off when your car is not running. Until someone comes up with one, I will use this charger.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-04: When Apple came out with the new lightning connection, I was forced to change how I charged my phone in the car by using a USB car charger with ports and my own cable. This Francois et Mimi branded car charger eliminates the need to use a separate cable although, of course, it's not as versatile as a USB charger since it will charge only newer Apple devices.The lightning pin itself fits smoothly, and it's Apple-certified, so you won't be getting one of those el cheap kinds that sometimes have faulty connections (one I bought only worked when inserted one way, not both as it is supposed to be.) The coiled middle keeps the cable neat. I have no problem lifting the phone from the console in my car where it charges to my ear, although the tension is there. The coating on the cable seems a little stiff and therefore cheap; I would like a softer, more supple cord, but I'm not sure that would work with the coiled design.This is a good option if you want an Apple-approved, dedicated charger for your iPhone. It charges the phone quickly, and it keeps my console a little neater.-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann

    2014-04-06: This product works fine charging an iPad in a car. I used it on a long road trip and the charger was very useful. The price is right too.The packaging indicates that the cord can rotate 90 degrees. When I first tried that, the rotation was not easy nor smooth. It was as if the cord was not built for rotation. As a result, the casing rubbed the insulation of the cord and left some scratch marks.The coiled cord is nice for taking less space, but it has too much tension. In a car it is not easy to reach the rear seats from the cigarette lighter socket because the coiled cord keeps pulling back the iPad.Although the product claims to be Apple certified and even have the word "Mfi" in its name (MFi stands for Made for iPhone/iPod/iPad), there is no indication of the true manufacturer on the packaging, so I was not able to verify if this is true using Apple's MFi licensed manufacturer list. Neither Francois et Mini nor the distributor Luzy's Storage Place Inc. is listed on Apple's web site as a licensed manufacturer. Another point of suspicion is that Apple usually does not allow "MFi" to be used in a certified product name because MFi is an Apple trademark. The license disclaimer on the packaging contains incorrect spacing like "Made foriPad" with a space missing between "for" and "iPad". Since Apple certification includes reviewing the packaging especially the legalese by Apple, I have my doubt of the authenticity of the "Apple Certified" claim.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-27: This car charger has quite a few things going for it:+ Short coil design keeps it from taking too much room in the center console+ Charges reasonably quick (about 1% per minute on an iPhone 5)+ The cable can swivel to come out from the side or the back of the plug+ Apple certified so it shouldn't stop working with the next iOS updateI do have a few minor concerns though:- The short length makes it uncomfortable to impossible to have the phone up to your ear while charging- The LED power light is a relatively plain looking rectangleOverall, it works well if you're using a handsfree device while charging or if you like shorter cables. The lighter plug fits snugly. The Lightning plug has a good firm snap in the iPhone and iPad.As others have pointed out, the cable is short and fairly tightly wound.
