    2014-03-25: I have tried numerous chargers for my iOS devices, and while most were just fine with the iPhone 4s, the LIghtning connector on my iPhone 5s and iPad are far more finicky. All of the car chargers I have tried before have always started giving me a "this device may not be supported" error after a short period of use. Some have simply stopped working at all. Of those, I have had chargers that claimed to be "MFi," but clearly weren't. This charger is the real deal. It never gives me the not supported error, it charges at the proper rate, and it fits snugly, but easily into the Lightning port. One of the telltale signs that this is a true MFi adapter is the speed with which my iPhone responds. When I plug my phone into the adapter that came with it, I hear the charging tone immediately. When I use the other chargers or cables that I have, it takes a few seconds before I hear that tone. With this charger, I get the tone immediately as well.If you're looking at chargers for your new iPhone, this is the one, period!

I guess the longer cords have their drawbacks also, but I hate to unplug when I get a call, but I'd have to in my minivan.

    Rating: 4

    2014-03-24: After I ordered this product, I noticed that it doesn't charge iphone 4, only iphone 5, so we weren't able to test it on my daughter's phone. But it charged my son's ipod touch just fine, and we liked the curly cord so we could get it out of the way while it was charging.I haven't had much luck with chargers in general - they stop working after a couple of months, or the delicate plug end breaks. At least when they're not expensive you can replace them, although I really dislike living in a "disposable" society where things are cheap and aren't expected to last.I'll upgrade this review after we've used the charger for a few months, but my first impression is that it's well made and works properly.

    2014-04-16: The fact that this charger is Apple certified is enough to make this worth the price. The charger works perfectly and a blue light is lit when plugged in the car. It charges fast and the lightning charger means that you don't need an adapter for your iPhone, iPad etc. Love it!

    2014-05-07: **Charger stopped working June 26th. That's less than 2 months after purchase. I tried different plugs and alternative devices to charge and it just didn't work. I would not recommend**I am very happy to have this charger, as mine went kaput. The pivoting plug is helpful since my outlet is in the center console. A complete charge of my phone takes the same amount of time as my USB/ AC Apple charger at home. I love that it is Apple certified.The cord is supposedly 5 ft long, but seems much less since it is a tight coil. I would have a tough time talking on the phone while charging, the cord would continuously be yanking back toward the outlet.However, it is good at its job.

    Rating: 1

    2014-05-08: Search for "Francois et Mimi" on amazon. What do you find? Coffee press, bluetooth speaker, cups, pitchers, iphone charger, cupcake stand--all sorts of random stuff. Go to their site and you'll see that they're an overseas sourcing and distribution company that specializes in getting your name on overseas products. And that's what they do: they put the "Fancois et Mimi" name on products that are made by other companies overseas. Since "Francois et Mimi" just puts their name on other manufacturer's parts I don't trust that they're a big enough company to control the quality.The first product I tried from them were bluetooth speakers. Half great reviews and half poor reviews. My pair had a bad ringing in the ear. I tried emailing their support on the webpage and got no reply (emailed 2 months ago). The build quality is ok, but very generic. Amazon had given them to me to review otherwise I would have tried to exchange with amazon.Now this charger itself works fine so far. Very generic! But it works. I actually like the curled cord and the fact that the cord can turn on the car end so that it exits the charger at 90 degrees rather than straight out.Even though it works, I have hesitation that it will last long. You see that 8 one star review out of 73 that state that the product didn't work or worked a couple weeks. Every single one star review but one says this! (one says they're getting not certified messages out of the box).Currently 29 of 35 5 star ratings are vine voice. Currently 25 of 28 4 star review are vine voice. This means amazon provided the item for review asking that it is review in a month. This doesn't necessarily mean that that they're bad reviews, but it does mean that most review are new in the ownership.It works fine so far. The design is so generic that it looks like a knockoff. The cord feels cheap and I'm worried about it lasting. I think I prefer a car charger with usb ports for versatility and the fact that car chargers tend to last longer than the cord.And even though it works fine, I emailed the support email address from the "Francois et Mimi" website saying I'm having problems with it to even see if I get a reply. So far no reply. The only option for support on the official website is an email address. (There is a contact form on the website that I didn't try). They say they will reply within a day.I don't want to knock it too far because mine does work fine, but I don't trust the company nor do I see any support from the company.

    Rating: 3

    2014-03-27: The charger does what that you would imagine it does, it charges up your Apple products that use the 8-pin connector (the small one). What makes this one different is that it allows the cord to flip up in the back so that when you plug it into your power (in the car). That is very useful for me because when the cord is sticking out of the back, it blocks the use of the cup holder or just anything that might be behind it.The cord is coiled and looks shorter than it is (It’s listed as 5 feet but that would eventually weaken the spring effect of the coil). When it’s charging you do get a blue flashing LED indicator and it also indicates that it prevents overcharging — and it could be my imagination but charging was lightning fast for my iPad and iPhone.BTW “MFI” is a special certification given by Apple to a select group of manufactures that insures it is meeting the Apple standards.In Summary, I like the innovative cord redirection and the small “footprint” and love how it works so If you need car power - this guy is up to the job!

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-16: This charger does faster than the usual charger. I'm not a big fan of the coiled wire, it gets a bit tangled and it could be a bit longer. I have some earbuds that have a flat wire and I love it because it doesn't get tangled, it would have been a good choice for this item.

    2014-05-15: What can you say about a charger? It works to charge my iPhone 5s and I like the coiled cable because it is easy to store in the car.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-10: This product is advertised as 1.5 meters which is nearly 5 feet. This is probably true prior to the wire being coiled, however, for actual use, the length differs. Measuring the charger cord from the tip of the plug to the tip of the input for your device, it is 22" out of the package. Stretching it out, with tension as it would be in use, it measures just under 4 feet.If your goal is just to have a charger in the car for charging, this cord works great. If you anticipate needing to talk on your phone while it is charging, it is tight, but it works.The cord can be positioned to stick straight out from the plug, or it can be at a 90 degree angle. If you are tight on space near the charging outlet, this is a great feature.The blue light illuminates to let you know when it is charging.If it were a bit longer, I would rate this 5 stars.

    Rating: 4

    2014-05-14: Many of us now have multiple devices that need to be charged on the go, which makes the singular focus of this charger puzzling. When many accessory outlet chargers offer two USB inputs, or a permanent cable along with a USB slot, this one has just the one. If you only have one device to charge, this might be perfect for you - it is otherwise very nice.On to the details: the coiled cable is a bit stiff, which is good so as to reduce cable clutter. The Lightning connector is housed in a sturdy looking vinyl that is larger than the standard Apple connector. If you have the AmazonBasics Lightning cable, it's close to that size, or slightly larger than the Monoprice Lightning cable. It charges at the higher rate that the iPhone 5 and newer demand, so charge time is similar, if not identical, to charging at home with the Apple cable and charger.The accessory-port end houses the cable connector, where it is attached at a nice two-position end point. Push it one way and it sticks straight out. Push it the other way and it makes an L, handy when space is at a premium. The connector end has a bright blue power light to let you know it's actually working.

    Rating: 3

    2014-03-22: Works great in my car charging my iPhone and iPad. Coiled cord help to elevated the tangles. Cheap price and apple certified

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-26: This seems to work well enough. It doesn't seem like the most sturdy thing in the world, though, so time will tell how well it holds up. But so far so good.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-09: I'm on the go all the time and recently (since IOS6) my iPhone 5 will not make it through the day without a "pick me up" charge.I've tried several car chargers with my iPhone only to get the dreaded "unauthorized charger detected" message.Finally, the MFI charger fulfills my need for fast and reliable charging.Quick positives:1. 2.4A charger means it's pushing a lot of juice to the phone quickly. It could charge an iPad if needed (as it requires more). Some car chargers only push 1A, which means longer charging time.2. Simple design...the short square plug recesses nicely and out of the wayA couple of drawbacks:1. 2.4A charger also means some cigarette adapters don't have that much juice available. The cigarette adapter by my gear shifter won't power this, but the one in the console will.2. The cord is kind of short due to the fact that I have to plug it into the console. I wish the coils weren't quite as tight as they are as the cord has a tendancy to snap back.All in all, I'm glad it charges quickly and is certified so my phone won't reject it.*UPDATE 6/23/14*After less than 60 days of use, the charger has quit charging. The indicator shows it has power, yet the phone is not charging. I have tried it with several phones to no avail.Downgrading my rating to 2 stars.

    Rating: 2

    2014-05-07: After years of owning an iPhone 4 I made the switch last year to an iPhone 5. Those familiar with the changes should understand my pain when I realized that all the devices I owned were rendered useless because of the different connector pin.I ended up getting a speaker I could use to listen to music and charge the phone a the same time but I was missing a car charged. I was able to work around this by using a USB connector I had in my car, so I could plug my iPhone5 USB cable in it. This car charger takes care of that problem , no USB connection is required, you connect to the car and directly to your iPhone. Granted, there are Power Cases you can use while on the run but truth is, those are bulky, tend to get very hot and eventually run out of battery as well. I have always preferred a car charger over a Power Case.I have been using it for a while now, in the times I remembered to take note of the time, it would seem in my case, it charges the battery at a 1% rate per minute, not as fast as when using an electricity outlet but not bad at all.Another great thing about this cable is that it is small, so space is not an issue, and the cable is not as long as others. Very practical and comfortable to use, I can definitely recommend you get one of this if the alternative of a Power Case does not appeal to you. Add to that the fact that the product is Apple certified and you have an excellent alternative!

    2014-04-02: Just got a new iPhone 5s and needed a charger for my car. I had the chance to try out this one and so far its great. The plug part is small and doesn't obstruct anything in the car. Its coiled up but I think its a little on the short side still. My plug port is in the center arm rest console and I need just a little more to stretch if far enough to get it in a spot where I can put it near me.There's a blue led that shows its plugged in which is great.     Rating: 5

    2014-04-12: There's nothing fancy about this charger, which is probably just fine. It does what you need: charges your more recent Apple devices (iPhones, iPads and iPods) that use the "lightning" 8-pin connector.It can do it quickly (5 volts at 2.4 amps), which is useful for devices with bigger batteries like iPads.The 5-foot coiled cable stays nice and tight and out of the way, but if you stretched it out to the full five feet it would likely soon cease being nice and tight.The cord at the base (the piece that plugs into your car's lighter socket) can be repositioned: either straight out the back, or off to the side up to 90 degrees. This can be quite convenient for keeping the cord out of the way of other things and minimize distractions while driving.Finally a blue LED light lets you know when it's charging.It's a simple compact design that works. For most car charging iDevice needs this one if a great option.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-01: This is a nice charger that has the correct lightening connector for use with the iPad Mini, Air, and iPhone 5 and above.     2011-03-08: I agree with the other reviews about it not being completely sealed around the optical control. Dust gets in and water could get in too.     Rating: 4

    2011-04-26: Let me first say that the Otterbox for my Droid Incredible is probably the most protective case I've ever seen! It pretty much turns it into a tank. I haven't tried to abuse it, but I'm sure it would stand up to quite a beating!That being said, I am returning it to Amazon. The reason is purely functional. Sadly, the things that make this case so good at protecting the phone also make it difficult to live with. Here are my problems...First, the case makes the phone huge! I have big hands, but this thing is pretty chunky, even for me!Second, one of the three "layers" (and BTW, that's a bit misleading... it's only two layers plus a built-in screen protector), is the screen protector that is built into the inner hard case. The problem with this is two-fold: First, it isn't a screen protector in the traditional sense that sticks to the screen. It is just a layer between your finger and the screen (or anything else that would come in contact with the screen). Unfortunately, this leaves my nice capacitive touch screen feeling like a cheaper resistive touch screen, requiring much firmer presses on the screen to make it work. It also is very difficult to get anything at the extreme edges of the screen to work because there is a little extra space there where the hard case pulls it away from the screen. The second problem with the screen protector is that, as others have mentioned, dust gets in between the protector and the screen, probably through the whole left open for the optical joystick. This becomes obnoxious as time goes by and dust builds up. It should be mentioned that I did leave my attached screen protector on the screen since I had read ahead about the dust issue and didn't want my screen scratched up by caught dust and dirt. This may have contributed to the lack of sensitivity to some degree, but I didn't want my screen damaged. I suppose one could get around these issues by removing the screen protector portion of the case, (it doesn't look like it would be difficult), but you shouldn't have to. That removes a "layer" of protection and voids any warranty that it might have.My other gripe is with the outer soft layer. It feels good in hand and makes it easy to grip, but it grabs dust and dirt very quickly and makes it look bad. I don't want my case looking dirty all the time, no matter how good at protecting my phone it may be.In summary, I would probably recommend this phone to a contractor or mechanic who is working in a dirty and rough environment all the time or for the person who uses there phone outdoors a lot. But, for the average person using it around the house and work, I wouldn't recommend it at all.I will probably be switching back to the Seidio Innocase II. I had that case/holster combo before, and while it has it's own set of problems, it leaves my phone looking nice and still quite functional.

    Rating: 3

    2012-11-30: Just what I needed and the price was very reasonable . I look forward to doing more business with this company nin near future.

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-07: This is a good screen protector. Reason for the 4 stars is it seems to get scratched easier than other brands I've used on different devices. As far as putting on... If you've applied protectors before, you know that taking your time making sure no dust is on the screen and lining it up will make it easy. The fit on the Galaxy S4 is great by going right to the edges of the screen. I had to lift it up 3 times and move it slightly to have that perfect fit. When lifting it back up just go slow so no dust blows in. The included dust strips are a god send too since they can be used on the protector itself it a speck of dust does get on it.

    Rating: 4

    2013-08-30: Yes, I agree the tab to peel off the adhesive should be located at the bottom home button like the instructions mention, but alas it is not. However, there is a workaround. If you slightly peel off from the top corner and work your way through the side and around to the bottom, the top plastic cover will stick back to the adhesive as you work it around. Then once you have the bottom peeled 1/3 of the way you can then start to apply it from the bottom then work your way up. I've tried this twice and was able to align it perfectly every time.As for the product itself, for an anti-fingerprint, it really isn't so "anti" so to speak. You will still see smudges and left over wipes, just not as much, and it is easier to wipe off. I purely got this for the anti fingerprint and don't mind so much on losing the clarity.Edit:: After having this for several weeks I must say I started to miss the clarity and sharpness of the display. Its a nice screen protector for what it is, but I had to remove it after it started to wear on me.

I guess the instructions are universal for both the matte and glossy screen protectors. My fault so I scrapped that first one. The second one fit like a glove. I once again followed the included instructions and this resulted in a clean application of the screen protector. I have one more to spare, but I think this current one will last a long time. I've been attempting to punish it with keys and a pen that I have in my pocket, and it's still nice and new. Recommended 100%!

    2013-05-14: I've been using screen protectors on my phones since I got my first smart phone (Nexus S), and this is the best I've ever used.In terms of the protector itself, it's exactly what you'd expect. It fits the screen (and sensors on the top-portion of the screen) perfectly, and it feels great to touch (it's not sticky or anything).The genius of this product is in the applicator.The protector comes sandwiched between two protector-protectors. This makes applying the protector cleaner, in the sense that it's basically impossible for stray hairs/dust/whatever to get onto your screen before you can apply the product. I've wasted many protectors in the past by applying them and then realizing a piece of dust got caught underneath, because once you lift it back up, it's impossible to clean and reapply.Bottom line is if you're looking for a screen protector for your S4, this is what you want. It's a great product, and it comes with 3 protectors, making this an unbeatable value.

    2013-06-20: I had always used invisible shield before, which seemed to be very highly rated by everyone. It was also anywhere between $20 and $40 for one piece of film, depending on the phone. When applying invisible shield, you have to wet the screen and be very careful with fingerprints. I would rarely get one onto a phone in precisely the right place.I saw Tech Armor on Amazon, and it was getting great reviews, and three films were less than $10. So, I decided to give it a try. I followed the directions, and it was remarkably easy to apply. After cleaning the screen, I went over it with tape to get up any dust. Then I peeled part of the backing and carefully positioned one edge of the film to the edge of the screen of my phone. I rolled the film on as I peeled the rest of the backing away. There was no moisture to apply. I smoothed it once with the card they included in the kit, and then removed the top plastic layer that was still protecting the Tech Armor film. The screen protector film was in perfect position. There was not a single bubble of piece of dust. It is the closest thing to a truly invisible screen protector application that I have ever had. And, if anything ever happens to this screen protector, I have two more waiting for me at no additional charge.

    2014-01-06: I purchased tech armor for many devices ive owned. Cant say anything negative. Good packaging, enough protectors, and the tools you need to get them on. Good HD quality too!!

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-02: I had never heard of Tech Armor and had considered buying another Spigen (which I had for my S3). However, I saw mixed reviews on the Spigen for the S4 and I also felt that the Spigen could have been a bit sharper (the one for my S3) than it was, as it sort of scuffed and seemed to also not be as clear as I'd like - taking away from the screen quality. After some research, I decided to try this option and I'm very pleased. On my white GS4 this screen protector is virtually invisible to your eye. It's so thin and clear that everyone that has touched my phone has said that I need to put a screen protector on it and was shocked when I told them there is one. That goes to show not only how clear/thin it is, but also the feel is very close to the same as just touching the screen. They don't pretend to have any extra technology to prevent smudges, fingerprints, etc. and if I was to compare it against the Spigen - which does - I still prefer this one. The ones that try to prevent those things with surface coating often times look oily after a little use anyway and it makes using a microfiber cloth a pain because it just smears the oil instead of removing it. This protector is just clear and while you will see fingerprints and things after some use, it's also easier to wipe off. I'm happy with this choice over the Spigens.

DO THEY ASSUME THAT BECAUSE YOU HAVE A CURRENT SMART PHONE, YOU ARE AN EXPERT?!QUICK SHIPPING, GOOD SCREEN, YET IT WOULD BE AN IMPROVEMENT IF THEY CUT OUT THE AREA AROUND TOP SENSORS SO THAT TRAPPED DUST DOESN'T INTERFERE. MY ATT&T; TECH GUY EXPLAINED THAT THE DUST AT EDGE UNDER EDGE OF PLASTIC MADE PHONE MODE SCREEN GO DARK WHEN I ANSWERED, AS IT WAS FOOLED INTO THINKING PHONE WAS BEING HELD UP TO MY EAR (WHEN HELD TO YOUR EAR, SCREENS ARE DESIGNED TO GO BLANK)..SO I TRIMMED THE PLASTIC SHIELD ON NEXT RE-DO SO THAT CAMERA, AND OTHER SENSORS ARE CLEAR.

    2013-07-05: I've gone through multiple screen protectors from different makes and I finally decided to try TechArmor at the suggestion of a friend. I wish I had discovered this brand sooner. Usually I'm skeptical about protectors that come in 3-packs for such a low price, but my assumptions were wrong. This is one of the best and certainly the clearest screen protector I've used. As a happy new owner of an s4 I was drawn into by the screen and really haven't put it down since the day I got it, even with this screen protector on the quality of the display is still there and almost like the screen protector isn't on it.Easy to install, fingerprints come off fairly easy, you get 3 of them in case you mess up or it gets scratched, and lifetime warranty all for <$10. One heck of a bargain if you ask me.My only gripe is that their "pull tabs" to take the plastic off the screen protector itself is at the top of the device. I don't know if it's my installation technique but I think I would've preferred the tabs to be near the "home button" hole because I don't like peeling the backing completely off. I like to line it up nice and peel as I put down the adhesive side of the screen protector. Because the tab was at the top the alignment is a little off, but still very happy with the product.Durability aside because it's only been on for 2hrs, I give this product a 9/10. Very strong first impression and hopefully I'm a TechArmor customer for life.

    2013-08-16: I have bought screen protectors for the last 4 smart phones that I have owned. I'm guessing about 7-9 different brands. Having said all that, I was concerned when buying these tech armors regardless of good reviews. Of course I bought 2 packs of (3) just so I had enough to make mistakes with. Also, I was buying for two phones (Galaxy S4's....wife's and mine). Still did the bathroom thing because I live in California and it doesn't rain for many months so every house pretty much has dust in the air. Also watched the video of which tech armor sent me an email reminder about (thank you!). My S4 is black and the first one went on just like their video (el-perfection). The wife's phone is white which makes it way harder to line up the screen protector because there is no black border contrast. Though I did misalign hers on my first try, I was still able to pull it up (only holding the edges) and place it back down 2 more times before it was perfect. Whew!!! Not only are these the best I ever bought, but if you screw up a little, you can actually still make it work without tossing one. Hers looks as good as mine. Not even the slightest of a bubble or dust (thank you steamy bathroom). So that's it, I bought 6 and only used 2. We will be able to replace them a couple of times over the next couple of years until the next big thing comes out. No question that these are great and it's also nice when a company goes the extra step (sending video reminder) to make things perfect. An easy 5 star review for me!

    2014-02-26: ❗ - I wanted to start things off by giving tips to applying a screen protector properly: - ❗1) If you want to put one of these on, the best time is IMMEDIATELY after buying a new phone. Don't let the salesman/woman take off the plastic covering and skip to STEP 52) If you have already used your phone and now decided that you need a screen protector (as most people are in this boat) gather these supplies:-Lens Cleaner (or anything else with a high alcohol content) [simply chemistry, alcohol evaporates quickly]-Lint free cloth (such as silk) [included in this purchase]-Credit Card3) Pour a small amount of your lens cleaner onto your lint free cloth and liberally clean all surfaces of the phone4) Repeat a few times to make sure all debris is removed from the screen5) Lift the bottom of the film from the backside (side that will be touching your phone) DO NOT TAKE OFF THE WHOLE FILM YET6) Place the bottom part of the cover on your phone and align it on the edges of your phone7) Use a credit card to smooth out any and all bubbles that may be present8) SLOWLY go back and fourth from using your credit card and removing a SMALL amount of the thin film from the back of the screen protector9) !THIS IS THE STEP MOST PEOPLE MISS!After your installation process is complete, try your best to wait about 30 minutes to an hour to really let to adhesive set. This will prevent any debris from gathering under your screen.If you followed all of those steps, you shouldn't have any problems getting a bubble-free screen protector!✅ - What really sets this brand apart from the others is that they don't have that sort of sticky feeling that most screen protectors are plagued with. You know what I'm talking about if you've used your friends phone and you have a hard time sliding your finger across the screen. This screen protector does not have that problem at all!✅ - Another great feature about this product is that it prevents fingerprints. Most phones come with the coveted olio-phobic coatings that are great for about a day.✅ - Also, one thing I have noticed with a lot of screen protectors is that after a few weeks, the edges start to peel off. The screen protector my mom has on her phone (something she bought at verizon) gets fingerprints like crazy and puts a nasty hazy glare on her screen and after about 3 weeks, about a third of the protector started to peel away. That alone is proof to me that the quality of a screen protector DOES matter.I can't recmmend it highly enough!✅ - I give this product my highest recommendation especially when following my suggested steps to putting this on

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-09: I'm no stranger to a cell phone or screen protectors. I'm the kind of person who prefers one to bare glass, no matter the quality/strength of glass. If you have the same ideals as I do, then you can't go wrong with the Tech Armor screen protectors.I debated on buying this product vs the alternativeTech Armor Samsung Galaxy S4 SIV Premium Anti-Glare & Anti-Fingerprint (Matte) Screen Protectors with Lifetime Replacement Warranty [3-Pack] - Retail Packaging. I chose the HD Clear Screen because of experiences with my wife's similar screen protector w/ antiglare/fingerprint matte version on her iPhone 5. Although the Anti-Glare/Anti-Fingerprint screen protectors do what they advertise, those screen protectors aren't as clear. I guess you can say the appearance of those is a "shimmer" effect. The pixels under the screen protector are slightly "magnified". That's what makes it "not clear". But with that, you gain anti fingerprint/anti glare. So you must decide do you want screen clarity w/ smudges & glare or do you want less clarity/display alterations to gain the ability to reduce glare and prevent fingerprints.Personally, I prefer the clear screen protector because the screen on the Samsung Galaxy S4 is very nice. These pretty much are invisible and you wouldn't know they were there except seeing the protector's outline on your phone.Regardless, I'm very satisfied with Tech Armor's product. For the price of $6.95, you get a pack of 3 screen protectors plus a card, one of the nicest dust cloths I've used, as well as 1 sticky tape to remove final pieces of dust before application. I can't tell you how many times I've wasted screen protectors because of dust causing bubbles. Because of the tape & cloth, I was able to install it perfectly on the first attempt.If there were room for improvement, I would probably tell Tech Armor to include 2 more dust removal tapes for customers. I mean if you're providing the tape and the cloth, that means you're wanting customers to stick the screen protector on the first try. But the sticky tape isn't reusable... So in the event that they need reuse a screen protector, all they have is the cloth. The cost of the dust removal tapes should be irrelevant. I guess if they had to, they could raise the price of this product another 50 cents to compensate for the addition of the 2 dust removal tapes.

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-26: Yes, this is a simple product but until you've tried to apply a few you have no idea how they can be poorly made and packaged. These Tech Armor screen protectors fit my phone exactly; there were cutouts in exactly the right places for the home button (bottom) and the speaker and four sensors (top). The application instructions were quite through. There were even several adhesive strips included which are useful in picking up stray dust before applying the protector. The entire package was first rate and professional. Getting the few bubbles out was a snap. FWIW: I close the bathroom door, turn on the hot water and let that steam up the mirror a little. That gets virtually all of the floating dust (and dog and cat hair!) out of the air making application much less traumatic. Also, if your phone is in a case, remove it as this screen protector fits exactly to the edge of the screen which is covered by the case.

A true privacy screen (at least the ones I'm use to at work) blocks all views from side angles except the head on view. So from the left and right it should look completely black, in this case it just looks dim. Which means you may need to turn up your brightness to see better which means lower batter life.Although I still like the matte finish and it went on very easily.     Rating: 1

    2013-06-05: I have bought an array of screen protectors for the Galaxy S3, Droid Charge, and now the Galaxy S4. These Tech Armor protectors include detailed instructions (and Tech Armor will provide an email with instructions if requested). Overall, I highly recommend these protectors over their Verizon counterparts. Done right, they work great. They also work with my Maxboost case. I can see my fingerprints on the protector; however, it doesn't bother me yet while using the phone. They wipe away fairly easily.The key to these (or any) screen protectors is the install. It is critical to wash hands before installing and having a clean low-fiber wipe cloth. The 3 protectors came with 1 piece of tape, 1 microfiber cloth, and 1 card to remove air bubbles. After removing all screen dust, I was able to correctly place sticky side 1 of the protectors. I also used the card to remove all air bubbles. Peeling off side 2 was slightly difficult as the protector wanted to shift, so it might help to peel it slowly. If the protector shifts, it could become misaligned picking up dust or bubbles.The provided scotch-like tape is single use; however, you can install the protectors if careful without using any tape. After 2 protectors, the card was slightly bent, so I hope it will last until the third protector is on. I feel confident these protectors should last at least 6 months (and hopefully longer).

    Rating: 5

    2013-05-09: hello,i have used tech armor stuff before i purchased this one for my new galaxy 4 phone. everything is fine, except for what i believe is the location of the pull tabs. the pull off tabs are on the bottom. they want you to pull off the bottom tab to start the process. but, when you get to the top, the holes for the camera,etc are not lined up correctly. they are off just a bit, i screwed up the first one, but on the second one, i switched the tabs to allow me to pull from the top down. everything was easier when the multiple holes for the top of the phone line up first, then the sides, and finally the bottom, where the big home screen button is. that big home button was easier to line up at the end of the process than at the beginning. second try was excellent. it was a good thing there are three clear screens for messing up the first time. there are a ton of bubbles, but the enclosed stiff card does a great job of eliminating those pesky bubbles. any dust underneath must start the process over. yrmv

    2013-12-02: For me at least, this screen protector was fairly difficult to install. There weren't really any dust particles, it was just air bubbles. On the upper right side of my device, there was a very large bubble that ran along the side of my phone. I tried really hard, but I just couldn't get this bubble out. After 5 re-applications, the bubble was no longer there. Other than my installation problems, this screen protector is great. It feels very smooth and doesn't get any fingerprints on it. Because this is a matte screen protector, it also has excellent glare reduction. This screen protector doesn't lower my phone's touch sensitivity or anything like that, as you would hope. Overall, this is a very nice screen protector. It was pretty difficult to install, but once you have it installed it feels/looks very good and appears to be a very long-lasting protector. And for the price, it's hard to go wrong.

    2013-06-19: First the Bad news:Just like most similar products Tech Armor's screen protectors present more of a challenge to install on your smartphone than the instructions might lead you to believe. Lining all the edges up properly and eliminating gaps, bubbles, dust, trapped particles etc can take more manual skill than the average first time user would probably anticipate.Now the Good news:Once you've finally got it installed correctly, this is a "must have" accessory that's well worth the investment. So far at least, the "Gorilla glass 3" screen on my Galaxy S4 seems to be fairly scratch resistant - even without adding any added protection. But I consider this product "cheap insurance" that allows me to stash my keys in the same pocket as my phone without the slightest concern over scratches.There are 3 protectors per pack. If you install the first one right you'll probably never even need the other two; they're pretty durable.The key is to just make sure you set it up right the first time - which might be easier said than done.

    Rating: 4

    2013-12-31: This is without question the best screen protector I have used. It is a lot better than the ridiculous one I mistakenly purchased at the ATT sore for $20.00. The Tech Armour and does not stick and works great. Tech Armour includes a tape like device that allows you to pull dust and fuzz from the protector as you are applying it. All others I have tried are pretty much ruined if you get something stuck to them. Besides all that, it is crystal clear and allows he great colors of my G4 to shine through. Highly recommended!

    Rating: 3

    2013-05-15: I used to always purchase the Zagg Invisible shield for all my previous phones. I'm not going to say it's a poor product, but my main beef with invisible shield is that it's a grease magnet as well as being quite pricey. Normally around 20-30 bucks depending on where you purchase it. Once the grease begins to stick the phones responsiveness becomes poor. Most people don't notice but the invisible shield also begins to yellow after some time and darken the clarity of the screen. This product retains the screens original feeling as well as responsiveness. And for the price it can't be beat. Even when you have to replace your ZAGG product you still have to pay $5 for the replacement. With this you get 3 for $5, really can't be beat for the price. The other product i want to try is the tempered glass screen protectors, but for the price of this is still the cheapest option with good protection.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-25: I've installed a dozen or so protectors over the years, and this product seems to be of good quality. That being said however, I do NOT recommend purchase of this or any other protector for the S4.The vast majority of phones and tablets today, S4 included, have "gorilla glass" and are exceedingly tough from a scratching perspective. The main vulnerability is when dropped the screens have a tendency to crack and craze on impact. Simple screen "protectors" such as this one do NOT protect from such hazards.Lastly I must live in a very dusty environment, I have YET to succeed at putting on a protector on with no apparent bubbles caused by tiny bits of dust. I ruined two of the three and still didn't get there. Yes, I did watch the videos and did my best.Save your money, invest in a phone protection plan instead. That's the real way to insure against loss or damage. I pay $5 or so per month through Verizon (the MPP plan).Oh, and get a case as well, there are lots of good cheap ones out there.My 2c

    2013-11-20: Great for the price! For the price, you can't go wrong. It comes in a pack of three, with 4 stickers to remove dust/lint and also a microfiber cloth to wipe down your screen. It's a clear screen protector and doesn't take away from your HD screen. Installing it is very simple but i do highly recommend you read the tutorials or watch their videos on doing so because these screen protector are different from the rest. The tend to attract to lint/dust more than other once you remove the protective cover covering the screen protector. If you have problems with alot of lint, i highly recommend you use a lint remover and placing the screen protector on it to insure you remove all the lint, and give it another try. The only flaw that comes with these screen protectors, are the fact that they do tend to leave a smug when your finger rubs across from it, but it's nothing a simple wipe can't remove. All in all, they are great!

    2013-08-31: Make sure you are very patient or have experience installing screen protectors before you buy these.Great company. Excellent protection. I've used these before. Can't beat the price.But...On the S4, these are cut TOO tight to the edges of the phone. When you install, you will get anything from a little bubbling on the edges (if you are really accurate with the installation) or a bubble line down the side of the phone (if you are a tiny bit off). I still have a small bubble in the upper-left corner (to the edge) that I just couldn't get rid of. It's small enough and off the screen that I stopped noticing it.My suggestion to Tech Armor - cut these 1-2 mm smaller. Yes, you might be able to detect a space between the edge of the phone and the screen protector but it will be completely flat. The cut of my S3 Tech Armor screen protector was more like this.The screen protector is a smudge magnet so you have to wipe it often and yes, it does reduce clarity a little because of this but, seriously, all protectors do this. (referring to HD version)I recommend this product with only the caveat I mentioned above. I would go to 5 stars if they cut them just a tiny bit smaller.

    2013-06-22: Got it. Came with instructions, links to a video, tape to remove dust, cloth to remove crud, cardboard to remove bubbles. Instructions are great - peel part way, align to bottom of phone, then slowly peel and stick. Of course if it isn't perfectly, and I mean PERFECTLY aligned to the bottom of the phone it won't align perfectly along the long edges. On my Galaxy S4 this means that there is a small area near the top where one side will not stick all the way down. It isn't an air bubble in the normal sense, but has the same effect. And peeling it off and replacing it will likely not be worth the effort.Instruction to manufacturers: I'd pay an additional $10 for the product if you would get a person to apply it for me and it was actually applied evenly and bubble free. I will probably waste the other two sheets in the kit then just give up. Although this material is really nice, the application still sucks.

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-08: The first unit that was sent to me I couldn't really tell if it was the correct item or not. The box was for the standard screen protector minus the privacy, there was a sticker slapped on saying privacy, and then the item inside I wasn't really sure what to expect as far as privacy. Needless to say I sent it back. Upon receiving my second one it was again in the wrong box. Seriously, they can't make the right box? I am led to think there are a bunch of clear protectors lying around without a box, or being sold on ebay for a fraction of the price? Anyways I got the second cover on without a problem. Their claims of being high quality "bubble free" do not lie. I previously had an otterbox provided screen protector that was nothing but bubbles, this one went on well, straight, and has zero bubbles. I really amazed.Now onto the protection. This is not a flimsy piece of plastic. I cant imagine any scratches on the screen with this thing on. I'd say it is 2 or 3 times thicker than the standard covers. As far as the protection aspect of this cover goes it gets an A+.On to the main event- the 4 way privacy. It seems to be directly related to the contrast. In a pitch black room, it doesn't work that great, or even at all. This would be bedroom, movie theater, or cave (?). On the other hand when you are outside on a sunny day, no one will be peeping on your screen. When I say no one, I mean no one. This includes yourself. Even on full brightness it either needs to be right up to your face (closer than 6") or you need to find shade. Otherwise you will be squinting to see what's on your screen or using the S Voice application to talk to your phone like a crazy person. Indoors it works well enough, though someone over your shoulder will be able to see it. Rather than privacy screen it should be advertised as darkening screen. All it really seems to do is make your screen a lot darker. It also makes the screen appear pix-elated. If screen brightness and HD are important to you then you probably won't find a privacy screen that appeals to you. Now the way around the brightness issue indoors is just cranking up your brightness to full blast. the down side for this is you sacrifice battery life. Using the auto adjusting brightness doesn't work very well because the sensor isn't covered by the film, so it assumes that the brightness is fine for whatever condition you are in.Bottom line I don't think the privacy aspect of the screen really does anything. Rather than guarding your information, what it really does is just make your HD crystal clear screen look like it's being displayed on an old tube tv. If there standard screen protector is equally thick then these are definitely fantastic screen protectors.

    Rating: 1

    2013-12-19: There is nothing better out there. At least not for this price. My last one lasted 3 months. They do not scratch when you clean the screen it's protecting.It saved my screen twice. Both times it fell between car seat and console and the seat adjustment rail dragged on it as I pulled it out and it had long deep scratch in it. I thought for sure when I pulled it off it would be damaged. It was not. I will never buy another brand. Also the center console in my Expedition was open and the locking mechanism peg landed directly on the screen when it slammed close on the protector, it didn't even leave a mark. BTW, The one that lasted 3 months I applied with a solution of soap and water that came with a competitors screen protector, which felt too rubbery. Do not apply any screen protector ever again without using this method. I can't guarantee anything or even say it won't cause any damage to your phone, but it is huge. You can adjust it to fit perfectly and you won't get any air bubbles. spray the solution onto the sticky side of the protector.and apply, squeegee excess water out and you are done. Apply with power off and let sit for a bit to set the protector in place. This is what I do. I do not know how the manufacturer feels about it.

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-22: What can I say....fit fine, work great. Tip- if you don't already know this....install in a bathroom after a shower is taken as this is the most dust-free environment within most dwellings.

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-12: I may be too conscious about perfection, but i had hard time installing this protector with as little dust-bubbles as possible. Good thing it's 3-pack, so if you mess one up, (i messed it up by trying to remove the dust with my shirt) you have a second chance!!

    2013-07-09: the product works as intended. i don't believe i've had it long enough to truly weigh in on this product, but works very well for the time being.

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-27: I've got Tech Armor matte screen protectors on every one of my devices now, including my new S4 as well as my iPod Touch 5 and iPhone 4 (yes, I have two phones :P ). I love the way they make the phone look and feel. Other protectors, and bare glass with no protector, often feel almost "sticky" as you're swiping around, and this decreases ease of use as well as accuracy. The Tech Armor protectors make the phone much easier to swipe on, lending the screen an almost silky feel.The matte finish also makes the phone much easier to see in sunny conditions, and it only barely interferes with the view of the screen (there's a bit of moire, but not much at all, especially on the S4's super hi-res screen). The phone looks somehow even more "high tech" than it already does on its own. The protector is slightly stiff unlike many other brands (especially Zagg), which is actually a very good thing. It probably means more protection, but it also makes it very easy to apply on your device. If you don't get it 100% right the first time, you can pull it back off and reposition it easily as long as you haven't fully applied it. Until you're 100% sure you've got it right where you want it, always leave the last inch or two of the protective backing still applied and curled under. This makes it so you don't get fingerprints on the adhesive. If you do find that you've fully applied it and it's not quite right, don't worry. They include little tape strips that help you peel it back off to try again. Just be sure to wash your hands, since the protective backing won't be there this time.One thing I point out in my other Tech Armor reviews is that these screen protectors are advertised as "Anti-Fingerprint" but not "Absolutely, Completely Impervious to Fingerprints". They'll hide the smudges that natural skin oil will tend to leave, at least in small quantities. If you go and gorge yourself at KFC and plunk around on your phone afterwards, you're going to leave fingerprints. If you haven't washed your hands in a few hours, or touched your face or something, you're going to leave fingerprints. That's just how the world works. However, unlike normal glass or other screen protectors, the matte surface seems to make it very easy to clean. I just take my phone out of its case and scrub it around on my shirt for a few seconds, and it looks brand new again.Another thing I like is the shipping speed. I decided on a Thursday evening that I was finally going to upgrade to the S4, so I ordered these around 7 or 8 PM. They went out on Friday, and I had them in my hands via USPS on Saturday. Maybe I'm lucky, or maybe it's because I live in the Atlanta area, but all 3 of my Tech Armor orders have arrived in almost the exact same timeframe. Gotta love it.The only suggestion I'd like to make to the Tech Armor folks is to make it easier to figure out how to obtain warranty replacements. The product is advertised with a lifetime warranty, but the wording on the Tech Armor website ([...] makes it seem like only "new, unopened" products can be truly returned. Per the website, "Replacements and exchanges are not supported; customers can return their original order for a refund and create a new order for the replacement". That's.... not exactly what I have in mind when I hear Lifetime Replacement Warranty which does, in fact, explicitly state "Replacement".Oh, one other suggestion for the Tech Armor specifically for the Galaxy S4 screen protectors - The "pull tab" to remove the backing is at the top of the screen, but I think it'd be much easier to align properly if the pull tab was at the bottom by the home button. It's MUCH easier to align on the screen if you can start at the home button end, like the iOS device protectors. I got it done, but it wasn't as quick and painless as I'm used to. There's a lot of repositioning which means more chance for dust and grit to get sandwiched in.Anyways, all that aside, the screen protectors themselves are 99.9% perfect and I highly recommend them (if you couldn't tell already).

    Rating: 5

    2014-07-08: Once placed on the screen, the finish gives the phone a fuzzy, grainy, pixelated look. It makes the otherwise ultra high resolution screen seem artificially of a lower resolution lower. The protector also seem to dim the screen a little bit.I like the feel of material, and it does seem to resist fingerprints. I am still not sure about the anti-glare properties (instead of reflections, everything just gets washed out), different, but not better.This is the first time I tried an matte finish protector. I am going to look for a different one now, have had luck with Anker products before.Update:Contacted Tech armor, they told me they would sent a replacement unit. 2 weeks later, I received nothing....

    Rating: 1

I thoroughly cleaned the screen as per the instructions but one corner really is resisting its natural role of sticking to the job. Still it is a 3 pack for $6.95 so it still is a good value and if the corner refuses to stay down, I have two spares.

    2014-07-04: I have used this protector on my Samsung Galaxy S4 for over a year and could not be happier. The package includes three screen protectors, a cleaning cloth, a cardboard squeeqee, and dust removal tape. I found it easy to install, has a natural feel, and has held up well (will not discolor). The only negative I have experienced is once I left my phone in hot direct sun light and the screen protector lifted off the surface of the screen. I flattened it out and it was a good as new.TIPS:- Follow the installation instructions on the manufacturer's website: www.techarmor.com/info/help- I recommend not using the squeeqee (leaves marks). I use the fat part of my thumb to push out the larger air bubbles and the rest disappear after a few days.- Use scotch tape to remove dust and lint from the sticky side of the protector. It works like a charm.

    $B005G606O8

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2012-01-30: OK, I confess, it's been a long time since my 16th birthday, and the tiny keyboard and buttons on my iPhone are a pain! So I was glad to check this out to see if it made taking pictures easier for me.I downloaded the app, then attached it right over my silicone case. As soon as I attached it, the app opened. By pushing the black button, I was able to take pictures, and by pressing the red one, I could shoot movies. The grid was available if I wanted it, or disappeared if I didn't. Same went for the flash and the auto timer. All of the options were there.When I was done, I went through the gallery and either sent the photos to be saved on my iPhone (and cloud), or deleted them. You can also post directly to Facebook.I appreciated the fact that everything was simple, and that it was easy to use. While I don't see me running around with this on my phone all of the time, I can see me using it at family gatherings where I want to be able to take multiple photos rather quickly.Whether you should get this depends upon whether you intend to take a lot of photos with your phone, and how comfortable you are shooting photos just using the iPhone. For me, it is a nice addition, and I appreciate the fact that the app does everything it needs to do, including transferring the pictures to your camera roll.I didn't give it five stars because I think it is a bit pricy, but then most of the stuff for the iPad etc. seems to cost more than I think it should. A nice product, works well, but probably an unneeded luxury for most.Edited:I have recently purchased theSunpak PlatinumPlus FlexPod Gripper Plus for Digital Cameras With Ballhead and Quick-Release Plate - Blue/Black (620-PLUSBUB). Because of the tripod setting on this, I have been able to use my iPhone in many more rooms for facetime and video. While the Belkin by itself wasn't spectacular, when combined with the tripod I am very happy.

    Rating: 4

    2012-02-14: For anyone who has struggled with holding their iPhone in just the right position while pressing buttons on the touchscreen and ending up with blurry photos, this is a good choice. The quality of your photos will increase if you can hold the phone at a better angle and operate the controls most easily. This is especially noticeable with video, since any use of the controls while taking video on the phone usually creates too much shaking and movement in the video itself. The grip is very simple to attach and setup and it works well for this purpose.As other reviewers have mentioned, the software that is required to use with this product is less impressive. I don't necessarily need the attachment itself to work with other applications, but I would like the application itself to be more functional and link easily with other applications, like Facebook, Twitter, etc. Hopefully, Belkin will release updates to the software that make it more flexible. In the meantime, if you want a better hold on your iPhone to make it feel more like an actual camera, this is still a fine choice.

    Rating: 4

    2012-01-31: More and more people are using their iPhone/iPod Touch camera to take photographs and video. While the camera quality is decent on these products, it can be awkward to try to take pictures as these devices do not have the "feel" of a camera due to their thin, sleek design.Belkin's LiveAction Camera Grip does the trick here. If you use your iPhone/iPod for more than an occasional photo, you may appreciate this product. It gives you an easy to use, lightweight solution to help you hold your iPhone/iPod more like a conventional digital camera or camcorder.The Camera Grip attaches easily and securely. It is advertised as an accessory for the iPhone 4 and iPod Touch. I've used it with these, and also tried it on my 3G devices, which it fits on equally as well.To put the grip on, you simply connect it to the device's charger port. The grip has an adjustable arm so it can adapt to various cases. I have tried it on a couple of hard shell cases as well as my favorite Speck PixelSkin. Once connected, the grip gives you a nice grip on the right side of your "camera", along with a good size 'shutter button.'If you are taking several photos or video, it is nice to be able to hold the Apple device as a camera as opposed to holding it so that your fingers might get in the way or it can slip from your grasp.The grip also has a tripod mount on it, making it convenient if you want to tripod-mount your device. I have read where some people complain about the location of the mount, but to me it is no different than on an actual camera, where the tripod mount is on the bottom of the camera, and you depend on your tripod's flexibility to put the camera in different orientation (portrait/landscape/somewhere in between).The one caveat about the product is it functions only with Belkin's LiveAction camera/video application (free at the App Store). The app, while not ground-breaking, works well. It is no better than Apple's native Camera app, and in some ways not as flexible, but in the end it works as advertised. Note: LiveAction does use its own "camera roll" so any images you capture with the app are stored there, not in the default Camera Roll.Other than that it is pretty straight forward with the typical nuances of an accessory for Apple products:* When its attached, the port is occupied so you cannot charge or connect the device.* Depending on your case design, physical buttons may/may not be inaccessible.Overall, the product (and by the way, the LiveAction app) work very well. If your intended use is once in a great while for your own amusement, the price is probably too high. On the other hand, if you use your iPhone/iPod as a camera/camcorder more than on rare occasions, this is a nice addition to your Apple accessories; the added safety of having a firm grasp of your Apple device is alone worth the cost.

    Rating: 5

    2012-02-02: I have an excellent digital camera and an iPod that also takes really good pictures in addition to a cell phone that does as well. As for this particular product, it is good for use with your iPhone. I found that it also does well with the digital camera.The grip is adjustable to your photographic device and the USB jack goes right into your phone. The photo and video buttons are separate, which is another nice feature. You even get a video recorder button. If you want to use a tripod, you can only set your photographic device horizontally, which may or may not meet your needs.While this little gripper does not have any affect on the pictures that you take, it does make for an easier grasp of the camera/phone.If your photography needs are modest, then this is for you. If you want to shoot the extra miles and have more versatile features, then you will want to look elsewhere.

    Rating: 3

    2012-02-26: When I first ordered this, I was skeptical that it would work with my SwitchEasy case, but it fit over it just fine. The arms have just the right amount of "spring" but plenty of tension to hold the phone in its grip.When I put the iPhone 4 into the camera mode and it the shutter button on the LiveAction Camera Grip, it popped up a message asking if I wanted to download the required app.[App subject to change, but the app is integral to the Grip, so I must review it here.] It took me to the App Store to the Belkin LiveAction app. After the app was installed, I could hit the shutter button and the app automatically launched. The app does give access to both the front and rear camera, has flash features and has touch-to-focus. It also has a timer feature built-in.There is a separate red video record button, which is great, since in the stock Apple camera app, it is a pain to switch back and forth, especially on older iPhone models.When you do take photos or video, the files do not go into your Camera Roll, but stay in the app. If you want them to be in your Camera Roll, you have the option to transfer them as a batch or one-by-one.On my iPhone 4, there is quite a long delay from when you push the button and the frame freezes on the screen to when it actually captures the image. In fact, it is so bad that I don't think I could use it as is. It makes you think you got the shot, then saves an image from 1-2 seconds later. This seems to be fixable with an app update. I will write updates to this review if they make improvements to the app.If you are simply looking for a tripod adapter for your iPhone, this would be perfect for the bare iPhone or anyone with medium- to slim-size cases. Even if I elect not to use the nice shutter button on the grip, I can use the up volume button on the bottom (if mounted on a tripod) without too much difficulty and meet my objective.For what it's worth, this is not a bad option for an iPhone mount for video viewing...Overall, this is a well designed, let's just hope they follow it up with some app development to support it.

    Rating: 3

    2011-12-20: Belkin seems to have read my mind because I'd been looking for a camera grip/tripod mount for my iPhone 4S ever since I got it 2 months ago. I love my 4S, but when in landscape mode, I find it very difficult to take pictures with just one hand, so a camera style grip is extremely handy. Secondarily, I have a tripod and a mini-DV camcorder, but I wanted to use my iPhone for videos now because it's just 100x easier not having to transfer off of tape before editing my footage.A camera grip/tripod mount would potentially solve these two issues, but unfortunately, this LiveAction Grip just isn't the solution. I have 5 issues with it:1) too much $$2) LiveAction app too few options3) LiveAction does not play nice w/ Camera, iPhoto or Preview4) app really buggy5) video button too smallFirstly, it's just way too much to pay for what essentially is a little cradle. It girdles around only the bottom portion of the iPhone and does not offer any scratch or drop protection. I had to remove my skin in order to use the attachment. I would feel a lot better about the price if the unit was a wrap-around skin or had a larger footprint and covered the back part of the phone. Would've killed 2 birds with one stone. It's somewhat awkward to hold, being the size of two AA batteries stacked up. Also, a data-port pass-thru would be greatly appreciated. I don't like having to remove and plug back in attachments so often because of increased wear and tear on the connectors.Secondly, Belkin forgot the word "only" in their product description, as in "works ONLY with LiveAction app". LiveAction (free from App Store) is an unabashed copy of the default Camera app. Belkin just moved some buttons around and made some small cosmetic changes. It adds no extra features or enhancements. In fact, it even took away "Options", so there's no Grid Lines or HDR. You cannot use the Grip with the iPhone's default Camera app, or any other app, for that matter. It simply won't work. When I originally ordered this product, I thought I could just slap this on and be on my merry way, happily snapping pictures like I've been doing with Camera or Photosynth. No siree, you have to use LiveAction. Camera isn't features-rich, but it's a heck of a lot better than LiveAction. This is a very stupid marketing decision that severely undercuts the usefulness of this accessory-- app incompatibility should give you pause when considering this or any other purchase.My third and equally big complaint, is photos taken with Camera are stored in Camera's roll. Photos taken with LiveAction are stored in LiveAction's roll. LiveAction's roll cannot be accessed by Preview or iPhoto. You have to email them to yourself, put them on Facebook, or move them into Camera's roll. They exist as two separate, jailed off galleries and do not co-mingle. This is probably due to lazy and/or rushed programming because Photosynth, for example, saves data to the shared Camera roll. If you want LiveAction's photos to be in the Camera gallery, you have to move them there manually. One by one. This would be solved by just letting me use Camera, as mentioned above.Lastly, the app is really buggy and the video button is way too small. I managed to freeze the app already within 30 mins. It went to a black screen when I tried to take a photo without the attachment. When I put the attachment back on and switched back to the app, the screen was grey.Some of these concerns may be addressable in a software update. They might not. I want to use the default iPhone app for photos, not LiveAction. Belkin has to go back to the drawing board with this one. Not recommended yet.

    Rating: 3

    2012-01-29: Belkin iPhone LiveAction Camera GripI was very interested in this grip because even with a case, the iPhone is not easy to hold while using it as a camera. While the iPhone's camera is really good, the iPhone really wasn't designed to be held as one, the on-screen shutter is awkward to press even using the new volume-up button option. I saw this grip and although it was expensive, I thought it would solve the problem. It does, in a way. It IS comfortable and it DOES make a steady grip possible, but I don't know what Belkin was thinking when they engineered it to only work with their own free LiveAction app that must be downloaded from the App Store. The package says, "Works with LiveAction app." but what it should spell out more clearly is that it ONLY works with that app. There are dozens of professionally excellent photography apps for the iPhone and it just doesn't make sense that this grip won't work with any of them. It's probably a limitation imposed by Apple, but it cripples an otherwise well-designed, useful device.The grip has some nice features that demonstrate a well thought-out design - there are two buttons on the grip (right hand only, lefties are out of luck), one for taking still photos and one for video; the grippers on either side that hold the iPhone are spring-loaded so the device will accept the iPhone in its case and a tripod mount is provided on the underside. However, in the end, the $40-$50 price is unreasonably high considering the limitation of only being able to be used with Belkin's app. This well-built grip would rate a 5 from me if it could be used with any photography app.

    Rating: 2

    2012-01-30: "Make Your iPhone Feel Like a Digital Camera". You can make your iPhone feel like a digital camera just by holding it sideways and using the `volume up' button on the side of the phone (which is now actually on top and on the right side like most cameras) to snap the pictures.This gadget will essentially give you that same feature, plus a few others. You can take pictures while you are shooting video, without interrupting the video. Make sure you put your camera on silent mode or you will hear the loud clicking of each picture you take. This won't interrupt the audio that you are recording. You will still hear a slight click, but it is not too bad.There is a zoom feature on the app, but this is a touch screen feature. And it is only digital zoom anyway (not optical zoom), so this feature is really quite useless.This camera grip fit onto my iPhone 3G (without it's case). It is meant to fit onto an iPhone 4 WITH it's case on. The instructions (which you need a magnifying glass to read) say that it is "designed to fit over most iPod and iPhone cases. The arms are on springs and can stretch over the majority of cases". I use a fairly bulky rubber case and it did not work.Anyway, to use this camera grip, you have to get the Belkin LiveAction app (which is free). It worked with my 3G phone. What I didn't like about it is that there is a quite a delay when you push the button and the phone takes the picture. My preinstalled iPhone camera app takes faster pictures. It was very frustrating working with this app. It crashed on me a few times. I had to uninstall and reinstall to get it working again. Hopefully, they will fix all the bugs and get that to stop happening. If not, this product will get added to my junk drawer.The pictures taken with this app do not automatically go into my "Photos" section of my iPhone. You can click on "save to camera roll" on any picture you want transferred there.I like having the tripod mount. That is this products best feature (and really the only thing of value to me in this product). And the thread for the mount is actually made of metal and not plastic, so no worries of it wearing down over time.

    Rating: 3

    2012-01-29: It's nice to have this camera grip attached to my iPhone when I want to take snaps. It works well too. It's another thing though to carry, and for this reason I haven't used it on while on trips.The main added complexity is the necessity to use LiveAction, the App that comes with the device. I didn't want to get locked into using LiveAction as my primary iPhone camera application, but that's what has happened.

    Rating: 3

    2012-02-16: THe Belkin LiveAction camera grip fits great on the iPhone. I don't have to remove my case to be able to use the grip which is a plus. My existing case is a pain to remove. It is easy to use the grip. It has two buttons. One for snapping photos and one for recording. The part I really like most is the tripod mount built in. The app you need to use the grip is ok. It is easy to use. Not that fast but it works. When you snap photos you have to save them to your camera roll. It doesn't save them automatically. You can't use the grip to snap photos from the native camera app which is a huge letdown. It wouldn't have been great if you would be able to as you can take faster photos. Overall, the product is good but I really like it due to the tripod mount.

    Rating: 4

    2012-02-21: I really like the idea and appreciate the ability to add dedicated special use buttons only when needed as well as a tripod mount.Belkin could make it a little better by letting you release the clamp or pinch to hold open when installing on a device with a grippy skin. You have to slide this on and the pressure of the clamps doesn't do well with a grippy skin.once installed it does hold on tight and with the free app is useful.I do wish there were a couple more functions. A led for additional light, zoom, timer, remote control, usb port for external power. These would all greatly improve the value of this device. However as delivered it only adds a photo and video button when in its own app.Apple apparently needs to do a better job with the hardware API. I have to assume that had Apple designed its products with support for this kind of device it would work across multiple applications.When you plug the device in it is immediately recognized and if you don't have the app iOS will alert you to go to the app store to download.Unfortunately once you install this app iOS completely ignores when you attach the device. It would be really nice if you could configure the app to automatically start up when the device is attached or perhaps when the shutter is pressed.I didn't find any feature of the free photo app that wasn't available in other more capable apps, to the contrary it is somewhat limited and stores photos outside of the normal roll and stream storage.This does what it can well, adds hardware buttons for photo and video for the Belkin photo app only, as well as a tripod mount. It feels well built with quality buttons. I suspect the device will outlive its limited usefulness.

    Rating: 3

    2012-02-13: Since finally getting an iPhone 4S in October 2011, I have used my regular point and shoot camera less and less. I did notice that taking photos with the iPhone is not as easy as I would like, so I was excited to check this item out.It is nice that this grip is adjustable to work around any case or protective cover that you have on your phone. This camera grip works with the free Belkin LiveAction app only. It does not use the camera app included on the iPhone. That would be fine, but I think the shutter speed is even slower than the iPhone camera app. Plus, it is still difficult to not jerk the phone when pushing the button to take a picture. So if you actually need a really good quality photo out of your camera, just use the remote on your iPhone earbuds that came with your phone. I lost mine, but I know that it worked great. I wish I didn't loose mine.Also this grip has a way to easily switch between taking video and taking photos. One thing that I found useful is the tripod mount. That is something that does not come with the iPhone. OK not all the time does one carry around a tripod, but if you wanted to be in the picture without looking like you were holding your phone with your arm in the picture, there is a 5 second timer and a 10 second timer.The instructions that come with this grip are not so great, in fact, there aren't really instructions, just warranty information. On the Belkin website, there isn't much information either. It's just something you would have to play with and figure out on your own. This is another item to bring with you when going on an outing, it might be easier to just take the point and shoot.

    Rating: 3

    2012-01-22: The theory behind the Live Action adapter is to allow you to quickly point and shoot with your iPhone and hold it like a traditional camera. I really never had a problem with that. Sure, most point and shoot cameras have buttons at the top rather than the side, but since I'm looking at the iPhone screen while taking the shot its really not a problem.The frosted plastic device is easier to grip than some iPhone cases and there is a built in port to hold a tripod, so that can be a nice feature for some. The free companion iPhone app does load faster than the camera and if you are doing quick shots (think those model photographers) it is easier to click the top of the phone rather than the screen.The device has a very limited use range and set of features but it's a one trick pony and certainly isn't worth the cost. If you have trouble clicking the screen rather than the top or need a tripod mount, go for it. Otherwise move on.

    Rating: 2

    2011-12-21: This is a very clever device with buttons for making iPhone photography a bit easier. The grip itself feels solid and is made of hard plastic and rubberized materials. The two end clips are on springs which allow the grip ends to expand, yet spring back over the iPhone or iPhone cases. The grip should fit around most rubberized type cases. However, the iPhone may have to be removed from some larger cases for the grip's connector to fit into the iPhone. Grip surfaces which touch the iPhone are rubberized to avoid marring the iPhone's finish. Once connected, the grip fits snuggly with no movement. The grip helps to steady the iPhone and provides a comfortable handle for picture taking. It also has a bottom metal thread mount for tripods.With the grip installed, my iPhone will not fit into the small pouch type cases I use to carry it around. It is also somewhat awkward to carry around in my pocket. It fits fine in a purse or larger case made for small point-and-shoot cameras. For my purposes, I'll remove the grip and only use it when I know I'll be shooting alot of pictures or video. The grip doesn't interfere with making or taking calls.On top of the grip are two buttons. One is black for normal photos and one is a smaller red button for taking video. With the Belkin photo app, photos and video can be taken without changing any settings on the screen. Just push one of the buttons. The app itself is simple to use and provides basic settings.This grip does exactly what it describes. It seems well built and provides a threaded tripod mount. It works seamlessly with Belkin's photo app. However, it seems overpriced for what it does. Also, I found it difficult to install the grip over my existing iPhone case and would only use it for dedicated photo/video sessions because of this. It would install quickly and fit perfectly over uncased iPhones or those with thin rubberized enclosures.In summary, this is a very good device for steadying up your iPhone for taking photos and videos. The bottom threaded mount is a real bonus. The photo app works well and makes the iPhone feel a bit like a small point-and-shoot camera. As previously stated, it seems overpriced.

    Rating: 4

    2011-12-19: My new iPhone 4S takes nice photos and is almost able to replace carrying a digital camera. However, it's difficult to hold that little bar of soap properly. This Belkin accessory grip fixes that very nicely. It has separate buttons to replace touchscreen for photos and movie, making it feel like a real camera. Even a tripod socket so you can take your own picture. A bit overpriced but clever and useful .. except ..... except it can only be used to take photos with Belkin's own photography app they call Liveaction photo (free)! So, as the price for using this, one is cut off from the hundreds of cool photo apps out there for iPhone, each of which takes pictures in a slightly different way, which is what the open source iPhone is all about - this is an astoundingly bad marketing decision by Belkin. Maybe they did not invite the right employees to their design meeting??     2012-03-13: As far as the product itself goes, it's well made and functions as it is designed to - so I can't really say anything bad about it's construction or inherent design.
