    Rating: 3

    2011-12-20: My iPhone, like many people, I'm sure, has replaced a conventional camera for photography.This is a nice accessory that gives the user some flexibility for ease of photography using the iPhone 4. The grip uses an adjustable arm to cradle an iPhone regardless of the width of the iPhone case. It plugs right into the USB jack in the bottom of the phone. There are two buttons: One for photographs and one for videos. The video recorder button is a bit diminutive in size and oftentimes, difficult to feel for. The photographic button is just the right size. Unfortunately, there are no connecting ports on the grip to allow for iPhone charging without having to remove the iPhone from the device. This is a big negative for me, since I have to remove the phone to dock it for recharging. There is a tripod mount that allows for mounting of the grip/iPhone; however, since there is no accessory hole to keep the grip from rotating, this grip will only work in the horizontal, not vertical or angled orientation.The Grip functions with the Live Action App that is downloaded from the iTunes store. Installation of software is simple. Since this accessory operations ONLY through the application, it is necessary to dock the icon in the home screen (at least that is what I did). Unfortunately, this grip only works through the app and not any other iPhone application such as the Facebook app, intrinsic camera app, Yelp!, Demon Cam, etc. That is a major limitation of this particular peripheral.The application itself is decent. It allows the user to take photographs and videos easily with just a push of the mechanical button. Control for timer shooting and flash customization just like the intrinsic camera app are possible. Unfortunately, the app stores the photos and videos in its own application jacket, not the Camera Roll. It can be exported to the Camera Roll or Facebook but not YouTube. Bear in mind, this grip only facilitates photography as limited by the technology of the iPhone. It in no way enhances the experience except for simplicity and ergonomics.ConsLimited mounting option for tripodsApplication is necessary for photography and videographyGrip/functions only function within the appNo external port to allow for seamless chargingExtra steps for exporting to YouTubeNot compatible with other iPhone camera apps/functionsProsSimple toggling of photography and videographyErgonomic design of handleTripod capable (WITH LIMITATIONS)OverallOverall, this is a decent product with some big limitations in my book. Certainly, future iterations of the applications can be good workarounds for improved functionality. The tripod mount is quite limited.Because of some major limitations, I must say that it has limited use as of this writing. It's decent but not great. It's just OK in my book. Your mileage may vary.

    2012-01-03: Nice quality grip, fits multiple case styles, but I still find myself not carrying it with me because it is bulky and of marginal use.     Rating: 2

    2012-02-15: The Belkin LIveAction Camera Grip is a simple grip that attaches to the iPhone 4 or 4S and provides two shutter buttons (one for still shots and the other for videos) as well as a standard tripod thread mount.When you attach the grip to your iPhone for the first time, the phone automagically notifies you that this accessory requires the LiveAction app and takes you to the app store so you can download it (the app is free).The LiveAction app is pretty similar to the standard Apple Camera app: the most noticeable difference is the addition of a delay shutter release button (5 or 10 seconds) and the lack of HDR control. The trigger button on the grip works great with the app; unfortunately, it only triggers the shutter in the LiveAction app, a significant limitation.The standard threaded mount is very convenient and worked well with my mini-tripod. The arms of the grip are spring-mounted and handled my favorite case (Amazon Basics TPU) without problems, although theOtterBox Universal Defender Casedid not fit.PROS----* Very simple to use* Helps you download the LiveAction app* Compatible with most iPhone cases (very thick ones won't work)* App includes timer feature* Fits well in hands of all sizes, shutter button feels very natural* Tripod thread mountCONS-----* Shutter button only works with Belkin LiveAction app, no other camera app (probably because of limitations of the iOS API, but it's still disappointing)* Not so necessary now that the volume button can be used as a shutter button in the Apple Camera app (but it puts a trigger button in a much more natural position)* PriceyCONCLUSION-----------Although the limitations of the shutter button to the Belkin LiveAction app significantly limit its usefulness, the universal thread mount and the compatibility with most cases make the Belkin Grip a fairly useful little accessory for the casual photographer, more convenient than aGlif-- even if you end up not always using the shutter button.

    Rating: 4

    2012-02-01: This is a good accessory to have with you when the iPhone 4 is the only camera you have. But the new iPhone 4s, with a new and powerful camera easily makes it the only point and shoot camera you need.When you first attach the adapter to the iPhone, it will prompt you to install the free LiveAction app from Belkin. Then it is the app you have to use to shoot pictured. Unlike others, I don't mind this because it is free and only takes a minute to download and install. Then shoot away. Belkin even provided a tripod mount, so you can set the timer and jump into the picture!This adapter can even attach to my iPhone with the case on! if you have a not too bulky iPhone cover, you can attach it without taking the cover off. It is much easier to attach without the cover, but it worked in my case with the cover on. Great accessory!

    2012-02-01: THis product by Belkin is a really great idea. I love the added comfort it gives when taking pictures. It has a great feel and is easy to hold making your ipod touch or iphone feel like a real camera. I hated taking pics as my fingers always get in the way of the lens and it feels weird to hold the ipod and try to touch the screen to take a picture. This solves that problem and does a great job of making the ipod more comfortable to hold. It also fits over any case you have so you dont need to remove your case. It is also very lightweight and doesnt add any weight to you ipod or iphone.The only drawbacks are the product only works with the Belkin liveaction app(which is free from the app store) and not any other picture apps. There are a few drawbacks but I really like the camera grip and think it has some great potential.

    Rating: 4

    2012-01-02: The iPhone is being increasingly used as both a "real" camera and videocamera, and so the idea of a usable camera grip is a great idea. With this grip Belkin gets several things right: the grip is nice and solid, the trigger button is well-placed, and finally having a tripod mount is a godsend. But I have to agree with several other reviewers: why oh why did Belkin pair this promising grip with such a half-baked app? No serious photographer would use their app. Without being able to use their trigger button functionality in a decent app, all I have left is an overpriced tripod mount. Belkin PLEASE reach out to some of the leading camera apps and convince them to put a hook in their code to your hardware. Otherwise consumers will pass you by for better and cheaper alternatives to this grip.

    Rating: 2

    2012-02-16: As an ergonomic handle for converting the iPhone into an easier to hold point and shoot camera, it does a very nice job. There are two bottons on the top for shooting pictures (a raised button), or shooting video (an adjacent smaller red button flush with the top of the grip). The design of the grip is well thought out: the top "wing" of the holder, is actually a bit concave, perfect for resting your thumb and keeping it off the screen.The things to like:Makes gripping the phone as a camera very easy and comfortable.The LiveAction App is free to download.Works with both forward and rear facing cameras.The App is intuitive: it has a zoom, delay timer, flash setting (on, off, and auto), with a touch you can tell it where to focus. It is very easy to transmit or upload photos once they are taken.The things not to like are:The buttons on the grip are a bit too far forward rather than directly over the phone, but you do get used to it.The Grip only works with the (Belkin) LiveAction App an cannot be used with the phone's regular camera functions or any other photo app.Pictures are not stored in your cameral roll, but in the "Gallery" of the app.The grip covers the charging socket and must be removed to charge the phone.Overall it is a nice little gadget if you want to use your phone as a dedicated camera. The limitation of using only LiveAction is a drawback.

    Rating: 3

    2012-01-26: I was thinking this little gadget was going to do something amazing in conjunction with my ipod touch, but it doesn't seem to do much. In its favor, it does fit both ipod touch AND iphone and it has a place to attach it to a tripod, but on the minus side...you can get the same type of contraption WITH a tripod that will work without taking the case off your phone for much cheaper. I just don't really understand WHY you would want this gadget...the app that it works with isn't anything special and another annoying little thing is I can't seem to attach this to my ipod without pressing the button on top of the ipod while I push this into place. I noticed that Belkin advertises a LiveAction Mic on the amazon product page and a directional microphone like that would be really cool for the ipod/iphone but this doohickey I don't recommend at all.

    Rating: 1

    2012-02-15: This sturdy grip allows iPhone 4s owners to turn their phone into what feels like a "real" camera, with the proper "real" camera buttons. Since the iPhone has such an excellent camera built into it, this accessory can make sense, especially if you would like to mount the phone to a tripod.One drawback: this product only works with the Belkin App, so that limits what you can do with this accessory.

    Rating: 4

    2012-02-02: I really like this hardware. As most people know, the iPhone 4s has a really good camera.The grip makes it easy to take still photos and videos. There are separate buttons for each.I found the construction to be firm and the button response was very tactile.The thing I was not so keen on was the software that comes with it. You are supposed to go to the app store and download a free live action app. Then you put the gadget on. Each time you want to use the camera grip you have to open the Live Action app, NOT the camera roll. Bah. Pressing the buttons on the camera grip when you are in the native camera mode does nothing. This could be confusing if you hand someone your phone to take a picture, making you miss a good shot! The good news is that when you plug in the grip the correct software opens automatically. But its still less than desirable.This is a software/hardware combination, and you must use their software. So, I feel its my responsibility to tell you some other shortcomings of the software.1) It puts all the pictures and videos in a "gallery". This is a separate place, and the pictures you take go there instead of into your camera roll. I don't like this. I like all my stuff in one place. You can tell it to save the stuff in your camera roll one by one. What a pain.2) You can upload to Facebook directly from the camera app. To do this, you must share your data with Belkin on Facebook. I don't like this very much. I guess its the only way. Otherwise you would have to take the picture, transfer it to your camera roll, go into Facebook, and upload it. Thats not much fun either. So I allowed it to access Facebook, otherwise I can't really review it. The first time I got an error. The second time it tried to upload but took 5 minutes for one picture, and then it timed out. I set it up to try a third time but I got a message that there was no internet connection (as if!). So that feature seems to be broken. Good thing that Belkin got permission to access my personal data up front!! (thats sarcasm)3) The timer should flash your iPhone 4 4s flash right before the picture takes, as a visual way to see that the picture is about to shoot.Anyway lots of room for improvement. I don't seem much need to go on. You get the point. The software is not very good.Overall I like using the device for taking photos. I like the mount that it uses. I think it would be great for snapping a lot of photos at theme parks, wedding receptions, or whatever. But the implementation of the software leaves something to be desired...

    Rating: 3

    2012-02-09: Based on an excellent idea, it could have proved to be far more useful, IF:- No need to use separate LiveAction app- Compatible with native camera pp and other photography apps.- Would have provided a locking mechanism to hold the cameraA lot of time, i strongly feel the need of such a grip, but the grip has to be universal and not just fixed to a crappy app like LiveAction.Belkin's app has no HDR support and does not saves pictures in photo album.Moreover while comparing images in exactly same lighting and scene condition, I found native camera app superior in image quality than LiveAction app.Digital zoo of LiveAction changes the frame & zoom level while taking picture!If Belkin's needs an interface to detect this grip, they could have come up with a simple app, which could recognize the hardware and automatically launch native camera app. Or to make it even better, they could have given an option to select your default camera app in settings (say Instagram) and launch that app automatically when grip gets connected. Come on guys this is 2012 and seamless integration is the key to success of any product!

    Rating: 2

    2012-02-02: I have mixed feeling about this product. i really like the concept of holding the IPhone as a small camera. It grips the phone better and can prevent the phone from slipping. It is also cool that you can basically turn the phone into a point and shoot camera by adding this.But I will point out a few drawbacks with my experience.1. With a defender otter box on the IPhone-a very popular case that protects the phone, you cannot use this gadget. I remove the outer rubber cover and then it fits.2.The user still has to be careful not to put fingers in front of the lens. The grip sits very close to the lens. This takes a conscious effort on the part of the user.3.When transferring the pictures to the camera roll to upload to your computer, the software only can transfer 5 at a time. This is a pain if you shoot a lot of pictures. It makes the process time consuming.I do like the small size of this. The concept is genius. When I attached the grip and it did not touch the sides of my phone completely, I thought it would not work, but it did. Plugging the grip into the IPhone's power source makes it work. The grip also fits into my purse easily.If Belkin can improve on the above, they would have a stellar product!UPDATE:As I stated above, when transferring to the camera roll, you can only do 5 at a time. But when I transferred and then went back to shooting, the device did not work. I had to restart my I Phone.

    2012-04-24: It would be a reasonable idea to add this grip to the iPhone if it didn't then disable basic functionality like zooming in and out, as well as using the great new iPhone gesture to get to the camera from the locked screen. The benefit of stabilizing the iPhone and making pictures easier to take is vastly outweighed by the downsides of limiting the photo software on the iPhone.

    Rating: 2

    2011-12-20: I wish I had this two weeks ago when I was on vacation in Alberta. I have always found the iPhone clunky when you are trying to take pictures...especially if you want to hold the phone steady. And maybe I just have fat fingers, but I am always inadvertently switching from photo-mode to video-mode. The Belkin Live action solves those problems and more. This is a must-have accessory for your iPhone if you plan on taking a lot of pictures. The Live Action Grip is comfortable, intuitive, and allows you to hold and operate the iphone like a camera. This easy, snap-on device moves the photo button to the top (and adds a new button for video) and allows you to have a firm, steady grip on the device at all times. And their free LiveAction app, which works with the accessory, simplifies the photo-taking process...and makes it even easier to send or post the pictures that you take. I love it. And so does my family. But it's easy for us to love -- we got it for free to review as an Amazon Vine member. At fifty bucks, the grip is way, way, WAY over-priced. What are they thinking? This should be a $15 item....and everybody with an iPhone would buy one. At least the App is free...!

    Rating: 4

    2012-03-14: As a serious photo-hobbyist, I am intrigued by using the iPhone as a camera. While image quality can't compare to that of my DLSR, numerous apps can be used to produce amazing creative photos especially for sharing on the web. The Belkin LiveAction Camera Grip, made in China, mainly caught my attention because of the tripod mounting capabilities, but otherwise seemed gimmicky.The Belkin LiveAction Camera Grip, made in China, requires using the free LiveAction app available from the App Store. Using spring loaded arms on the sides, the camera grip is case compatible, and attaches to the charging end of a 30-pin connector iPhone. Photo and video on/off buttons are located on the top end of the grip and a 1/4 inch tripod mount on the base.The LiveAction app interface provides limited setting options for photo/video. A flash button toggles between on, off and automatic, a timer button toggles between off, 5 seconds, and 10 seconds, and a camera button toggles between front and back camera lenses. A small photo icon on the bottom right takes the user to the browsing section where a slideshow can be played, photos/videos can be deleted, or photos/videos can be shared to Facebook, sent by email, or saved to the Camera Roll.The best features of the Belkin LiveAction Camera Grip are the spring loaded arms and tripod mount. Otherwise, shooting photos or videos are more trouble than using the iPhone camera app. Photos are stored in a separate location from the camera roll as well, unless the user physically chooses to move them there. The lack of integration and a troublesome app ruin the benefits of having an iPhone camera grip.If you're looking for a useful tool for taking photos and videos on your iPhone, the Belkin LiveAction camera grip is sure to disappoint. Save your money and skip purchasing this product.PROS:1/4 inch tripod mount1 year warrantyCONS:Camera lag between pressing the button and the shot is takenLiveAction app continually freezes and reacts poorly to touchNot integrated with iPhone Camera system

    Rating: 1

    2012-02-16: I ordered this hoping it would be as easy to use as advertised. A certain family member (cough - husband - cough) sometimes misses kodak moments and I had high hopes of this grip with app being able to help. As it turns out, not so much. Although this device was easy to use, it did not provide much more than what is already provided by your iPhone in the way of features.The Belkin camera grip is easy to plug into your iPhone and the app is quickly downloaded and installed. The app is not complicated and although basic, is helpful but doesn't go much beyond free features already provided by Apple for your iPhone. It provides an easy way to toggle between the photo and video buttons (iPhone has a sliding button between camera and red dot/video), allows you to instantly go from still to live shooting (also provided by iPhone screen) and makes it easy to share your photos and videos with social networks (this is pretty easy without using this app too). I did like how the grip has a built-in tripod mount for any standard tripod, very convenient.The only added benefit to this device is the comfortable camera grip that easily attaches to your iPhone. The app itself provides much of the same features already provided by Apple for your iPhone (which is free). I cannot recommend this device unless you have money to burn or willing to spend money for a comfortable grip.

    Rating: 3

    2012-02-02: The use cases for the Belkin F8Z888tt iPhone LiveAction Camera grip are limited since it is a bit bulky, and requires that you launch a dedicated application on your iPhone. If you want to keep your iPhone in your pocket and whip it our for a picture, then this is not for you. But if you want to go on a photo shoot, or record video, with a bag or holding your iPhone in your hand, then this works great.The Camera grip works with the Apple bumper case as well as will most other slim cases.The Camera grip plugs into the charging/sync port on the iPhone and the arms are spring loaded to accommodate cases.The major contact points with your iPhone or case are rubberized.There is a dedicated video record button (small red), and a dedicated picture taking button (large black).You need to be in the app in order to use the still or video camera.As you are recording video, you can take stills and the video will continue recording.The app does not require the Belkin Camera grip to work.There is no pass through port so you cannot charge your iPhone while you are recording.I can imagine taking this into the back country, leaving Canon at home as I can us my miniJoby GP1-D1EN Gorillapod Flexible Tripod (Grey). I do wish that there were an iPhone app that let you set aperture, white balance, etc... but my iPhone does take some amazing shots without those settings.

    Rating: 4

    2012-02-14: TheBelkin LiveAction Camera Grip with Application for Apple iPhone 4sis a good idea for making your iPhone or iPod Touch more camera-like. The grip's shape and controls are ergonomic and functional. But this product is unnecessarily limited by the LiveAction application, which is required to use the grip. So while there are some nice design features to the hardware, the product's design does not leverage the IOS software and the tons of other photo applications that are out there.PROS:++ Ergonomic grip makes holding your iPhone or iPod much easier++ Intuitive and simple buttons for photo and video++ Threaded adapter for tripod mounting++ Spring loaded grips adjust to the thickness of your device (can work with some cases)++ Does not cover up any lenses , ports or buttons (only the dock connector)++ Nice matte surface++ Hard rubber cushions on the grips for a sturdy fit++ Included user manual is short and sweetCONS:-- LiveAction application is extremely limited-- Product won't work with native IOS camera functions or other applications from the app-store-- No way to lock the grip arms in place once your iPod or iPhone is mounted-- Noticeable photo lag when taking pictures-- Pictures are not automatically stored in your camera roll and must be transferred afterwards-- Limited numbers of pictures can be transferred from the app at once-- Causes freezing & requires frequent reboots-- Excessive list priceCONCLUSIONPerhaps there is a way for them to address this product's limitations though software updates. But I think there are enough problems that they will likely have to go back to the drawing board. Wait for version 2.0 because this product is not yet ready for primetime.

    Rating: 2

    2012-02-15: Given that almost all Smart Phone accessories are generally expensive, Belkin has created a nifty product for photo and video ease that is what I'd call "in the learning process". The adjustable grip is nice and snug and easily held, however, it will not fit over an Otterbox and some other cases. Only the thinnest case will allow it. The video and camera buttons are easy enough feel and work; much better than simply taking the iPhone and holding it up (forward or reverse) as it helps keep your fingers out of the camera view. There is a tripod mount which is convenient and Belkin does make a remote control feature accessory but oddly it does not fit with this accessory.For charging your device, you need to detach the handle. It would be nice to have an extra input on the bottom so you could simply rest the entire phone and handle in a charger.Belkin does require the use of a free app which means you are limited by its proprietary software. This means it is not compatible with other iPhone camera apps or functions. Exporting to YouTube is more difficult as well. It is a very good idea built I would wait until Belkin or Apple invent a similar device that is fully compatible with all camera applications and functions.

    Rating: 2

    2011-12-22: It doesn't quite fit into your hand as well as they'd like you to believe. It does help to stabilize your iPhone or iPod but there is some awkwardness. It helps steady your hand some but I wouldn't say that it's perfect. I did notice that the app got low scores in the app store but that doesn't always mean very much.

    2012-02-17: As a child I had a Pet Rock. It was round, firm and had a name written in ink on it: Fred. I bought Fred of off a kid down the street for a nickel because Fred was advertised as a fun and loyal companion. Fred was not. Fred didn't run, he didn't talk and I'm not convinced he was all that loyal. In fact, Fred was pretty useless- almost like a, well, a 5 cent rock.I've recently come into possession of the Belkin LiveAction Camera Grip with Application for Apple iPhone. I downloaded the app and messed with the hardware and feel the product is absolutely worthless. You attach the Belkin "camera handle stabilizer thingey" to the business end of your sleek iPhone 4, encumbering it to be more like a camera. Nevermind that some newer cameras are about as small as the attachment itself - but with the push of a button (or two) you can instantly snap some pics - just like a REAL camera! That is, if you've already had the attachment on your iPhone and you haven't snaped off the male end of the attachment when you sit with the phone and attachment in your pocket. Having to carry an extra accesory with you also renders the point of a small, sleek and mostly compact iPhone very moot.If, by chance you didn't have the Belkin Camera Kung Fu grip attached to your handy iPhone 4, it'll be much quicker to unlock your iPhone and call up the resident Camera app than fumbling with the gadget.The Belkin app itself is a wonder to behold. A line or two of code above bloatware. After taking pictures with the proprietary hardware and software, your pics have dissappeared into, yes- a Proprietary Gallery. HOW AWESOME! Gallery is accessible only through the Belkin app itself. Suh-weet!Well, I could go on and on, blasting this product but it'd be like beating a dead horse.I still have the Belkin Camera Grip in my possession. I named it Fred and it sits on my shelf. My $32 Pet Rock.

    Rating: 2

    2012-04-19: I manage my company's blog program and often shoot video interviews along with photos. Belkin's LiveAction Camera Grip is perfect for both still shots and video.It allows me to fire off photos with a shutter button like my old digital camera. For videos, there is a tripod mount. Those two features alone make up for the minor inconvenience of having to use the Belkin LiveAction App, which actually is a decent one. I just wish it gave me the option of using whichever app I wanted. But a huge deal, though.It you are looking for an option that will allow you to leave your digital camera and videocamera at home, then the Belkin LiveAction Camera Grip is worth a shot. Two thumbs up from me.

    Rating: 4

    2012-02-06: #It's difficult deciding how to rate this product.It does grab onto your iPod or iPhone, even if it's in aBelkin F8W043ebC02 Essential 051 (Silicon) Case for Apple iPod Touch 4G - Fountain Blue, and when you click either button you get pretty much what you expect.But it works only with the Belkin LiveAction app, which it downloads from the App(le) Store. Had I known this I would not have ordered it.For one thing I don't want to have to move the images I take using this product from where they automatically get sent to to where I want them, which is the Camera Roll, which is where all the other images are. And I don't want to have to go through Belkin to upload images to a social media site. I find the LiveAction software to be just generally not quite mature.On the plus side, the product does offer a standard metal tripod mount, which is the only reason I ordered it at all. At least one reviewer already correctly noted that to use this product -- since you're not going to keep it attached to your device if you aren't using it as a camera grip -- you have to carry it around with you and then attach it to your camera before you can record images using it. I just leave it attached to my tripod, since that's the only way in which I use it.So far I award three stars, because if I really need a tripod-mounted shot I can now have it. But that's not much for the price of this product so I subtract one star, which means we're down to two.Now it's time to report on a few off-book tests I performed to see whether I should add or subtract any stars to arrive at the final rating.1. Although it latches nicely onto an iPod or iPhone 4, it does not latch at all well onto any of the following: a Droid Razr smartphone, a standard bowling ball, a hamster, a $6,900Leica M9 18MP Digital Range Finder Camera (Black, Body Only), the USS Nimitz CVN-68 aircraft carrier (not a camera), a Steinway Model D Concert grand piano (too big), and a slab of lime Jello-O in the shape and size of an iPhone 4 (WAY too squishy). I didn't test other flavors.2. The Belkin LiveAction Camera Grip with Application for Apple iPhone 4s does not contain any radioactive elements or isotopes. According to the USDA and the FDA and the EEUNSSHA you may use it while pregnant. China does not object to it, which is where it's made. Dan Quayle is not on record as objecting to it. No animals are harmed in the testing of this product. It is not prohibited on airplanes by the TSA.3. When shot through the heart with a .22 caliber bullet at ten yards, my particular example of this product flew into several pieces and is now both utterly unusable and also not, according to a very nice woman at Belkin named Beulah, covered by the warranty.#

    2013-11-30: Never really worked properly with my iPhone and I never use it. Wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Belkin does make good products but this one is a miss.

    Rating: 2

    2012-02-22: Well, it seemed clever, and I gave it the benefit of the doubt that it filled a need. The problem is that in filling the need for a quick physical shutter button for the iPhone 4/4S, it makes the iPhone a completely clunky device.For starters, the device must be used in conjunction with a very basic camera app provided through the App Store by Belkin. It basically replicates the built-in iPhone camera app's functions, but disables the on-screen button. Belkin could have gone a step further and added some special filters, something, anything to make this stand out a bit. But that's beside the point - it works just fine as it is, but you're stuck with that app and ONLY that app. No using Camera+ or Instagram or, well, *anything*.Plug the grip into the iPhone via the dock charger and you find that it cradles that end of the iPhone perfectly, with self-sizing grips holding either side of the iPhone that will stretch out to accommodate a bumper or other similar-sized case. Open the app and press the camera button, located closest to the speaker (that's the "right" grill opening on the bottom when holding the iPhone in portrait mode, or the "upper" grill in landscape.) It does indeed make taking a photo very quick and easy, with a confident little "snip" feel to the button.There are two routes you can go with the LiveAction Camera Grip - you either leave it on so you can take full advantage of it or mount it as needed. Neither of these works all that well, however. The grip is big and, as we know, the iPhone is long and slim. Leaving it on makes it awkward to keep in a pocket, but the alternative is putting it on for every picture, then removing it, and keeping the grip somewhere. It's just awkward, period. A solution, it turns out, for what is really a very minor problem.And making things worse, Apple included shutter-button capability in iOS 5, so depressing the "up" volume button while the Camera app is open snaps a picture. So, basically, this device becomes pointless, other than the plus of the built-in tripod mount - but then there are solutions to that out there, too (like thisStand with Mini Tripod Mount Adapter for iPhone 4G (Black).)

    Rating: 1

    2012-02-02: I was excited to be able to try this grip with my iPhone 4s. Two things attracted me: 1. Tripod socket; 2. A "real" shutter button vs. the on screen or volume button release that is native to the iPhone. What I didn't realize was how bad the accompanying app is and that the hardware is incompatible with any other camera app for the iPhone.Pros:1. Very nice shutter button that allows for smoother shutter release that will reduce jitter.2. Rubbery surface on the grip that helps you hold the slim and slippery iPhone with more solid confidence.3. Metal tripod socket - not plastic - that allows you to use the LiveAction self timer function when mounting the iPhone on a tripod.*** the one plus the LiveAction camera app has is the self timer, btw.Cons:1. Weak, weak, weak, Live Action Camera app is required to operate with the grip.2. No support for the HDR capability of the iPhone 4s.3. No suport for any camera app other than LiveAction.4. No positive lock onto the iPhone with the grip connector. it's pretty much held on by friction.5. Expensive for this level of functionality.Conclusion:I gave it two stars because it is frustrating that something that has so much promise is left with lame software and a high price for what you get. Hope they revise it in the future.

    Rating: 2

    2012-02-15: I really like this hardware - more than I thought I would, candidly. It makes the iPhone much easier to grip and take pictures with, and adds the ability to take timer pictures by using the tripod mount and software. My only issue with the hardware is that I wish there was a zoom in and out button - you still have to use the touchscreen for that. It does add some bulk to the phone (and to carry it around when not attached to the phone), but it makes picture-taking in certain situations significantly easier.As others have noted, the software is not the best. However, I assume Belkin is working from hardware/software interface restrictions that do not permit the device to access the shutter function via the dock connector for Apple's camera app and other camera apps. You can move images from the Belkin app to the camera roll manually (and then post process them with any number of apps - a bit of a wonky work-around, for sure), but my biggest frustration is that you can't do it automatically or in bulk - it's a one photo at a time process. Hopefully these issues can be addressed in an update to the companion app.

    Rating: 4

    2012-01-30: The LiveAction Grip works nicely to help you hold your iPhone for picture taking or movie making. However, it only works with the Belkin LiveAction app. This app is virtually worthless and is full of bugs. I have the latest version and there are many problems. After taking a picture, when I go to see what I took, it was always upside down! I had to quit the app and restart to get it to work. It freezes up, or has a very slow response. There are no HDR settings to take a good picture. No features come with the app other than to take a picture with or without a flash, or a movie. No way to turn off the shutter sound so even though it lets you take a still while you are making a video, the shutter sound comes out on your video. The hardware is worthless without good software.The best use of this device right now is as a handhold for another photo app, or to mount your iPhone to a tripod because it does have a tripod mount screw hole.

    2012-03-24: If iPhone is the only camera you use, and most of your photography is planned then this may be a useful accessory to have. It turns the iPhone into a digital camera that you can use with Belkin LiveAction app on a tripod.I have a couple of Canon digital cameras that I use for planned photography sessions or occasions. iPhone camera is what I use for spontaneous or extempore moments because I carry it in my pocket most of the time. Belkin LiveAction app does't have as many options for pictures as other apps like Camera+ have.If iPhone is the only camera you have, you may find this Belkin LiveAction camera grip useful.

    Rating: 3

    2012-02-12: I'm in love with the fact that apps can now take advantage of external hardware on iOS - and the Belkin line of camera accessories for the iPhone is no exception. The idea behind the LiveAction Camera Grip is great - it gives your otherwise limited iPhone, "real" camera buttons and the ability to mount to a tripod. Who could ask for more? Well, for starters, people who like the large variety of camera apps for iOS will be disappointed, as this accessory only works with the Belkin App. This means you are unnecessarily limited in your options.The hardware is pretty decent - it clips onto your phone, and a spring loaded set of clamps keep it in place. In many ways it really does feel like you are holding a "real" camera. The tripod mount option is there - but in my experience, the whole setup wiggles around a bit too much.Sadly though, the biggest drawback is the price - $45 us just too much to ask for something this limited. Sure, if you absolutely must attach your iPhone to a tripod, and you absolutely must have hardware shutter, this will deliver and make you happy. Otherwise, just do what everyone else does, and use the screen or existing buttons.

    Rating: 3

    2013-06-07: It is so rare that any camera-related iPhone accessory will accommodate a case - I'm just floored at how well this works. It fits snugly into the 30-pin port of my iPhone 4S and expands to snugly hold my phone in it's Smigen case. With one hand, I can hold the phone, compose the shot and click the shutter release - all w/o touching the screen. The red button next to the shutter release is a quick toggle to the video mode. These hardware switches are SO MUCH FASTER than the software method of tapping the screen and waiting for a result. I highly recommend this product for ergonomic ease of holding your phone while taking photos - and for quicker snapshots w/ the physical hardware button. This thing is awesome.

    Rating: 5

    2012-02-02: The Belkin LiveAction grip attaches to the phone firmly. I like that the side arms are spring-loaded and the clearance to the back of the grip is sufficient so that it would work with most bumpers and cases, unless you're an Otterbox fan. When you insert the phone into the grip, the LiveAction app automatically opens. As others have said, the buttons on this grip work only with that app and not any others.If the LiveAction app were good, then perhaps I wouldn't complain, but it has only the features of the standard Apple camera app and, in my experience, it froze twice when I tried tapping some of the on-screen options (such as flash, or when viewing the gallery.) Worse, there was a noticeable delay between when I pressed the shutter button on the grip and when it took the picture. With the standard camera app on an iPhone 4S, I measured the delay as about a quarter-second, whereas with the LiveAction grip and app, it was two seconds! The app is also unresponsive to taps on its controls and it would often take me several tries to get an action to register.It is nice that it provides a tripod socket and if you are using it for movies, the shutter delay is probably inconsequential, but there are lots of "camera grips" for iPhones out there. You could of course ignore the buttons and the LiveAction app and just use the standard app, or something like Camera+ or Filmic (both great), using the Belkin grip as just a grip. Otherwise, I'd recommend skipping this and looking elsewhere.

    Rating: 2

    2012-04-09: The Belkin LiveAction Camera Grip is a gadget looking for a problem. It is a neat idea, to turn your iPhone into a camera, with the look and feel of an actual shutter button. It does work, and it does give you a nice area to grip your phone in both portrait and landscape modes. However, practically, there is little use for this accessory.The main issue is that you cannot use any sort of case when using the camera grip. I don't know about you, but I like to keep my iPhone safely covered. It also adds quite a bit of bulk to your iPhone. The other limitation is that you are only able to use it with the Belkin app. It would be much better if it worked with the native iPhone camera functionality.Bottom line, it isn't a game changer and will most likely get left at home.

    Rating: 2

    2012-02-16: I am not wowed by this. The grip does make it easier to hold, but I am not likely to carry it around. Let's face it, The iPhone takes good video for a phone, but it's not a video camera. I would be hard pressed to make this a must bring to any event. There are many free or inexpensive apps that make this not a good value. I think if it were not so expensive, I might recommend it more. You are really paying (in my opinion) for the grip.

    Rating: 3

    2012-02-23: This Belkin grip is a great idea for hardware, but is limited by its requirement for use with Belkin's propriety software.The hardware, the grip itself, is great. It's got a grippy rubberized feel, easy to use photo and video buttons, and a tripod socket. It fits perfectly on an iPhone 4/4S without a case, and very well on iPhones with cases because of its cleverly designed flexible clasps. I found that my iPhone4S with a Switcheasy brand case was slightly loose in the Belkin LiveAction Grip, but it still held it and I had no fears of it coming loose.The required app (free) that runs with the Belkin LiveAction grip however is less than impressive. I've had it crash once or twice, and freeze up once as well. Photos and videos taken with this app do not go directly to the iPhone photo library, but require a few extra steps (not entirely intuitive) to get them there. It's therefore a real shame that Belkin has hobbled a nice piece of hardware with its buggy and proprietary software. It would be much better if Belkin allowed this Grip to interface directly with the iPhone's fine photo and video app. If that happens I'll probably use this Belkin Grip a lot more.Until then, it's just as easy and more convenient for me to use my iPhone and the photo/video capabilities it already has. My iPhone case is almost as good a "grip" as the Belkin Live/Action Grip itself. Given the opportunity to use the Belkin Grip directly with Apples software however I would gladly use the Grip more.

    Rating: 3

    2012-02-06: This is a pretty cool little add-on for the iphone 4. I do not have to take my case off and it just clicks into the charge port on my iphone. I can now take pictures or videos with a push of the button on top, just like a camera would have. You can use the flash or flip the camera around for self-photos also, no more fumbling around trying to find the little camera button on the touch screen. I can see my self using this for vacation or gatherings where I will be taking a lot of pictures. Makes the Iphone easy to hold and use. The price is a little steep (hence the 4 stars) but it is actually something that will be handy to have in my purse for when I want to take some pictures. Also another downside is that you have to use their app when taking picures, but you can download those pictures to your camera roll.

    Rating: 4

    2012-02-16: The iPhone 4s has a spectacular camera and this grip allows for better handling of the phone thereby giving you better pictures.The way it works: plug the grip into your dock connector, launch the Belkin LiveAction app (yes you need a app which is free in the app store), and take still images with a regularly sized black button or video with a smaller recessed red button. Simple. Once the pictures are taken they are stored in the app's memory...you can facebook them, email them, and or save them to the Camera Roll on the iPhone. Perfect.If I had to have a gripe...it would be simply that the dock connector will only work without a case on your iPhone. I naturally use a case as do most others and that may cause a problem....the case generally sticks out a bit and this would not fit perfectly. I also wish the software automatically saved everything to the camera roll on the phone...perhaps they will include the option in a future update.What I like is the fact that I can pop this on to my iphone, launch the app, and take amazing pictures with a little more stability then I had with the phone alone. The grip is quite comfortable. I also like the fact that I can click the smaller red (recessed) button and start taking video immediately.It is an awesome product which enhances the picture taking experience on the iPHone 4s. HIGHLY recommended.5/5

    Rating: 5

    2012-02-15: The Belkin Live Action Camera Grip is a device that makes it physically easier to use your iPhone or iPod as a camera, which I really like. It also uses a free, proprietary app, Belkin LiveAction, which I really don't like.The grip is one piece, and attaches firmly and securely with rubberized, spring-loaded side grips. Like many other i-devices, I cannot use it without removing my Otterbox Defender case from my iPhone 4S as that case is too large, but it does work with my iPod Touch in this case:Gummy Cover - Transparent Clear/Solid Black (S Shape) for Apple iPod Touch 4G. That is a plus because my 9 year old often uses my Touch and I am loathe to let him use it without any sort of protective case.There are 2 buttons which are conveniently placed. The large, slightly raised button operates the camera mode and it works wonderfully. Next to it is a small, red button that sits flush with the grip and operates video mode. People have mentioned it being too small but I like it. That way I don't accidentally activate video when I am trying to take a pic. There is also a place to attach a tri-pod.The big problem is that this grip works exclusively with Belkin's LiveAction app, which is quite limited. As long as you are content to keep your videos on your iPhone or iPod, it's OK, but you won't be able to export them to YouTube. It also puts your pictures in a different folder - not the native Camera Roll. This limits the multi-media aspects of your Apple device and who wants that? I see this as a deal-breaker.I am pretty happy with this grip for when my young son is in a photo taking mood because his pictures and video are less blurry and shaky when using it. But at $50 and the issues with the app, I can't recommend it for general use.

    Rating: 2

    2012-09-13: I love the idea of a grip for the iPhone camera function. I take a lot of photos with my iPhone so I thought it would be helpful. The grip itself is great and fits over my snap-on case. (Huge plus for that!)But that's where my likes end...The app for the camera grip is horrible. The photos don't save to the camera roll on the iPhone. Also the quality of the photos appear to me to be diminished. I prefer my Camera+ app or even Instagram over the Belkin app. And for quality, I'm going to stick with the iPhone's built in camera.Overall...not worth it.

    Rating: 1

    2012-03-13: I love this grip for the iPhone. It makes handling the phone to take pictures much easier and fit around my silicon iPhone case with no problem. That's what I loved about this product. If I could use this grip without having to use the Belkin LiveAction Camera App it would be perfect, but alas, that's not the case. As soon as you plug the grip into the phone it automatically opens the app. I prefer the built in camera app or Instagram for taking photos. If I was tech savvy enough to find a way to disable the app and continue using the grip I would but so far I haven't found a way to do so.I'm giving this gadget 3 stars because the app isn't very good compared to other camera apps for the iPhone but the grip is very ergonomic and a huge improvement on just trying to hold the slender iPhone steady when taking a shot.

    Rating: 3

    2012-03-17: Yes this holder is made to grip and use your iphone to manipulate picture taking.It is functional and clean in design.I for one am not someone who will make this object a priority,as I am a more spontaneous type of character. Belkin also requires an app to pair with this device,and I am wary of the future of this pairing in our world of transient technology.It works and that is a plus,but necessary? Not for me.

    Rating: 3

    2012-02-06: One of the issues with the iPhone camera is that you have click on your iPhone screen while focusing on an object - not the most convenient.So, Belkin came out with this device which fits on your iPhone, so that you can hold your iPhone like a camera use the buttons on this device to click for pictures like like a hand held camera.But wait ! The recent ios 5 software upgrade on your iPhone just does that - once you have upgraded the operating on your iPhone - just launch the iPhone Camera App, click on the volume button on your iPhone (instead of clicking on the screen) to take pictures !! No need for any additional software or hardwareA couple of other points about this device:* Like all belkin products - it is very well done hardware : nicely crafted, built to last* As soon as you plug in the device, iPhone launches the App Store to download the free software which will be used along with this hardware* The pictures taken with this device/software does not get stored in the same folder/vault as the default iPhone app* fits over your iPhone case effortlessly* There are 2 buttons on the device - one for stills and one for videos- The button for video is very misleading: it looks like a button for flash on/offOverall - I would not buy this device given the fact that the ios 5 upgrades makes the iPhone usable just like a pocket camera. Belkin - if you are reading this - add an additional zoom lens & a flash and I would definitely buy it.

    Rating: 3

    2012-02-04: This is a pretty handy little accessory if you find yourself constantly taking pictures or video with your iPhone and having trouble holding the phone steady (particularly for video). The grip is small enough to not get in the way (and it expands to handle chunkier cases) but still gives you more of a handle to grasp your phone with. I found it much more helpful for video than photo.Installing the software is super easy - the first time you connect the device your phone automatically connects to the app store and downloads the app. The app is basically the same as the built-in iPhone camera app, except that you don't have to choose video or camera, you just press the appropriate button (there's a camera button and a video button, which is convenient). A big drawback to me is that the videos/images you capture in this app don't automatically populate into the regular folder. You can export them there but that's an additional step that shouldn't be necessary.This device has a spot to screw into a tripod but I haven't tried it with a tripod.

    Rating: 3

Also, note that 3-conductor is for stereo headsets. 4-conductor is what you will need if using as a phone headset/microphone.

    2014-06-02: My old iPhone car charger broke and I needed a new one. I saw this PowerBolt Duo and I like the fact that it will charge our iPhones, iPods, and our iPad 2. You can use it on your iPhone and iPad at the same time.I like the fact that the device has an LED that indicates that it is getting power and that it is low profile so it doesn't take up a lot of space and it is not easy to bump. I also like that charger cable that goes to your Apple device has a standard USB connector on the end that plugs into the car charger plug. This means that you can use the cable that came with your Apple device if you need to. The charger is so "low profile" that once it is plugged in to the car charger socket, it is difficult to unplug. It is literally almost flush with the top of the charger socket in my vehicle. You can barely get a finger nail on it to slowly pry it out. Overall I like the charger and it serves a multipurpose function for many of our Apple toys.

    2013-01-27: Finally, an ipad charger that works. I have tried numerous ones that all started to charge, but failed after a few minutes. This one charges, all the way.

    Rating: 5

    2012-01-28: A quick summary of this product before I get into the details:Likely great for dedicated Apple device users that has all the power it claims (simultaneously 2.1 Amps on one port with 1 Amp on the other for a total of 3.1 Amps output combined, but under performs DRAMATICALLY for non-Apple devices due to protocol issues for USB chargers. It gets 3-stars because all it claims to support is Apple devices.Now for more details...A little background on USB charging for those who don't know:The USB power spec is for 0.5 Amps at 5 Volts... or 2.5 Watts. This was great up until the last couple years when devices have gotten really power hungry, particularly smartphones and tablets and to a lesser extent dedicated GPS's. Some of these devices use over 2 Amps, particularly the tablets like the iPad (or in my case the HP Touchpad).Manufacturers of these devices therefore had a dilemma. If they had their devices pull more than 0.5 Amps, they risked damaging the power source, which could be a computer, that was only prepared to source 0.5 Amps. Thus the manufacturers have used tricks to determine whether their device is connected to an unknown source, at which point they purposely only draw 0.5 Amps, or to the dedicated charger that was provided with the device, where they can draw all the power they need.There seem to be two common tricks used. The first is to short the two data-wires together in the charger. This is what most non-Apple devices do. Since a computer or older device wouldn't have done this, the device can assume it is safe to draw all the power it needs.Apple seems to have taken a different approach, one that I don't fully understand but know can be seen by the fact that the data lines are neither open nor shorted when the charger is plugged in, and is more sophisticated and probably superior, because I suspect it allows the device to know exactly how much power it can use.While Apple taking a better approach might be nice in concept, it's created chaos in the USB charger product category. What is the non-specific charger to do? They can't support both.Kensington chose to go the Apple route for the 2.1 Amp port. I don't own any high-power Apple devices, so I can't say for sure, but I suspect this unit performs well with Apple devices. Using electronic equipment I was able to draw 2.1 Amps when putting a fixed load on this USB charging port. However, when I connect any of the 3 high-power devices I have (HP Touchpad (2 Amps), Motorola Triumph Android phone (0.85 Amps) and the LG Optimus Slider (0.7 Amps)), none of them drew all the current they could have, because they were expecting a shorted set of data-lines.The 1 Amp port on this device is a bit of a quandry however. It didn't have the signature on the data lines of either the Apple protocol or the shorted lines. It appeared to have them open... which was a surprise and I believe a mistake (although I can't be certain with Apple products). The results for my 3 devices however were identical to that of the 2.1 Amp port.To highlight the positives, I can say this, I was able to draw all the power the product claims it can source using fixed loads. As my above explanation makes clear, it is the DEVICE, not the charger, that chooses not to make full use of the available current (Amps). So by using power resistors I could test the actual capacity of the device without dealing with the data-line issue.As such, I was able to draw both 2.1 Amps from one port and 1 Amp from the other, simultaneously. I can not say the same for the other charger I have tried (and I have two in shipment to test).Thus this device gets 3 stars because it only claims to support Apple devices and without any to test I have to assume it would work great for them. It also can deliver the current it claims. It is likely a 5-star product for sole apple users.However, for non-Apple users, I STRONGLY encourage you to look elsewhere for your Car USB power needs. The other device I've tried is the "PowerGen Dual USB 2A Heavy Duty Ouput Car Charger" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00622AG6S/ref=oh_o05_s00_i00_details). It has other problems (the 2A port doesn't have the data lines shorted and it only sources a TOTAL of 2A, not 2A on one port and 1A on the other), but at least one port (the 1A, which can really do 2A by itself, see my review over there for more details on that) on that has the data lines shorted to get the full power with non-Apple devices.I've ordered two additional devices:- "Ultra Compact High Output Dual USB Car Charger - 2.1A Output" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00470C35E/ref=oh_o01_s00_i00_details)- "Bracketron Universal Dual USB Car Adapter (UGC-298-BL)" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0056VNVV8/ref=oh_o00_s00_i00_details)Hopefully one of the two of them will be able to deliver to their specs for my devices.

    Rating: 3

    2013-06-05: This broke after less than 1 month and only a few uses (I bought this one for my 2nd power outlet to charge the ipad when needed on trips). Of course, I missed the return window (I thought I hadn't plugged it in properly so that's why it wasn't working by the time I got around to checking to make sure it wasn't user error it was over a month) so now I'm stuck with a product that doesn't work. I tried to look on the Kensington website for info but there is no email so I guess I'll have to call them to see if maybe they will exchange it. It was great the few times we were able to use it. My husband bought some cheap chinese knock off for his car for a few bucks and it works great. I also have a Motorola charger that works well but doesn't have the juice to power an ipad. Maybe I just got a dud as I had another one of these and it lasted at least 6+ months.

    Rating: 1

    2012-12-31: have had for about a month and still works fine. nice to have when there are sevral devices in one vehicle.

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-18: I am using it to charge either two android micro usb, or mp3 and phone. Works great - word to the wise - if its a USB jack it will charge most anything.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 5

    2012-01-26: I have multiple devices that need to be charged while I work on the road. This includes my personal Motorola Droid X2, an iPhone provided by my company, and iPads brought aboard by co-workers. This is good, considering how much the vehicles I am vibrate and get jostled on the road.     2012-04-09: I had high hopes for this charger. I needed a dual car charger for my iPhone 4 plus my Jawbone headset. The included Apple connector (cable) did NOT fit my iPhone 4 (but fit my 1st gen iPad - however I don't take this in the car!) The only option was to use my phone's USB charge cord (that plugs into the house outlet) but that defeats the purpose of having the convenience of two chargers, not to mention carting the cord back and forth between car and home.Oh yes, I COULD just purchase an extra cord on Amazon, but the price of this dual unit doesn't justify having to pay even more money to get it to work.

    Rating: 2

    2012-01-03: I bought this because I travel quite a bit and have always charged my phone or ipad before leaving but even still I had to watch the battery levels when using my stuff for gps or information. The charger works excellently. The 2.1 amp charger works quickly for the phone. On a couple of occasions I charged my phone for 10 minutes and it charged from 47% to 63% and 52% and 72%. My iPad charged completely in about a 4 hour drive which is very comparable to what it would take while plugged into the wall. I charged two things at once a couple of times and didn't see a big reduction in the ability of the charger to charge my iphone or ipad. This is a great product.

    Rating: 5

    2013-09-26: It was exactly what I was looking for and it was cheap so that was even better. I can charge my phone in my car and my iPod at the same time. I love it!

    Rating: 5

    2012-01-13: Excellent charger with no stupid error messages. Seems to be well made. I like having the extra USB port so I can charge my bluetooth headset.<EDIT>I bought a second charger December 2012. The first one stopped working after about eight months. Okay, I figured that was a fluke. I just bought another one, and it stopped charging after about three weeks. When I plug in my iPhone, nothing happens. (Yes, it's in the correct port.) If I remove the USB connector from the cigarette lighter and move it over to the other port and then BACK to the first port, it will start charging again. Bizarre.The only thing that keeps me from rating this as a one star product is the the $10 price. If it were $25, I'd rate it one star.

    Rating: 2

    2014-04-20: The cable suddenly stopped working! I liked the cord because it was thicker than the original Apple cable (mine came with some added "gray" colored reinforcements around the joints) and I was aware that you'd need MFI certified cables to charge iPhones with updated iOS. It worked wonderfully up until 2 weeks ago and nothing. Not even a warning message on the phone. Connecting it to the computer with my iPod nano did nothing either. The cable simply won't register as a USB cable.

    Rating: 1

    2013-03-10: If you have two iPhones, this is perfect for charging two iPhones while out traveling for the day. It fits very snug, so if you have a recessed cigarette lighter port it can be hard to get out of the socket. But since we are not smokers, we just leave it plugged in all the time. I'm tempted to buy another for our second vehicle.

    Rating: 5

    2012-08-08: A well constructed dual USB adapter; compact yet not too small and flush against the surface that it's tough to pull out of a DC outlet.This is a great product and I merely only mention this one comment as more of an easy "wish-list" item that I hope Kensington takes into consideration for future iterations:This adapter could benefit by also marking the sides of the charger identifying which port is the 2.1 and 1 amp. Don't get me wrong it IS clearly marked on the front face but if you are an avid traveler renting various types of cars you'll know that some of the DC adapter outlets are located inside armrest consoles, tucked in the lowest parts of the center consoles in the front or back seating areas depending upon make/model/year of the car. These outlets can obscure the front face and it makes it hard to see which port is the 2.1 and 1 amp, especially at night. I use the 3 vent holes on the one side to establish the orientation and mentally remember that that is the side of the 1 amp port. If you want a better visual reference you could always do it yourself by marking one of the sides with a bright sticker, nail polish, etc.

    Rating: 4

    2012-12-16: This unit has been great. can charge two units together which is great for car trips with my wife, can charge both of our iphones together. very dependable and have had no problems in many months of usage.

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-24: I know Amazon prices fluctuate far more rapidly and widely than other online retailers. but the tale of this charger is whackier than most:On December 7, 2012, I see this for $9.99 here on Amazon and order TWO. It's a no brainer! Kensington at "no-name" pricing, dual power slots at "single slot" pricing, 10 watts at 5 watt pricing. It's sold direct by Amazon, not by a 3rd party vendor closing out on over-stock.Did I mention it came with an original style cable, which seems sturdier than the Apple which is prone to fraying at the juncture with the connectors themselves?So I dutifully come back here on December 24, 2012, to review it, and suddenly it is $24.96! Not a buck or two more expensive, almost THREE TIMES as expensive.Now at $9.99, that's a cheap price for a name-brand cable, let alone for a dual slot power supply, with one of them delivering the full 10 watts preferred by the old iPad 3. But at $24.96 the decision is much tougher - go with this one, or with a no-name for half the price? Do I really need an extra cable (at this higher price), or would a no-name without a cable be ok? What about a no-name that is reviewed as being able to deliver 10 watts but only if the other slot is unused? What about a no-name that can only deliver 5 watts, enough for my phone but not for an iPad? See, I got the first class, feature-rich charger, WITH cable, for a stripped, generic device price. Yay! But - why the pricing difference? Is it still worth it?See, products don't have "absolute" value. They have value relative to their price.The new model of online pricing - varying prices daily, or even hourly - is making it really hard to shop.This isn't limited to Amazon, the NY Times did an article this holiday season about how Target, Best Buy, and WalMart, among others, varied prices day by day this holiday season, post-Black Friday, to match or beat their competition, and which store had the most consistently low prices - which wasn't consistent across all products. I just read an article that another retailer, Staples, even delivers different online pricing depending on your zip code and nearness to one of their identified competitors, like Office Depot.So this review is a little different from my other product reviews, and different from the other product reviews of this particular product.For the best insights on performance of this product, read the two top-rated reviews here - I believe those two are honest, objective, and insightful. The only thing I would add, is that I have three Apple cables that are frayed at the junction with the actual connector - the flex portion wasn't well-designed. From the looks of it, the flex portion on the Kensington cable is longer and thicker - which should extend the cable life at this critical juncture where more stresses occur. The first top rated reviewer has actually used this for over two years and reports that, yes, the Kensington included cable does last longer, so that is a nice bonus. Secondly, and don't laugh, now that Apple has released the new Lightning Connector, I like the fact that Kensington departed from "Apple white" to make their connector in black - why? - because it's a lot quicker to grab the right device cable when black means old style and white means Lightning. Yes, this comes up, since I have devices with both styles of connectors and travel with both. It's just one less thing to be annoyed by, when trying to charge them.In terms of pricing strategies, good grief, stay on your toes! Amazon USUALLY has very competitive prices, if not the best, but now more than ever it pays to comparison shop, even to open an "Incognito" browser tabe in Chrome to see if searching cookie-free returns different pricing. Above all, comparison shop, and if you don't like the prices today, bide your time, and post buying, monitor the prices for the first month so you can ask for a price adjustment if things get out of whack.

    Rating: 5

    2011-12-27: This thing is perfect. Not only can you charge an iPad at full power with the thing, but the secondary port outputs 1A which will charge your phone faster than usual. In some cases the typical 0.5A charger (which might not even be outputting a full 0.5A) can't even supply enough power to my phone to both satisfy its power consumption and charge the battery if the phone is running the GPS, playing music, doing bluetooth, keeping the screen on, and other stuff that causes it to consume lots of energy.While this thing is more expensive than the cheapo adapters out there, it's well worth the cost. Having your devices too low on power when you get out of the car is really not fun, especially when they're drained before you can even make it back to the car. Two high power USB ports in one cigar outlet is a major advantage because most people don't have more than one or maybe two cigar outlets in their car. Even if you don't normally need two USB power ports, trust me... you will be happy you have the extra one day when you do need to plug something else in. And eventually you will.Buy a cheap adapter for $5 or something and one day the extra $15 you should have spent will feel like nothing when your battery is dead in some critical situation.

    Rating: 5

My Explorer is a 2000 so I know that may be an issue but I find it ridiculous that so many chargers don't work at all. This one works great & is a rapid charger. In less than 15 mins I had nearly a full charge :) Yay!

The IPhone port will take longer to charge, whereas the IPad port will charge considerably faster but may cause wear on your battery with extended use. I still use mine, it's cheap and useful in those trips where both me and my buddy want to charge our devices. Kensington is a good brand for mobile accessories.

  • B00BL5FBFW

    $B00BL5FBFW

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-10-25: I LOVE the feeling of the the phone without a screen protector, but always have to sacrifice screen scratching. These screen protectors fix that, still get the great feeling on the screen but also protects it from scratches. I recommend these screen protectors.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-30: I agonized and analyzed for weeks about what kind of protection to get for my new iPhone 5s before my upgrade date arrived. I'd never heard of this company before but was really impressed with what I read about their products. I mean, a GLASS screen protector?? How cool would that be? I always like to have unique stuff for my phone. Arrived quickly I will admit, but the instructions for installation are slim to none. I washed my hands, cleaned the table, cleaned the phone screen and placed the protector on the phone. I figured application of this was the same as the flimsy plastic screen protectors I've always had. The center attached well, but I had a long air pocket on the very edges of both sides. I tried to smooth them out with the plastic card they supplied, but it was too much. I now have a nasty chip on the right edge of the protector which slowly but surely spread into a nice crack running down to the left bottom corner. So frustrated! So now that I'm considering another one (I must be crazy) in perhaps a thicker model, I saw a video about the protector. I assumed before it was a sales pitch and hadn't watched it. In the first 5 seconds of the video it quickly shows a protector being placed on a phone and SIMPLY USING ONE FINGER to touch the middle of the protector to begin the attachment process. Well hello!!!! It would have been really super great if they had included that in the instructions. Now mine is ruined and I'm sure it's only a matter of time before the crack turns into a break. I'm sure the product is good even though I've had it installed for a few hours. The look is awesome, keeps the screen beautifully bright and you really cannot tell it even has a protector on it. The 2 stars is for lack of information to the consumer on proper installation in the packaging.

    Rating: 2

    2013-10-21: I've recently looked into tempered glass protectors. I first tried iloome's flexible glass. For it's price if you're looking for a very thin tempered glass screen shield I highly recommend it. But it was kind of difficult to install like any protector, and I don't know if it was just my protector but it always had fingerprints and picked up oils quickly.I decided to change it and go with the Glas.tR. Packaging wise, its great. Comes in a nice casing that can be used to store extra shields and such. For the price I paid of $21, it was a good deal, 1 glass shield, a back protector, alocohol pad for cleaning oil off the screen prior install, 6 mini gel home buttons (for the iPhone 5 and below) and a mini micro fiber wipe.To pull off the "perfect" install I ran the shower in hot water to steam the bathroom to allow dust and hair to fall due to moisture. This actually HELPED a lot. There was no dust, hair, or lint after wiping down the phone. I suggest when you pull off the adhesive of the protector have it faced down just in case if any dust or hair fall on the adhesive side. I slowly aligned the protector and laid it on the phone lightly. From here I used my nail to push and align it. Once I aligned it perfectly I applied pressure in the center and it applied on by itself. I used my thumb to push out any bubbles. I started to get tiny bubbles on the corners and it wasn't dust but after 10 minutes or so I pushed them out. But as the instructions mention, tiny bubbles would take a a few hrs or a day to go away.Overall great product! Hardly any fingerprints catch on and if any they are easy to wipe off. The protector feels like glass and imo better than the actually phone. The curved edges seem to be case friendly. It worked with my Speck pixel HD, but I am currently using spigens Neo Hybrid in champagne.This product is a go!

    Rating: 5

    2014-02-14: i love this screen protector. you can't even tell that it is on the phone. it's so thin and lite. they even made one for the back. now they need to make these for the galaxy note 10.1 2014 edition as well...

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-08: The feel of glass on the screen is great. It does not dampen the sensitivity or cause you to use more force. You must be careful with the initial placement as it is very difficult to take it off and reapply it if you get it wrong. It is subject to chips if you put too much force on the edges when applying. These are not negatives as I really like the product, just some cautions on application.

    Rating: 5

    2014-07-09: I've had a spigen glass screen protector on my phone now for the past 8 months with no problems, however when I ordered this product it came broken. Unfortunately I had to send it back and decided on a different brand.

    Rating: 2

    2014-03-21: After using my first Spigen glass screen protector, I haven't gone back to plastic ones. This is my second one and overall, the best protection and value. To put things in perspective, I would compare to it it's plastic counterparts.Pros:Better overall protection from impactsSuperior visually to the screen. Plastics tend to create strange reflectionsSuperior feel. Since it's made of glass, it's a true screen feelNo scratches. Protector is far more resistant to scratches than plastics. I have yet to have one on two different iPhones.Better value and hassle: One glass protector will outlast 10 plastic screen protectors. Less work to replace bc of this.Cons:As will all screen protectors, you need to understand how best to install them to avoid dust and particles from getting between the phone screen and the screen protector. Glass or plastics have yet to master these. The good thing is, these are slightly easier to install IMO, but still a pill, therefore resulting in a "con".Because this is glass, it may affect different cases. As an example, this does not affect any open-faced case. That being said, the thickness seems to affect my waterproof case. The thickness seems to affect it's snug fit. If you don't plan on wrapping your whole iPhone in a waterproof case, you should be fine.Overall, this is a wonderful product if you can get past the installation process. This still gets 5-stars, because all these products suffer from this. Skip the cheaper plastic screen protectors and upgrade to the glass. You won't regret it.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-22: This screen protector is amazing. It's so clear and just as responsive on the phone as it was before.My only gripe would be how you can only apply this cover on once, so application is a bit stressful to get it just right. In order to take off the cover, you'd have to break it completely since its shatter-proof tempered glass rather than a thin film material.Overall very satisfied so far.

    Rating: 5

    2014-03-25: The Good:I really do love the feel of this screen protector. It's feels wonderful to swipe. Fingerprints aren't eliminated completely but it does very well at not showing them. When a smudge becomes noticeable a quick swipe on my shirt sleeve or pant leg and its gone.The Bad:Installation is a "one shot" deal. Make sure that your phone is perfectly clean (and your hands too). I think Spigen will send you a discounted replacement if you foul up installation too badly. (see their web site for details)One minute speck of dust during installation and the bubble has never fully gone away. I opted to live with it as the feel more that makes up for it. The fact that it's down by the home button rather than in a more view area of the screen probably helps too.The Ugly:I quickly saw what many people mention ... fragile sides ... mine got a small chip and nearly invisible crack after only a few days after I installed it. not drops or anything just going in and out of my pant pocket. It may have had a problem sharing the pocket with my keys.

    Rating: 3

    Rating: 5

    2014-01-05: I purchased this item AFTER I dropped my iPhone 5 on the sidewalk while walking my dog. Because it's tempered glass you can crack it. I haven't any issues with it on once it's in place it's good to go!

    2013-10-08: Expensive, but worth the price in terms of clarity. A breeze to install.     2013-09-01: ~First I'd like to start off with I haven't actually put this on my phone yet due to expected launch of the New iPhone 5S this September, in which case I'm waiting to apply this to that phone when I pre-order it.~Product over view based on looking at everything included:Front protector looks greats with no scratches like mentioned in other reviews.Back protectors look like simple easy peel and stick protectors, no scratches here either.Gummy stickers for home button were fine besides the fact I was missing the pink one entirely in the whole box.genuine code came back genuine on there website.Card board wedge, clothe, manual, and alcohol wipe were all present and fine.~A tip for all when applying this for minimal dust (being its a one shot protector with no retries). In a small bathroom with all windows doors vents and so forth closed, turn the shower to the max heat and let it run until its very very steamy within the room. (This will force most dust to settle and therefor make it far easier to apply) I also have a suction cup on a ring for easier placement onto the screen and more precise.Good luck all!
