    Rating: 3

    2009-08-16: Original review, posted in August of this year-I bought this case for my iPhone 3G, and I am very pleased with it. The magnetic closure has not interfered with my iPhone in any way, and the belt loops make this holster very, very secure. The phone is easily removed when needed. I bought this to replace theDLO Leather Holster Case for iPhone 3G, 3G S (Black), when the belt clip began to become loose; if you want to make SURE that you never loose your iPhone because of a lost holster, the PC Microstore holster with belt clip AND belt loops is the way to go. I had the unfortunate experience of losing a Motorola Razr when another holster's belt clip slipped off my pocket; an honest person turned the phone in, but not before it had been stepped on and the glass front broken. Do you really want to risk losing your Iphone in such an accident? At the offering price, I feel that this iPhone case is one of the best deals available on all of Amazon's web site.Follow-up, December 2009-My wife recently upgraded to an iPhone, so I ordered two more of these cases, still at a great price. While they seemed very similar to the items I received in August, they are of MUCH poorer quality- the belt loops broke in a mere three weeks of usage. I have contacted pcmicrostore about a refund or replacement through Amazon, and I'm waiting for their response. The cases received in November have a small logo on the front, but the ones I received in August did not. I have resumed use of the case received in August, which is somewhat worn and with stretched belt loops that are nevertheless still intact. It seems as though pcmicrostore has changed suppliers, without bothering to let Amazon (or anyone else, for that matter) know that they had done so. I can no longer recommend this phone case because of its poor workmanship.

    Rating: 2

    2009-07-28: This iPhone case arrived better then the photos showed. Nice texture. I had no unususal odors and the magnetic latch works well.The only down side I see is that because of the shape of the iPhone is may be easy to drop the phone when removing it from the case. Removing the phone is easy but the iPhone has no texture to make grabbing it secure. I've not tried adding a skin to the iphone to see if this helps, the iPhone may not fit in the case with the skin attached.Bottom line- at $2.98 this is a steal & money well spent.BTW: keep credit cards and other things with magnetic ID strips on the back away from the magnetic latch or the information on the card will be lost.

    Rating: 5

    2009-06-13: This is a pretty good case, especially for the price. It does have some drawbacks though.I started with a DLO case for my iPhone.DLO Leather Holster Case for the iPhone 3G(Black)It was perfect: Thin (close to the body), access to the headphone port while the phone was in the case, and a big hole in the bottom to push the phone up out of the case. That turned out to be a big key in how much I liked the case. It was very easy to get the phone out with one hand. The only issue I had with the DLO was that it had velcro to close the case. I use my phone as my watch. So, it was distracting in meetings to hear that "rip" every time I wanted to check the time.So I tried this case. The magnetic closure works well and it's quite. It does have both a belt clip and belt loops--which added to the bulk and made the phone stick out more from my hip. The biggest drawback (and why I'm looking at yet another case) is the the flap is too big and the hole use to push up the phone is too small. So, it is difficult to get the phone out with one hand.

    Rating: 3

    2010-04-15: I must've lucked out and gotten two of these (a second one a few months after the first one was ordered) that looked like the original picture; tan on the inside and black leather on the outside. Two elasticized side-end panels allow for a good fit (although my second one was a bit snugger than the first).The second one fit the iPhone 2G (no skin) perfectly, but not a 3GS with a Thermo Plastic Urethane--too tight. The first case, although outwardly the same as the first, was a bit looser in fit that allowed the 3GS to fit with a TPU skin just snugly enough.So it appears that the supplier varies and it sometimes is the luck of the draw as to what you get and how well it fits. This is probably the only reason I would give it 4 instead of 5 stars--lack of quality control or a consistent supplier.

    2010-05-28: I ordered the horizontal leather iPhone case indicated here. The seller shipped extremely quickly - I think I had it within 3 days of ordering. It connects to the belt through either a clip or through built-in belt loops. If you're worried about losing the phone if you just use the clip, don't - it's so tight it's a pain in the a55 to remove it from the belt. I'm ordering a couple of different configurations just to test out my options, but I could see coming back to this one.

    2008-10-20: I don't know the final verdict on whether or not magnets affect the iphone. Some people seem to think they do, some don't. I noticed none of the cases on the Apple website have magnets. But what I couldn't find, was a belt clip case that would fit a phone with a skin on it, except for this one. I didn't want to spend $50 on a case from the Apple website to find out it wouldn't work. Of course I had already ordered this case when I found out about the magnet conspiracy.So for $7 with shipping, I decided to give this a try. But I didn't want to fry my phone with a $7 case. So I cut the magnets out and bought some 3M Velcro stickers with "permanent" adhesive. I put the velcro over the spots where the magnets were. So far they work great. I imagine they will need replacing over time.I have an iFrogz case on my phone, and it fits in this case just fine. Snug but not too snug.     $B0078JFQ6Y

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-11-17: Great sound, and comfortable while cycling. I haven't had a chance to use microphone while cycling, but it works well normally.

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-02: While it was not an expensive set it does well for me when I jog and bicycle. It could use a little more bass, but like I said it's not expensive.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-05: A great value for these headphones. They don't have to be inside your ear fully and with the over the ear clip, they stay put while you are out and about. The sound is great and the wired remote works to pause or skip to next song and also answer your incoming call. ** Note.. for remote to work .. you have to turn screen lock to "off". It is a pleasure to take the T and walk around Boston while listening to my music without constantly adjusting my earphones. These are agreat value.

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-15: I bought these to replace myMotorola SF200 Sports Headphones. They perform the same functions, and I will use this review as a comparison between the two.Pros:Have an adjustable ear clip to accomodate those with "longer" ears. This is not necessarily an issue for me.The in-ear speakers are not silicone "buds" that you shove into your ear. They are plastic and they are meant to sit outside the ear. I think that because of this they draw more power from the mp3 player and are much louder than the SF200s. Although they are not as comfortable as the silicone buds, they don't pop out of place like the buds do.The microphone/button function the same as the SF200s, with a single button for call answer/pause (1-click), and next/previous track (2-click, 3-click).The microphone picks up audio very well.Cons:The headphones are made of cheap flimsy plastic. This must be where the $7 difference is between this product and the SF200s. I don't know how long they'll last. I've had the SF200s for a year now and have been through many many hours sweat and rain. I don't know if the JVCs will hold up as long, but we'll see.The 3.5mm jack is straight, as opposed to angled. Thus, it sticks out of players much farther than an angled chack, such as that of the SF200. This isn't "bad" in any way, but if I were ever pressed for space near a headphone jack, these most likely won't fit.If you were to ask me if I would prefer the SF200s or the JVCs, I'm not sure which I would choose. Probably the JVCs since they are $7 cheaper, and I really did not like the fit of the SF200s in my ear - the silicone would always come loose and pop out while I was running. Furthermore, fresh ear wax would build up inside of the buds, and the JVCs don't have that problem. However, the SF200s are entirelly cased in flexible silicone/rubber material (even the wire), so there is no worry of something cracking or breaking. I only replaced them because they got a little too wet one day and the button signal would send to the player at random times, pausing my music or skipping to the next/previous track uncontrollably. If the SF200s would switch from the silicone earbuds towards the plasic ones that won't pop out, then I would definitely switch back.

    Rating: 4

    2013-11-15: These headphones are surprisingly comfortable, the sound is perfectly decent, they stay in *really* well when I'm working out, and the cord doesn't tangle nearly as much as with other small headphones. The remote is near the ear, making it easy to find, and well-positioned for when I use the microphone. I find that a pair lasts about a year of hard use, and I always keep an extra pair ready in case my active set dies or I lose it.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-10: Very nice headphones, quality and finish on the ear design was very nicely done. doesn't look like a cheap product. My wife has small ears, and this is working fine for her. shipping was fast via prime of course, product arrived in great shape.

    Rating: 5

    $B008THTP3O

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-03-25: The reveiws that said that you can barely see the screen are lying. You can see it perfectly in any light. It fit great and went on smooth. no complaints.

    Rating: 5

    2013-09-17: The protective film works as advertised, and takes a bit of abuse in the pocket without scratching. The mirror part is a bit gimmicky. It makes the screen very difficult to read in sunlight and doesn't do much to enhance your privacy. Others CAN see the screen.     Rating: 3

    2014-06-30: Like the privacy of it but when the sun is out ended up blinding myself or others more than anything else.

    Rating: 5

    2013-05-06: I am not as impressed as I thought I would be. I am still getting scratches and fingerprints. I was hoping that would have been taken care of. I still like the fact that I do not have to use to mirror as longas I have it.

    Rating: 4

    2013-08-19: The mirror effect when the phone is asleep or off is a bit dark but does work as a mirror. Most importantly though, with this film, you CANNOT see the screen in sunlight. It is nearly impossible to use the phone outdoors on a bright day. I have kept the film on for the time being because I do enjoy that it somehow makes colors on the screen brighter while using the phone indoors.

    Rating: 4

    2013-03-30: I love the privacy that the Tech Armor brings to my iPhone, now me and only me can watch my texts in private

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-01: These screen protectors are so-so. The price is low so I can't really be mad, but they advertise "anti-scratch layer" of film on this screen protector. Well, the mirror part does work quite well. With the screen off you can see yourself (and what's behind you) when you're out in public. Catch people spying on you? Trying to evade the police? These will help. HOWEVER, like I said about the "anti-scratch layer"---- my screen protector has a million little nicks and scratches all OVER the thing. I thought this thing was supposed to be scratch-proof/resistant? Hardly. Protector fits screen perfectly, that's a plus. It took me a couple tries to line up the thing before I got it just right. I was very happy with it for the first couple weeks I had it but then I started to notice all these little scratches showing up. Just about anything will leave a scratch on the protector- but nothing so far has gone thru and scratched my actual screen of my iPhone. I've had better protectors that were non-mirror & the kind of rubbery feeling sort of material that is more "scratch resistant" than this material. I gave this product a 3 because its cheap, mirror works good, perfect fit for iPhone 5, but they scratch really easily. I guess that's why they give you 3 in a pack because the life span of the protector is short- unless you like looking at your screen thru a million scratches.

    Rating: 3

    2013-01-05: I don't know what the other reviewer that gave it one-star, but I found this mirror protector to be the best one. I used another competitor mirror protector, and the edges would start to peel a few hours after application.The tech armor stuff does not do this, it does not have a brownish tint, it's mirror, and the color out of the screen through the mirror finish is not distorted. The competitor mirror protector gave my iphone a greenish tint on the screen when it was on, this one did not (just check the white and black color when you turn on your retina display).I hate it when people use this and don't know what they are talking about, this is my last and final screen protector, I went through four different ones since I got my iphone 5 two months ago. This is by far the best and most reliable one.Remember, when you buy other brands, the reason why the edges peel is because, the screen protector is stretching and deforming, therefore, unable to keep flat, so when you apply it on your screen the edges flare. This screen protector is just thick enough that it did not deform when you peel back the protective film before applying, and not too thick that it makes the screen look like it has a layer over it...

    Rating: 5

    2012-05-19: Not sure if it is real leather or not,but it looks good!!!!Finishing is top notch.This case is basically a snap on hard plastic case (which completely covers the phone's sides, but not so the top and bottom) wrapped with a leather like material on the outside. A screen flap is stitched to the leather covered plastic case.This cover's weak point, is the exposed top and bottom parts, but, if protection and a professional or elegant look is the goal, this cover will deliver. For field, or active work, I would prefer an all around sides cover.This case uses two magnet strips to keep the flap securely closed: one in the flap, the other on the tab. I tested the magnet in the flap and found its magnetic "field" or "force" is stronger on the upper side, away from the phone than on the lower side, into the phone. On the lower part of the flap, the magnetic force is very weak almost imperceptible!!!Given its price, this cover is a bargain!!!

    2013-01-30: Have two sets of these, one in black and this white model. Seem the same to me, but the white version is more water resistant. For as far as 40 feet or so from my phone I have still been able to listen to podcasts, etc. The phone quality is certainly acceptable. They do seem to create a wind tunnel sound for the other side if I am driving with the A/C on. Magnify background noise a bit, but all in all, most people tell me I sound clear with these. They sync quickly with all 5 of my bluetooth devices. Have been very robust after 6 months of constant use. Did have them stop working one time and I just held a few buttons down and they "rebooted" and worked fine.The battery rating is completely legit. I can get a solid 10 hours of use out of these no problem.I wear them for my weight lifting workouts and have jogged with them, but the ring or necklace portion - not the ear buds, will bounce unless there is some way to hold them down. Kind of annoying but still workable. Occasionally the buds will pop out of my ears. Rather have that then the type that squish my head in and do not have good range.The sound is good enough for me to hear nuanced foreign languages, and music sounds good - not super rich or filled with highs or lows, but good enough to enjoy.These are an extremely clever addition to blue tooth headphone technology and LG knocked the design and execution out of the ballpark.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 1

    2012-09-09: I, as many of the reviewers, have used many different Bluetooth headsets over the years. I have always used them as a hands-free device to connect to my phone. I thought that I would try this headset in order to get both Bluetooth stereo for music and remote voice connections with my smartphone which I use both as an MP3 player and, of course, a phone.Music sounded very good on this headset--as good as a pair of $12.00 ear buds that I usually use for this purpose. However, when using it as a head set, it was only fair. Callers sounded as if they were in a cave (I could hear a slight echo). In addition, due to the ear bud, sound was sealed off; that is, ambient noise in the environment was reduced considerably. T^his was a positive feature for music, but I felt it was a negative for a head set.The ergonomics were not great: although the neck band stays firmly in place, the earbuds which are attached with thin wires, tended to get caught on seat belts, etc,. and got pulled out of my ears occasionally.Bottom Line: Four stars as a Bluetooth stereo earphone device, but only two as a hands-free head set. If you want to use it primarily to listen to music via a wireless connection, its a good product.

    Rating: 3

    2012-01-12: Got this for Christmas, and it's great. The only BT headset I've found that works with a motorcycle helmet. Since the controls are around the collar, I can still change songs or volume (unless I'm wearing gloves, but that's not the device's fault).Good sound on the phone. It's SO helpful in a noisy environment to have the caller's voice in both ears. People say I sound great from their end (much better than using the phone's microphone).Good music sound, too. Well, at least as good as it could sound considering the compression of .mp3 compounded by the compression of bluetooth. Hi-fidelity it ain't, but I wasn't expecting it to sound like a really nice pair of wired headphones patched into my home stereo.Works well with all media on the phone, except that my ringtones don't come through. It just beeps its standard beep. But I haven't found a headset that actually plays my ringtones yet, so I don't knock off a star for that.However, I do almost knock it down to 4 stars since I can't find a way to turn off the flashing blue light that says it's paired with a phone. The manual doesn't mention it and the internet hasn't been helpful either. I'm thinking that LG overlooked that option. My Motorola earpieces have all had the choice, and I really miss it. I don't want to be noticed for the silly blue light that everyone can see but me. And the orange tips are really lame. As with the silly blue light, I have no use for the gaily colored ends. Once I was sure about keeping them, I colored them with a black marker.All in all, I'd give them 4.5 stars.

    2013-02-21: I was yanking out my smartphone from my pocket whenever the headset cord would catch on something. Although I have a pretty good case for the phone, it was a matter of time before something bad was going to happen. Also, it was my third wired headset from line breakage near the plug. So I did a lot of research and decided to try the LG HBS 700. I mainly listen to podcasts and some music but still wanted to retain the ability to use the phone. This unit met all those needs. The bluetooth pairing is fast and simple. The earbuds are comfortable, the controls are easy to feel and use (one you know what all the buttons do). and I hardly notice any weight around my neck. I've had this for a month and have had no issues with it. My only concern at this point is durability. For now, I give it 5 stars.

    Rating: 5

    2012-05-13: I bought a pair of these headphones for use in my walking and jogging exercise routines. I use them with an iPhone 4s. Mine seem to skip out the audio a fair amount. I suspect this may have something to do with GPS. That's what comes to mind anyway. I don't really know why they drop audio. I could try them with GPS off and see what happens just to see.Aside from the above, I'm someone who buys the Apple headphones with the play/pause forward/backward mic on the cable so I can skips songs, talk to Siri or make/receive a call. However, when you constantly jog or do intense cycling with the Apple ear-buds it seems to me that a little sweat on those headphones kills the controls. They just flat out stop working. I can say that I order them from Amazon a lot. I tend to buy 4 replacement headphones at a time, which gets expensive. I carry an extra pair in my laptop bag. I have a few extra pairs at the office and home. Just yesterday another pair died on me.So anyway... my thinking is to go wireless. If I sweat on these there is nowhere for it to go really. When you see the image of these you'll understand. Today I did 2 miles run and then a 1,500 foot incline over 3 miles. Get my heart rate as high as 163. Having the right music keeps me going. Any the last thing I want is something that feels awkward and takes me out of my oneness with the road, the wind and my workout. These headphones are almost invisible to my attention. The collar goes pretty much unnoticed. And the cables going from the collar to the ear buds are long enough that you can twist your head in any direction without ever feeling a wire touch your neck.Back to Apple's ear buds for a second. One of the biggest problems with ear buds, is that as you jog your arms sway in and out building momentum for your body. Wired ear bud cables can sometimes get yanked right out of your ear when the cable gets in the path of a swaying fist. And this of course isn't a pleasant feeling. It happens at home too. Once in a while I pass an open door and find my ear yanked hard because the cord of a head phone gets caught on the passing doorknob.Don't like the seemingly random cutting out, but I'll take that over corded headphones. Maybe someone should make WiFI sport headphones for joggers. It was actually pretty difficult to find a pair of headphones that looked like they'd be suitable for jogging. So far these seem the most suitable.Update 8-11-2012I have changed from the iPhone 4s to the Samsung Galaxy SIII. And guess what... The headphones don't cut out anymore. Well, as long as I leave the phone in an arm holster, the signal is strong. I find that if I put the phone in my back pocket, then the headphones cut out. And standing close to a microwave oven also causes drop outs.I'm now using these headphones for running, the trip to and from work and walking. I upgraded my rating from 3 stars to 5 stars.

    Rating: 5

    2011-12-31: If you want a real headset an not just an earpiece, then this headset is your best bet.The neck harness is so comfortable, you will forget it is even there. You run the ear buds up, so people can hardly notice them.The audio quality is as good as average wired headset, which means it is AWESOME for a wireless headset.If you want to listen to music, or want audio quality that does not sound as awful as the average Blue Tooth earpiece, then you need to look no further.

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-12: this is a wonderful headset. my son has eplipsy and listens to his music from it and it works great.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-11: I was given these headphones as a gift and while I thought they were kinda neat I wasn't really sure how much I would use them. I typically use my headphones for physical activities like running and cycling; and I already have a pair that stay in my ears while doing that (previously my only criteria). But since the giver was very excited about them I thought I'd give them a try. I've had them a week and I've found it hard to put them down since. It's amazing how liberating it is not to have a wire. I keep having to remind myself that I can just walk away from my phone, or I don't have to unplug my headphones when I get off the bike.Pros so far:-Battery power. My initial charge seemed to last forever! Then it only took about an hour to recharge.-Distance. I find it has pretty decent distance. In my office I can go just about anywhere with zero interference (about 1800 sq ft but it is mostly "open" space with few walls). At my house I left my phone in my car parked in my driveway, went inside my house about 20 feet and it still worked fine. This will really depend on what's in between you and your phone but for the most part you're pretty free.-Everything it can do! Part of this is because I have an iphone 5S but I'm very impressed with all that I can do without touching my phone, including having it read my texts or emails. Requires no setup or special app, just push the phone button and say "read my texts", after reading it Siri will ask you if you want to reply and she'll accept dictation. Speech seems to be very clear through the headset. Previously I didn't have much use for Siri, now I'm using it all the time. If you're like me and don't utilize it much, I'd suggest Googling everything Siri can do.-Noise canceling. These headphones work well to cancel out background noise. Almost a little too well, so I only wear one ear bud while at work.-Comfort. I thought it'd be awkward to have these around my neck all day but I forget that it is there.My one complaint, is that for me these won't stay in my ears during a high impact workout, like running. They seem fine for everything else including the gym, elliptical and cycling. Maybe I just have funny ears :) But I'll probably stick to my headphones that wrap around my ears for my runs. I can handle that. I'm glad someone else realized how much I would love these.

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-12: Was working really good but now one side of the headset goes in and out. Too much of a pain to use now so in the trash they'll go. If I were you I would stick with something that is more durable and that can't be stretched or pulled making it impossible to use.

    Rating: 2

    2012-02-12: This headset has good sound, and the volume goes much louder than my Jabra bluetooth for my phone (and I searched high and low for the loudest one available). The fit of the ear pieces is just a good a most earbuds. The bluetooth connection seems to be made rather easily and the battery-life is an absolute ton of time. I like that the little orange ends of the headset are magnetic and can hold the earbuds easily for storage.The one flaw is that there is no native way to keep the headset from falling off while on your back (bench press, sit ups, etc.). I bought a $.60 eye glasses lanyard and used a could of knots to make a sliding loop and an adjustable length. It is not the most attractive apparatus, but effective and it never falls off now, and is not heavy enough for me to notice any pull on the front of my neck.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-08: This headset is great. Very good sound, very durable and very affordable. The controls are pretty simple to use and I can easily listen to my desktop PC or Transformer Prime or android phone. They are worth what you spend on them as they work really well......Unless you're at the gym and then they will fall off of your neck any time you are leaning or lying back. Incline or flat bench (or similar) they are falling off. Hop around too much and they will come off. Lean back in your chair with your hands behind your head and they will come off.If there was some kind of connecting lanyard or something like that across the two ends then I think that would solve the problem. Better yet, a band that goes around your neck connecting with velcro. It wouldn't have to be tight and yet could keep the electronics secure. Add a bit more noise cancellation and you would really have something special!But, if you aren't jogging or bike riding or in the gym then these bluetooth earbuds are worth every penny. I will be getting another pair of these soon as a matter of fact.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-25: I hate Bluetooth headsets.I've tried Plantronics, Jawbone, Motorola, and others. In ear, on ear, hanging over your ear, you name it. The problem with ears is that everyone's ears are different, and despite being similar, the generic earpieces all suck for my ears. Beyond that, the biggest drawback for Bluetooth headsets that I found was battery life. If I'm working for eight hours and my earpiece dies after three, I'm out of luck. For the longest time I relegated myself to using corded earbuds with my phone, because it was the only thing that was comfortable that I could wear for a long period of time. For ages, I wished that I could find something as comfortable as my earbuds without the hassle and frustration of a cord and a plug tying me to my phone.Enter LG, and their remarkable invention, the LG Tone. I ordered this item in August of 2012, and I've been using it each and every day since it arrived. The earbuds are soft and comfortable, and it arrived with a variety of sizes for varying ear canals. I use my headset at work to listen to streaming audio, and although the advertised battery life is ten hours of use, I frequently get much more. The controls are easy to use, and despite its size, once the collar is resting around your neck it's barely noticeable, and light as a feather. I even wear it when running and working out at the gym without any problems. Bluetooth range is exceptional, allowing me to walk thirty feet or more from my phone before I experience any interruption in signal.Without question, I will never buy another traditional Bluetooth headset again. Thank you, LG. I've recently ordered a LG Tone+ for use with my laptop computer while at home, freeing me from yet another cord.pros: Amazingly comfortable; easy to use; comfortable earbuds; spectacular battery life. durable. great sound and microphone response.cons: the gauge of wire for the earbuds could be a heavier gauge, though I have experienced no problems after more than 1,700 hours of use.

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-04: I use this mainly to listen to Audiobooks on my Nexus 7 and 10. Is it pairs very easily with either. The audio quality is clear and smooth. The controls are intuitive and easy to use and you can easily adjust the volume controls, play/pause, and fast forward and reverse. It lies comfortably around your neck and the short, but adjustable, earbud cords reach perfectly to your ears.The soft silicone earbuds fit very comfortably and are supplied in 2 sizes: small and medium. The earpieces are magnetically held to the ends of the lightweight neckpiece for storage, which essentially prevents the rats nest tangle of wired headphones. I've used a dozen other earphones and I'm always struggling with the wiring. Listening to 1000's of hours of audio books and podcasts this is a constant problem. It's great not to have to deal with it chords any more and I can move around the room freely without having to carry the tablet all the time.The rubbing noise that you always get from cords on earphones does not exist with these. It makes a great difference in the audio experience and is one reason why the perceived audio quality is superior.There's a blue LED that blinks every 5 seconds to indicate the bluetooth is functioning. It's a bit bright at night so I simply put the neckpiece on upside down.The battery life is stated as 10 hours. All in all, I'm extremely pleased with this item.

    Rating: 5

    2012-06-01: Love this thing. The only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is because while running it moves all over the place and doesn't really conform like it's supposed to. That doesn't bother me much but I wish it wouldn't move around so much while I'm tryna get my jog on! More than happy with it for the price. Highly Recommended!

    Rating: 4

    2012-07-12: So I move around a lot. Like spinning around in my chair at work, walking around outside, doing chores around the apartment. So you can imagine that wired headphones can get annoying really quickly. While there are lots of bluetooth headphones out there, I wear glasses, which means that ear-bud headphones are most comfortable for me. The ear-bud types are really rare, and the ones I have found (aside from these) tend to be of very poor quality according to reviews, or they are more expensive than I would like.These LG headphones are relatively cheap, and they are high quality. I have been using them for about a week now, and I think I can easily say that they are the best headphones I have ever owned. Previously, thePhilips SHE6001/28 In-Ear Headphones Surround Sound (White)were my "gold standard", since they could take my abuse and deliver great sound. This LG headset has, at the least, comparable sound quality and is well constructed. I am convinced that it will be able to survive everything I can throw at it! Not that I would intentionally abuse a fine piece of electronics like this, I'm just very... "accident prone".I have only used it with my Droid Razr, but the sound quality for music playback and calling is great. It was easy to pair with the phone, and it beeps to let me know when it has connected to the phone after I turn the headset on.Pros:-Durable-Great audio quality-Incredibly small learning curve-Easy pairing (at least on an Android phone)-Built in cord/ear-bud management-Roughly 20-24hrs of battery life based on playing music, making phone calls, and turning the head set off when I am not using it-Awesome range (like 30-50ft)-Great value for what you getCons:-Not free-You may forget you are still wearing it at times-When the battery starts to die, it doesn't beep or anything to let you know, your music/calls will just start to stutter and go in/out and the phone button will blink until you figure out that its the battery and not interference-It would be nice if the ear-bud cords retracted into the bigger parts, instead of having to use the loop dealies to keep them controlled

    2012-03-24: When I first saw this headset, my first thought is how weird to wear this on my neck and have loose wires go up to my ears! But I had to try since this headset is so versatile that it can replace all of my ear buds / headsets for portable devices and my laptop! It works well for stereo music and phone conversation for my Android phone. It works good for my iPad as well for music. I'm also really enjoying using it with my PlayStation Vita. In all cases the stereo sounds quite good, even better than many wired headset at this price range. Doing phone calls in stereo is also quite refreshing. If I want to hear outside, I'll just use one ear bud.At first I was concerned about using this for jogging and mountain biking, as I would be conscious about having something around my neck. But that turned out to be non issue. It's also very light.Despite having 6 buttons and a on/off switch, remembering them took less than few seconds! This is because the grouping of buttons on each side are very logical. Changing volume and forward/rewind songs make sense.One thing we often taking for granted is the ease of switching connection with varies devices. This one is capable of pairing with multiple devices. I was able easily switch between my Android and Vita.I highly recommend this product, event though it already has the overwhelming positive reviews. It's funny looking, but it's fun to wear knowing I can use just one headset for multiple electronic portable devices.*UPDATE* After having it for almost 1 year, I can say it's the best I ever had for 30 years! I use it every day for both phone and playing music. Heck, I stop using my car stereo (BMW) in favor of listening to music from this headset while driving!

    2012-02-15: Just got the LG Tone(black/orange) today and synced to my iPhone 4S no problem. Music and calls worked without problems. There were just a few features that I would have liked to have on this headset though. I found out from the LG live chat rep there's no way to see how much battery is left...see the conversation below:Guest: Hi I just received my LG Tone HBS-700Guest: and have a few questionsGuest: Am I able to check the battery status some how?Guest: and how long does it take to fully charge?Guest: and can it be used while chargingJermel: 1. no to the first question.Jermel: It should take as long as it will show the fully charged light.Guest: so once the light is blue?Jermel: And it is not recommend to be used while charging.Guest: okGuest: Is there a warning sign when the battery is low?Jermel: You will start to notice that the quality of the calls are not the same.Guest: thats it?Guest: no flashing lights?Guest: or anything of that kindJermel: Unfortunately not.I am sure I need to live down the hype of not having to deal with cords now and having stereo sound first before I can make an honest review. But so far, calls worked great (people on the other end said I sounded clear), battery is rated for at least a whole day worth of use and the music sounds great (I am not super picky about the sound BUT am picky when it comes to static sounds and the like, which I did not hear)Only time will tell how well this will hold up. I will update this review with any bad (or good) observations in the future that are worth mentioning. For now, 4 stars for the initial impression.---- UPDATE ---- ONE YEAR LATER ----So I have had these headphones for a year now and still work like day one. I am leaving at 4 stars because while it serves its purpose well, I wish it had some type of battery meter. It pairs well with my iPhone 5 (upgraded since the last time) and the buttons on the BT headset still function properly. Battery life seems to be good. I wear the headset in the office, while working out and cleaning. None of the components have started to wear off and no clips or ear buds have broken off. I use for music and taking calls over bluetooth and it is good. By good I mean it serves its purpose. If you're looking for rich bass and treble with amazing voice call quality - you may want to look elsewhere (like in the $100 range). Mines lasted a year so its been worth the investment (cost me $50 at the time).

    2013-12-21: While researching well-rated bluetooth stereo headsets, I narrowed it down to two choices: this LG 700W or the Air Fi Runaway that was also rated well by customers. I decided on this LG item first since it seems more inconspicuous and won't leave a dent in the hair, LOL! The Runaway headset does seem sturdier though..Upon first seeing this LG item, I was surprised how skinny and flexible the loop part of this headset was (the section that goes around the back of the neck)! Indeed very lightweight and I hope this doesn't make it too fragile. Want this headset to last awhile ..To start, swing the usb slot cover out to charge the unit via a micro usb to wall outlet plug. It paired easily with a Samsung Galaxy 7" Tab 2 and also to an older model flip cellphone. The headset vibrates and flashes when there's an incoming call. Pressing the button on one end turns off the music and connects the headset to the incoming call. Talk quality is excellent from both sides of the phone conversation.The magnetic earbuds are seated into the grooved ends of the headset and the wire slide adjustments take up the slack to keep the cords from getting all tangled up. I would recommend storing the headset in a protective pouch or ziploc bag to prevent the wires and all the various buttons from getting scraped up and damaged.This is an impressive product .. recommended!

    2012-06-25: I've been looking for a bluetooth headset for a couple years now.I finally took the leap with the LG Tone.The yea! These are great. The design is much more comfortable that I expected. As many reviews state, you really do forget you are wearing them.Not having to worry about the cord snagging and wrapping around every little thing takes a little getting used to.The sound is much better than an old wrap around BT that did pretty much the same things as the LG, just poorly.I didn't think that there was such a device that would provide great battery life, good range, great sound, and practical design in one package.The LG Tone has done so admirably.The meh: Running, and outdoors generally, are slightly better. Earphones do allow me to hear outside noise. The buds tend to slip around with jarring and moisture. Other than super glue, there really isn't a good solution though. Wind can be a problem, but what system doesn't have that problem.The cord can get hung up on the collar, or a shoulder strap catch it, but this has only happened two or three times. This is easy to avoid.Summary: The phone is great. The mike picks up just what it needs to. The controls are perfectly placed and I really love the magnetic earbud holders.All in all my expectations were guarded at first, but I've been completely satisfied with all aspects of this device.

    Rating: 5

    2014-03-06: (though as a qualifier there are few out there that I have been satisfied with)Pros-Lightweight, Switch for power(opposed to holding a button) good sound quality, comfortable earbuds, good battery life, vibration functionCons-Magnets do not hold earbuds in place for storage, flashing LED light on front, pieces that hold the cable back are poorly designed, lacking in volume(common in most bluetooth headsets)Sound quality is the most important factor and the LG 700s are above par in the field of bluetooth headset, a good balance of highs and lows and good fit that are all hard to find in a set of wired earbuds in this price range much less in a bluetooth headset. Next is comfort and they again succeed where others have failed, the main unit is very lightweight and when I'm in my work attire with a collared shirt I wear it underneath the collar and on top of my undershirt and would not even notice that it is there. In a T-Shirt it's a bit different but still not uncomfortable. The only problem I have had is while out running the ends of the unit will bounce up and down on the top of my chest which gets very annoying, I usually end up shoving the whole thing behind my back and just using the earbuds to hold in up. The vibrating notification for calls is a novel concept that I love though it kind of freaked me out at first since I was not aware that it did that.My big complaints are with the design of the cable and the earbud holders, the magnet are far too weak and they often get knocked out. Sometimes I just let them hang down the inside of my shirt instead of bothering with them. Then the way the cable is designed to attach to the back band seems poorly designed where the clips get pushed too far forward or back holding the cable up.In the end I would recommend it as the best out there right now, there is the 730 model but there seem to be some large kinks to work out.

    Rating: 4

    2012-04-14: I bought this on a whim based on the massive number of stellar reviews. Despite that, it's better than I expected. The sound is outstanding, much better than my Motorola S9. It is remarkably comfortable. The headset itself weighs next to nothing and on top of that, it's resting on your shoulders. The controls are well sized and easy to operate. In particular, with a sliding on/off switch you can tell at a glance which it is and also turn it off without looking and also reliably turn it on or off while you're wearing it.The design is... perfect. I like that while I'm wearing the headset and someone comes up to me all I need do is flip one of the ear-buds out and I can hear what they're saying. If it's someone I *really* care about I flip both out. If it's someone I don't want to talk to I flip... never mind. When I want to resume resuming the ear buds are easy to retrieve. If I want to get fancy I can drop them in the magnetic holders at either end of the around-my-neck thingy.The headset works flawlessly with my iPhone4. The "call" button answers calls if someone is calling, hangs up when I'm done, and get's Siri's attention at other times. Thanks to a decent microphone Siri understands what I say as do people I call. Also, unlike the S9, it doesn't matter where I carry my phone. The signal is clear at all times.About the only time I used my S9 was while I walked my dog. I'm using these lots more. While they don't sound as good as some of my wired headsets (costing many times more) they do sound pretty darn good and there is the convenience of not having to deal with a cord.In some ways this headset travels better than wired headsets because there's nothing to get tangled. Just drop the earbuds in their individual magnetic holders and put the whole thing in a flat compartment of your backpack, briefcase, purse, satchel, valise, etc, and you're good to go. For me it fits nicely in pocket #3 of myMoblie Edge, Mini Messenger Bag fits up to 13.3- Inch laptops and 11- Inch widescreen netbooks, Black/Dr Pepper.So how, you ask, can you make it better still? This headset came with two different sized pairs of ear gels, one pair slightly larger than medium and the other pair slightly smaller than medium. My problem is, these press-to-fit ear gels never work for me. Some work better than others and these worked about as good as any but it wasn't perfect; they would slip out on occasion. Then I stumbled across these:2 Pair, Mens Size - Earphones Plus Brand, Tri-Level, Replacement Ear Cushions, Earbuds for Sound Isolating Earphones. (See Fit Information in Details Below). They fit both this headset and my ears perfectly. The soft silicon (?) seals out noise, keeps the ear buds from slipping out without having to drive them in with a hammer, and they make the headset sound even better. *Now* it's totally perfect!Please feel free to let Amazon and me know if this review was helpful to you since it helps me improve the information I provide.

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-30: I've owned a few variations of Bluetooth headsets that I've used while exercising, including the Motorola S-9 and S-10 and the Jaybird Freedoms. The new LG Tone 700 may look a bit strange, but it quickly became my favorite Bluetooth headset for exercise and general use.The 700 fits around your neck, and is light enough that you really don't know you're wearing them. The only caveat I'd add regarding comfort is that if you're wearing a collarless shirt, like a tee shirt when running, you will feel the headset's thin band on the back of your neck. This doesn't bother me since the Jaybirds have a wire connecting the two earbuds that also rides the back of our neck, and the Motorola headsets have a heavy, think band that goes back and over your ears. When evaluating comfort, also keep in mind that a regular wired headset or earbuds have a wire that's flapping around. On balance, the LG headset is really the most comfortable and least noticeable of those I've tried.Surprisingly, the LG's stay in place, even when running. Unlike the Jaybirds, which have some weight to them that helps to dislodge them from your ear, the LG earbuds are featherweight and stay put. After the first few minutes of wearing them, I didn't even notice that I had them on, they're really that comfortable. With a collared shirt, like a polo, I didn't feel the headband at all. It's like they're not there!The LG's have the best battery life by far of any of the Bluetooth headsets I've owned. I tried an experiment with the LG's where I used them on two 1-hour runs, then took them to the golf course where I volunteer once a week and listened to them for 6 hours straight. The battery didn't quit and still had enough juice to keep running. The Jaybirds and the Motorolas would both have died after about 3 to 4 hours of use.The built-in phone works great, and no one I talked to with the LG's complained about the sound, even though I was outdoors. I often got complaints with the Jaybirds that people had trouble hearing me.I will concede that the Jaybirds have better sound and noticeably better fidelity than the LG's. The LG can be adjusted to boost the bass response, but they don't match the Jaybirds for sound. On the other hand, the Jaybirds can't compete with the battery life of the LG, so you'll have to decide what's most important to you. I mostly listen to audiobooks while I exercise so a small loss of fidelity, while disappointing, isn't a deal breaker for me.There is a newer version of this headset, the 730, but after reading the reviews, I thought I'd stick with the 700. There are reports that the 730 is less stable holding onto a Bluetooth signal, although I can't verify those reports. I can say that the 700 is rock solid and doesn't drop the audio stream even when the phone is in my pocket of backpack.The bottom line is that I think the LG's are a great value for the price. The Motorola S-9's LED burned out on me after a year, and the S10 wasn't nearly as comfortable as its sibling. The Jaybird Freedom slips out of my ear, even with all of their adapters, so I'm constantly fiddling with them as I run. In addition, the Jaybird Freedoms have limited controls for your iPhone or iPod. Stop, start and volume are about all you can do, as well as answer a call. With the LG you can fast forward or reverse as well as jump tracks. Another plus in this area for the LG is that it can tell you it's remaining battery life via its LED, which the Jaybirds can't.Compared to these products, the LG Bluetooth Stereo Headset is my new benchmark for audio. They do look a bit weird, but they really are well designed to deliver maximum battery life, a strong Bluetooth connection, and all the controls you need to manipulate your iPhone or Android device.

    2013-07-05: How I use it:I wear this while biking to work. I keep my smartphone (which the headset is connected to via Bluetooth) in a pouch beneath my bike seat. I only use the left earbud (illegal to wear 2 earbuds while riding a bike in California, and its safer to only wear one).Bluetooth connectivity:Works very well. It automatically connects to my smartphone when I turn the headset on. The connection rarely cuts out and, if it does, cuts out for less than a second.Audio:The sound quality seems pretty good.Locking the earbuds into the earbud holder:The earbuds have magnets in them (don't worry, they shouldn't fry your brain...) so they 'lock in' to the earbud holders pretty easily, and then they stay there (even when I'm bouncing around on my bike). The magnets are nice because they enable me to lock the earbuds into the earbud holders without looking, and also when I have semi-bulky gloves on. Occasionally, the earbuds do fall out of the earbud holders; this usually happens when I am riding 'hard' and am bumping up and down a lot while riding.Comfort:I often forget that I'm wearing this headset. That is how comfortable and light and unobtrusive this headset is! The earbuds, themselves, are very comfortable, as well. The neckband is especially useful for me because I only wear one earbud. If there was no neckband that holds earbuds not in use, the earbud that I do not use would hang and pull the other earbud down.Button Controls:The volume and song skip buttons are very accessible. I can even press them when I have semi-bulky gloves on, though I can often press the wrong button (volume up instead of volume down).Battery Life:The headset lasts something like 500 - 800 minutes on a full charge. This is really good.

    2012-04-20: I received the LG Tone as a gift. First my evaluation; then the comparison.Setup: EasyI charged the LG and turned it on. I turned on bluetooth on my Samsung Note, and then hit the button to search for bluetooth devices. The Note immediately found the LG and I told it to pair - which took less than 5 seconds.Comfort: Good.The LG sits around my neck almost unnoticed. It comes with only 2 silicone ear bud sizes, but the larger one fit my ears. The ear buds are then just as comfortable as any other ear bud.Snagging wires: No wires!Other ear buds must be connected by their wires to the phone/device and are prone to snagging.Range: About 30 feet.Casual Listening: Great!No hum, no hiss, no obvious distortion, and overall volume is good. I usually have my Samsung Note music player set to 9/15 loudness with the LG volume set 3 down from the max loudness. The LG Tone is a pleasure to use.COMPARISONContestants:1. LG Tone HBS-700 Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Headset (set to bass boost)2. Samsung Note Ear Buds3. JBuds Hi-Fi Noise-Reducing Ear Buds4. GOgroove DynaMIX High-Performance Ear Buds5. Sennheiser HD203 Closed-Back DJ Headphones (full size)6. JVC HA-RX500 Over-the-Ear Headphones (full size)Last Place: Gogroove. Maybe this is unfair. GOgroove didn't sound bad and seemingly (see below) had good base, but it was way too bright for my taste. [If your ears have lost sensitivity to high frequencies maybe this would be your first choice.]Second Place: LG Tone, Samsung, and Jbuds.Really, it was hard to tell the difference between any of these 3 second place ear buds. They were all a bit bright and all seemingly (see below) had good thumping base. All 3 have what I would call a good quality of sound (low distortion). I am happy that the LG sounded as good (to my ears) as any of the other ear buds.First Place: Sennheiser and JVC full size headphones.I hope nobody is surprised here! There is just no way an ear bud can beat a good quality over-ear full-size headphone. The ear buds only began to seem a bit bright when compared to the full size headphones. Clarity was also better in the full size headphones (but not much better). BASS RESPONSE? This was the big difference. After all, the JVC has a 40mm driver (almost 2 inches in size)! Although the ear buds seemed to have good bass response, as soon as I put on the full size headphones the sad truth became obvious. ALL of the ear buds were weak on bass and none of them had any very deep bass what-so-ever. But then you knew that already, didn't you?Conclusion: I think that all the second place ear buds (including the LG Tone) are at least adequate for casual listening, and because of their smaller size they are more convenient to carry around. The LG Tone was my favorite since it didn't have wires to snag.

This bluetooth wireless headset is a life saver for both me and my iphone!

    2013-04-28: So this was my third pair of Bluetooth headsets and it's the third one that fails my usability tests. Bear in mind all 3 were different brands and all 3 had significant faults to them that forced me to return them.For starters I was kind of put off by it being called "wireless" when infact you have wires leading to the actual ear pieces but that's just semantics I guess. They seemed durable, flexible and looked like they could be around for the long haul. I had no problem syncing them with my Android phone and the sound clearly beats out the Plantronics rival and the Motorola. While the bass is weak the overall sound quality is the best one could expect from a Bluetooth device. Same goes for the call quality.Now looking at the device before I purchased it one would assume that since it sits around your neck it would be stiff like a partial necklace in case you had to have them on while you were doing anything that required you to be horizontal. Not the case, it is flimsy and really the only thing keeping this on your neck is the weight (not much of it) of the ends/buttons. This poses a significant problem if your sole reason for purchasing these is to utilize them at the gym. If you need to do a bench workout, situps or anything that requires you to lay flat even for a moment these will fall right off your neck. When running with these they bounce around your neck and don't feel at all secure. I tucked mine into my shirt but I'd imagine if your a woman and run in a sports bra or tank top that's just not going to be possible.Much like the Motorola I wanted to like these but at the end of the day the cons really outweighed the pros and I could not in good conscience let LG keep my money for this product. I'm hoping one day someone get's this mastered for a reasonable price but until then if you're an active guy/gal and looking specifically for a gym headset I'd stick with a good pair of wired ear buds.

    2014-03-01: They are just ok. Just like I figured, they don't stay around neck when I'm working out. They tend to slide off. Also, the battery life isn't 10hrs as described.

    Rating: 2

    2011-11-02: The HBS-700 is a stereo bluetooth headset with a unique design. Bluetooth headphones are a challenge for hardware designers because of the need to house the electronics and a big enough battery to supply decent autonomy, and the need for a wire between the electronics and both earpieces.This is why so far there has only been two major designs on the market: one is large over-the-ear pads connected with a headband or just a wire, the other being earbuds connected by a wire to a little box housing the electronics. Both designs have problems: the former is usually uncomfortable and the earpads tend to have problems staying in place, particularly when exercising; the latter defeats the purpose of wireless headphones by still leaving you to deal with a tangled mess of wires.The HBS-700 offers a novel approach to solving this problem: the electronics and controls are housed in a circle clip that sits around your neck, and the earbuds are connected to it by a short wire that can't get tangled. Even better, the earbuds attach magnetically to the tips of the neckband when not in use.Ergonomically, the HBS-700 gets top marks. The usual controls are very logically organized and easy to identify by touch even while running or exercising. The power switch is a mechanical slider, so there's never any doubt whether your headphone is on or off. Charging is done via a standard microUSB connector.The features are what you expect from bluetooth stereo headphones: bluetooth action button (pick up an incoming call, hang up, initiate a call/siri, redial), volume +/- on the left hand side, play/pause, previous and next on the right hand side. Everything works very reliably and just as you would expect (I have been using these headphones for months with an iPhone 4)Even better, the battery life is phenomenal (at least 10 hours of music playback) and the neckband vibrates when a call comes in: impossible to miss a call even in a noisy environment or while exercising.If you're listening to music and a call comes in, press the call button to pick up the call and the music pauses. When you hang up, the music resumes.In terms of sound quality, the HBS-700 delivers as well. These are not high quality audiophile headphones, but they sound perfectly adequate and will be great to use at the gym, while jogging, etc...Convenience, sound quality, battery life, reasonable price make the HBS-700 an excellent value. If you're only going to buy one set of bluetooth headphones, I can't think of a better model to recommend -- and I've tried them all.

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-28: I use this at work and working out, the distance is incredible and the sound is amazing. it hides under the collar for a stealthy look.

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-28: I have bought 3 versions of stereo bluetooth headsets. All worked well initially, with only the Samsung 3700 awkward. The LG might fit into the awkward catagory for some, maybe most, but so far, I have nothing but nits and PRAISE for this headset.The built in Play Music Android equalizer solved any sound quality issues I had. The headset works very well. The auto override of the music to the phone and back has been flawless. The bluetooth has been the best functioning bluetooth units I have ever had.So far, the only nits I have are the charging cover seems strange, the UP/DOWN (Next/PREVIOUS) song selector is the opposite direction as the volume UP/DOWN, and mostly, the charger light. Once you learn when the red light goes out, the unit is charged, this one goes away.Overall, so far, a very high quality headset. Now to get it to Florida and see how it handles sweat...

    Rating: 5

    2012-08-12: Primarily, my wife and I use these to listen to music on to iPads.Battery LifeIn the real world, these need to be charged daily. We've had them about 3 months and generally I can get a fully work day about 9-10 hours plus a one hour workout. I have a pair of Artic headphone which have phenominal battery life but are silly to wear cause they stick out far.ComfortWe always forget we are wearing them. Last week, my wife jumped into the shower with them on but I saw her jump in and was able to stop her before they received a thorough shampoo treatment. They go best on the inside of some shirts and under the collar of others.The LookPeople are always asking about where they can get these. If you are one of these people, you are getting much warmer...IOS/ipad and Blackberry and AndroidThese can be paired with two devices at once but there's a trick to it. Connect the phone first. If it connects to my ipad before the Blackberry it won't connect to Blackberry at all until bluetooth is off on IOS. When it works, it works greatand music pauses while I take my call and resumes afterward.I've tried several different ear buds with these but ended up (unknowingly) back with the original size. Other buds I had came from and earbud tip kit i bought at an airport electronics place. Not that it matters, but I saw reviews trashing the headset because the person using them couldn't get a replacement. Hope that helps you with your purchase!

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-15: I found that my old blue tooth was just palne uncomfortable. When I asked a friend how he liked his LG Wireless Bluetooth Headset, he responded "it's the best investment I ever made". "It's so easy to use and you don't have something stuck in your ear all day". It synked up to my Palm Pixie phone with out a hitch!! The sound is AWESOME!! One suggestion to those who might want to buy this headset, as with any bluetooth headset. If your phone is in a craddle, make sure you do not walk away from your phone for more than 30 feet. The headset will go into standby mode. You must reconnect to your phone when you get back within the 30 foot range. Also, girls if you have long hair or a necklace on, make sure you remove your necklace and put your hair up. Keeps everything from getting tangled in the headset. Speaking from experience... LOLIt's an AWESOME accessory to my phone and I would recommend this product to anyone looking to purchase.

    Rating: 4

    2013-09-27: I've had for 2 months now and I'm enjoying them. works very well with my Samsung Galaxy S4 phone. Sound quality is great.. Only has one problem. It pick-ups background noice.

    Rating: 5

    2011-12-30: I work in a warehouse pulling orders and driving a forklift all day, and I like to listen to news and audio books while working. I've had a couple of Jawbone models and many pairs of corded headphones/ear-buds by Apple, Phillips, and Sony. Problems with all of these include difficulties keeping the cord out of my way while working, volume levels too weak for loud noise environments, problems with the buds staying in my ears, and poor battery life. This model corrects all of these deficiencies.The ear buds stay in my ears well because they are very light and the rubber tips seal well. This was my biggest problem with the Jawbone models-even the icon was heavy enough to jostle out of my ears simply by walking. All of the battery weight in this model is around your neck (and it's not that they're heavy, because they're not - it's just that even a little heft won't stay in my ear) This setup also allows LG to cram at least 3 times as much battery into the halo around your neck, because the battery life is three times as long as the Jawbone, and as far as I could tell in my research, it has a better battery life than any other Bluetooth headset.Even running, the halo never threatens to fall off my neck, and I often forget it's there. (Update; this is not the case when the buds are in the magnet pockets. What happens then is that the buds bounce out of the pockets. Bottom line, don't run without the buds in your ears.)The volume levels are fantastic, and with my Iphone 4 it gets louder than I can handle (and I am a drummer, I can handle loud). I can barely say this about many of the corded headsets that I have used.The range of this headset with my Iphone is the best I have ever experienced. Maintaining line of sight, I can easily exceed 100 meters without losing signal. In my warehouse, with many obstructions, I can exceed 50 meters as long as I don't enter a closed room without my phone.I cannot testify as to its water resistance.Callers tell me that background noise levels are much quieter than with my other headsets, which was an issue I didn't find addressed often in other reviews.There are many buttons on the headset, and initially I kept confusing the phone side with the media side (left is phone, right is media). However, they are easy to use, have a nice feel when I press them, and I get the impression by the way that they feel when I press them that they will prove to be durable, which is a good thing because in my experience it's often buttons that wear out first on devices of this kind.The wires that connect the halo to the buds are not heavy duty, and are thin enough to have caused me a little anxiety at first, but it has not been a problem, and I cannot give too much praise to the designer who came up with the idea to provide magnetic pockets to hold the buds. This is ingenious, and not only keeps them from flopping around when they're not in my ears, but also minimizes the opportunities for damaging them.Overall, this headset has a excellent design and is well built. I love it, and when I wear this one out I will buy another.

    Rating: 5

    2012-02-10: There was a great review of these on CNet - that is what prompted me to get them. I am so glad I did - they are very comfortable, easy to use, syncs up great with a Blackberry. The controls on the headset work great for the music on a BlackBerry. Great sound, very very comfortable!

    Rating: 5

    2012-01-24: I have to admit that even in bass boost mode, which is activated by holding the volume up and down buttons simultaneously for 1 second, the bass response of this headset leaves a lot to be desired. If you listen to music where bass is an important component, this is probably not the headset for you. For bass, I give this headset a 2 out of 5.However, for mobility and convenience, this headset easily gets a 5 out of 5. You quickly will forget that you have them on. The controls on the device allow forward, back, pause, play, up volume, down volume, call answering, etc. Also, if you're accustomed to the low volume of many bluetooth devices, the LG HBS-700 will blow you away because the volume is adjustable to uncomfortably loud levels, so you will never have trouble hearing a caller on the other end.Great device overall and I'm pleased with my purchase.

    Rating: 4

    2011-11-22: Two-week update: I cannot emphasize enough how FANTASTIC it is to be able to fast-forward through overly long podcast commercials in one simple button press with these things. I'm ordering another!This is one of the few (perhaps the only) bluetooth headsets that features a dedicated fast-forward button (quick press for next track, hold longer for fast-forward within a track).The FF offers a quick beep every other second it is pressed (which is good; it lets you know it's registered the button press and is obeying your command).I'm using an iPhone 4S. Connecting the unit via bluetooth has been easy.The sound is fine for podcasts & audiobooks. For music, I found the LG Tone adequate -- but subtly lifeless, and it was necessary to dig into the iPhone's EQ settings to make music listenable (but still a bit lifeless).Since I'm using it during my 25-minute walking commute along noisy brooklyn streets (buses, trucks, sirens), I don't mind the merely adequate music playback (which most BT headsets suffer from).I mainly listen to audiobooks & podcasts anyway. And for anyone who's ever suffered through one of Leo Laporte's five-minute Ford Sync ads knows, that FF button will come in REALLY HANDY. (I don't own a car!) The main reason I bought this unit is so I can FF thru junk without fishing out my iPhone.Battery life seems normal for a stereo BT device, and the neck-wrap style is only annoying for a minute before it blends in with the weight of your winter coat.I'm pleasantly satisfied with my LG Tone. :)

    2013-11-17: I have had several mono and stereo Bluetooth headsets. I have had several call only and audio streaming devices. This one is the best yet.Good call sound, listening and speaking. Fits comfortably. It's not exactly unobtrusive when wearing a business suit, but it does look less geeky than always having a unit hanging on your ear.The sync is super solid. I haven't had it drop a call or a connection yet. The downside is that I am more likely to forget my phone in the car or in the house because I can get a good distance away from it before the connection breaks.I love using it for podcasts.     Rating: 5

    2012-07-29: Design:The first thing that struck we was how well it was designed. Every aspect of it was paid excellent attention to. The headphone sits very well across the neck and very seamlessly. I did not sense it while running after the first few minutes.Every operation (at least the ones we care for from a headphone) has a dedicated button. This means, you can concentrate on what you do instead of figuring out a button push sequence or using it in combination.The headsets are not think and heavy going into the ear and when you are done they snap back in place that fundamentally removes cluttered wires.Performance:The pairing was seamless. It only took a few seconds (MotoACTV).I am not a audio expert by any means, so take it from that perspective. The audio stream has been very stable without any "silence". The bass (especially when you run outside) is okay and the it also sound slightly tinny (which can probably be adjusted if we had an EQ app but the ACTV does not support such apps). It does not isolate external audio as well as it advertises. It is definitely not annoying (not even close) but i am not sure that the noise-suppression works as well as it is advertised.The battery was high when I received it and have run for about 2 hours now and haven't had a chance to recharge it yet.I haven't tried multi-connection with my phone yet. I will, someday, but dont have a usecase for it yet.Overall, if you are looking for a simple-to-use headset that you aren't constantly worried if it may fall down, get this one and you will not be disappointed. Do note that its not a performance headset but definitely well-designed and does well what it mainly sets off to do at its price-point.

    2011-12-20: very good product.Very comfortable.Supplied rubber ear inserts are cheap, I used silicone ear inserts from a Nokia device instead.Battery lasts a respectable amount of time, but not the claimed amount of ten hours of use.Audio quality for listening to music is good (considering it is bluetooth).Microphone is good, no need to hold mic next to mouth or cheek. Unpairing and repairing will not resolve this problem. I do not know why it does this and have not been able to remedy it.>>> UPDATE: Nokia's update to Belle (not Belle Refresh) has resolved the connection/interface problem with the E7-00.

    2012-12-27: This was one of my favorite purchases of the year. I recently misplaced them, however, and will be upgrading to the new model (HBS-730).First, if you have never had wireless headphones, get ready for a treat. Not having to worry about snagging a cord on something is great. The battery lasts all day for me, and the duration did not seem to noticeably decrease after a year.I used them to listen to music and podcasts at work almost every day. I appreciated the fact you can leave one earbud in, while the other sits safely in its magnetic holder. This way I could still hear my coworkers. Being able to leave my phone charging and still walk around while listening is great. I can grab a glass of water from the water cooler or walk over to a colleague's desk without any hassle. I am using a wired set of earbuds until my HBS 730 arrives, and it is amazing how much of an inconvenience the cord is.I enjoyed using them while running, although I know many hear have said the neckband bounced around too much for their liking. This didn't bother me much so maybe my neck is bigger. The fact that you don' t have a wire pulling on them as you run means they stayed in my ears better than a corded set. Putting my phone in an armband and having no cord involved made running very enjoyable.Sound quality is OK. It was better than I expected for a wireless set, and although I hear the newer version has improved sound quality, I had no complaints. A lot of my listening was just talk radio podcasts with only one earbud in, but sound was decent for hip hop and rock when I was listening to music.Finally, just a comment on the build quality and durability. As others have noted, these things seems to be very well built. My set still looked new after a years worth of use. I didn't exactly baby my set either. They may seem kind of flimsy when you first pick them up, but the materials being used are apparently high quality.If I end up having range issues with the HBS-730 as some of the other reviewers have mentioned, I will likely end up returning those and coming back to the HBS-700. The only thing that is NOT in question is that I apparently can't live without these, as replacing my lost pair was never in doubt.

    2012-02-10: I love the headset. However, even though it looked like it was in original packaging, it did NOT come with a user manual. Instead, just tap the phone button and voila, voice control. It works great.So I've put this up to a 5star rating.
