There are many adapters for different devices. I use it for my Apple iPad and iPod.You really can't beat it!Please note: I was provided with a sample from the distributor in order to give an honest review.

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-18: Being a former Road Warrior, I value items that are "Swiss Army Knives" by fulfilling more than one role as well as products that "standardize" my life freeing me of carrying extra power cords and adapters to charge my various gadgets.The Xamp PB5600 is a full 5600 mah battery boost for mobile devices such as cell phones, Droids, iPods, iPads, tablets, and mp3 players. It also contains an LED light for spotlighting a small area. The Xamp comes with a cloth carrying case, 7" and 27" USB cables to the proprietary Xamp connector the DC3.5v, a USB AC wall plug, as well as connectors for mini USB, micro USB, Nokia dc2.0, iPod and iPad and one other adapter I have yet to determine what it will connect with. The box suggests "Please use your own charging cable for Apple Products." This is somewhat misleading since the Xamp comes with 2 adapters for the common Apple products. Theoretically a USB charger can be used to boost the battery for most similar handheld devices and gadgets.The power button requires a double press to toggle the LED on/off.Per the very elegant packaging, the Xamp is fully charged in 6 to 8 hours via 5vDC 1amp input and claims to be rechargeable 500 or more times. The charger claims a robust 1000 mah/hour output to devices to satisfy even the most hard-core device needs. The packaging indicates 3 connectors are included - the USB mini, micro and dc2.0, however there are three other adapters included as well (a bonus of sorts).The manual states the LED lights indicates the power remaining:one LED indicates less than 25% remainingtwo LEDs indicates 25-50% power remainsthree LEDs indicate 50-75% power remainsfour LEDs indicate 75-100% power remainsSuggestion to Manufacturer: I wish the Xamp 5600 mah was slimmer and included a built-in mini USB power adapter such asMotorola Universal Dual-Charging Portable Power Pack - Black - Retail Packaging. However the Xamp is 5600 mah whereas the Motorola is only 1500 mah.Rating: 4.5 stars. The lack of a built-in microUSB cable, the proprietary DC3.5v connectors should be changed to microUSB connectors and more consistent information between the packaging to the user manual would make the Xamp a full 5 star product.Full-Disclosure: The manufacturer provided this item for reviewing purposes.

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-24: Disclaimer: I received this product free for the purpose of an honest test run and review.Okay, so I'm not going to touch the technical aspects of this device. The other reviewers have done an admirable job of doing so. I will simply speak of my experience and my thoughts regarding this power bank.Simply put, I thought it was pretty exceptional. I dont have a lot of experience with these devices, but I have found it to be quite useful so far. It was able to fully charge my dead droid battery in about two and a half hours, and still had all four circles left (the circles, which you can see in the pic, show the charge left in the power bank). I then used it to charge my girlfriends droid and our kindle Fires. All told, that drained a little more than half of the power bank, although the Fires both had about a 50% charge when I plugged them in. It mentions PSP's in the description. I dont own one, but I do own a pair of Vita's. This device did not work with the Vita's even though I was able to plug them into this. I left the light on overnight after all that, and after about 15 hours of basically continual use, it still had one circle left. I plugged it in and it took about 10 hours to recharge the power bank (using the included wall plug).As far as aesthetics, this is a very nice looking device, small enough to fit in your pocket (although it does come with a mesh carry pouch), comes with a small assortment of charging attachments designed to fit a variety of phones and devices.The flashlight also works well. It isnt strong enough to illuminate a room or even a decent path if you are walking in the dark (although it will light up the area immediately in front of you). It is however more than adequate for rummaging through boxes, trunks, etc...and I have found it particularly useful in looking for stuff in my bedroom after my girlfriend has gone to sleep.So, I am quite pleased with this device. I think it works great and is a welcome and useful addition to my array of random gadgets and devices.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-24: I have a bunch of portable powerpacks. Several, like this one, were provided at no charge for my review. This is the most bang for the back as far as size and power. It's 5600 mAh - that's enough to charge the average smart phone two or three times. This is small enough to keep in a purse or pocket while charging or powering your device. I can't count the times I've forgotten to charge my Droid, grabbed it, left the house - and no phone. Charging in the car is a pain - if I'm out on errands, the car is running 10 minutes, parked, etc. With the battery pack, I can keep the phone "plugged in" and charging the entire time. I use it to charge my iPod and Droid. Especially handy on long trips where I won't have access to chargers.It weighs 4.5 ounces (heavier than most phones) and includes several adapters. Other packs include a wider variety of connectors, but this has the most common. Micro USB, mini-USB, iDevice and several other power connectors. Also includes a small padded carry pouch, USB charger and cable.For the price you really can't beat this.

    Rating: 5

    2013-05-01: This charger has an interchangeable plug so it can charge the iPhone 4 or the iPhone 5 as long as you use the charging chord that came with your phone.It holds its charge for up to a month when not used. It is very handy for business to have as a back up to recharge your phone when traveling by car or if you are in all day meetings.The LED indicates charge level. My wife really likes that it works as flashlight, for her when traveling at night. It sets you free from the endless quest to find wall outlets during rest stops on car trips or airports. While one amp adapter is included for recharging, remember it is also compatible with other USB chargers for easy use on most types of phones.

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-26: I recently received a TimeTec Xamp 5600mAh Portable External Battery for reviewing purposes. I often run my iPad and iPhone in a mode that leaves me looking for a power outlet after about a day, and I'm always interested in ways I can extend the battery life. I must say I'm very pleased with the TimeTec battery. It's a well-designed unit with plenty of adapters, and it has enough juice to do the job.First off, I plugged my iPhone 4 into the unit at about 75%. In about 30 minutes, I was back to 100% and the charger was still showing four power indicators (100%). I then plugged in my iPad (1st gen), expecting that to just hover around the 80% mark that it was at. Wrong... It charged up just as fast, and left the charger showing 75% remaining. Realistically, it was probably down to about 50% but just hadn't tripped the second indicator yet. I plugged it back in to recharge, and it was back to full power in a little over an hour. I was using the AC plug for recharging the battery, but you can also recharge via USB. Since my car is USB-equipped, that means I can use this on the fly.The unit is very light, so it's not a hassle to lug around. It comes with a large number of plug adapters (Nokia DC2.0, micro USB, mini USB, and standard iPhone), so it's quite versitile. It even has a small flashlight built in if you happen to be using it in some dark area and need a little extra light. Coupled with the mesh pouch that stores everything, this makes for a convenient addition to your travel bag.This is definitely an option to consider if you're looking for an additional power source to extend your electronic device battery life on long trips or at times you're not around a power plug.Disclosure:Obtained From: CompanyPayment: Free

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-19: I was approached by TimeTec Inc. to try out their new product and provide a review. So I did receive this product as a gift from TimeTec.The product is exactly as described on Amazon. It is small and compact and provides a great way to charge my iPhone and iPad when I am not near a power source, or while traveling without having to take along several cables. I can take this product with just one cable and two different small adapters that were all provided and fit easily into the provided carrying case.After opening the product it took just an hour to get it fully charged up. As advertised it has a small flashlight app, but I'm not sure how often that will be useful, since the flashlight app on most phones is more convenient.My iPhone was 50% charged when I connected the TimeTec 5600 to it. It took 64 minuets to bring it back to a full charge. The TimeTec didn't get overly warm, it was cool to touch during the charging. It also showed no drop in power bars (it has four circles to signify, 25, 50, 75 & 100% charge. After an hour charging my phone the TimeTec still showed 100% capacity, I assume that means it used only around 10% of its power to recharge my phone.I then gave a quick charge to my iPad, it was at 75% when I started. A half hour later it was fully charged. And still the TimeTec showed full power left, so i would believe that means I used less than 1/4th of its charge to give my two devices a quick boost.The product came with two USB cables with power plug ends, 4 device attachments to fit apple products and android products, along width a wall plug for use with the cables.I would have given a 5 Star rating but I did have one problem. There is a web site listed on the packaging box but whe I typed it into my browser I'm told the site can not be found. So I was unable to verify the company. I tried a Google search and also could not find thei company.The device is made in China and I can only assume that it is part of a much larger corporation.For the price I believe this product will satisfy most travelers that want a quick battery pack back up for their phones and tablets.

    Rating: 4

  • B00A55Q2HA

    $B00A55Q2HA

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-02-11: My very first TPU case purchase was a black Diztronic for my Galaxy Nexus. I was satisfied with it, but I always wondered if the other (more expensive) brands were better. When I got my Nexus 4, I decided to flirt with a Cruzerlite Bugdroid in semi-transparent smoke. I liked the cool droid carving design, but I didn't like the feel of the glossy edge. The slightest bit of oil or moisture on my hands would make it slippery and the phone kept wanting to flip in my hands. That's when I knew I should have stuck with Diztronic. While not super grippy, the matte finished edge on the Diztronic provides a consistent feel regardless of how dry or moist my hands are, and it doesn't show any fingerprints. Also, I can say from trying both cases that the sealed buttons on this one are much easier to use than the perfectly aligned button cutout design on the Cruzerlite case.I was tempted to buy the Diztronic in smoke color, too, but read the other reviews here about the branding on the back colliding with the LG logo. So I went with classic black instead. When the case arrived, I was surprised to see the Diztronic had fixed the issue (at least on the black color) and moved their logo down closer to the bottom edge, below the LG logo. I guess I shouldn't have been so surprised since this company has a history of improving it's product based on customer feedback, just like they did with the Galaxy Nexus case when they eventually got it right with "revision 3".So why the missing stars? There is one significant issue with the case I received: the bottom right corner has a very rough "blemish" - see the photo I uploaded. It may be related to the injection molding process, and I don't know if it's just a random anomaly or a recurring manufacturing defect. Others may not notice it, but it's a big deal for me because when I make voice calls, I hold the phone with my left hand and wrap my pinky around that corner to secure it. That blemish is jagged enough to irritate my skin. It's extra annoying because the rest of my fingers feel a nice smooth texture, and then bang - a rough patch that screams out of place.I've considered sanding it down with fine sandpaper, but I'm afraid of making it worse. It's not just excess bits, some of the unevenness seems to be material being too thin at certain spots.Also, Diztronic should update their product pictures to show the location of the new branding.

    Rating: 3

    2013-06-18: She loves it and fits her phone perfectly! All the openings are where they should be and it looks nice on the phone. A+!

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-16: I have been using the case for 3+ weeks. It protects the phone well. I use it with a ghost Armor screen protector. No issues. I like the slim profile. Also, works with the Qi charger I have.

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-09: Remember, all cases are a compromise between style and protection. Some of us want protection that is not like an Otterbox, but at the same time more than just a plastic scratch protector. It appears Diztronic did this right.PROS:1. High quality workmanship and manufacturing. No rough edges or frayed plastic.2. Snug fit, but not too tight.3. No cut outs for the buttons as that loosens the case and allows pocket lint and dust another entry point. Buttons work fine.4. The lip on front is very useful for accidental drops or if you should place your phone screen down and it moves. It protects the screen.5. The case will protect from small accidental drops and scratches.6. The cutouts for the camera, speaker, micro USB, headphone jack, and microphones are perfect. They line up exactly.7. Minimalistic design that offers protection, but is still slim.CONS:1. Like other cases of this style, if dirt & debris enter the case from any opening, it may scratch the metal bezel and glass back. It may be a good idea to protect the back with a plastic skin.2. The back appears to have been fused or molded on, thereby delineating an edge around the back. This is no problem, but I would have preferred it to be smooth like other Diztronic cases of the past.3. The Diztronic logo on the back should be one font size smaller.4. The Nexus 4 tends to heat up on heavy 3G use, this case will prevent you from feeling the heat. This isn't necessarily a "CON", but important to point out since if you feel heat, then the battery will drain quickly and users should be aware of this.BOTTOM LINE: This is the best slim case for the Nexus 4.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-10: Perfect fit for my Nexus 4. Keeps the back glass protected and has holes perfect for the camera lens, flash bulb and speaker. For $10, I couldn't ask for a better case. Sure, it doesn't do anything for the screen, but I'm okay with that. As long as it takes the brunt of any damage to the back and corners, the screen is usually pretty resilient on the Nexus 4.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-24: This is the first Diztronic product I have ever purchased. As of right now, case selection for the Nexus 4 is fairly limited (much like the supply of the phone itself I suppose). I tend to like keeping my phones in cases from the first day I own them. To be honest, I purchased this case thinking that it would only be temporary until some of the more well known brands developed cases for the Nexus 4, but I ended up liking this case so much that I think I'll be keeping it on the phone long term.One of the main reasons I picked this case is because I like when cases have a "lip" on the front that sticks out to help protect the screen when laying the phone flat on a surface. This Diztronic case has a nice lip, probably about 1/8th of an inch. It's large enough to ensure adequate screen protection without being overly large to make the phone uncomfortable to press against your ear. Perfect size.Also, I like the material the case is made from. It provides plenty of grip beyond what the stock phone offers (glass on both sides = slippery). It's just the right amount of grip in my opinion. Comfortable to hold without being so grippy that you can't smoothly slide it into or out of a pocket without it getting stuck on the lining of your pocket.I like the color as well, it looks good on the phone. Yes, as others have mentioned, the Diztronic logo on the back partially covers the "LG" logo behind it, which is still visible since the case is translucent. Who cares??? I know what brand my own phone is, and I don't care if other people can see it. I'm not sure why this would bother anyone. You can still see "NEXUS" perfectly fine on the back below the camera...that should be good enough.All cutouts on the case are perfectly sized and line up well with the openings on the phone. The case covers the volume/power buttons, but actually makes them easier to find and press than they are on the stock phone. If it were up to me, I would have made the buttons even slightly larger to make them even easier to press. But as it stands, they've improved over the stock phone, so no issues there.Also, one last note, this case will still allow the phone to work on wireless charging mats without needing to pop the phone out every time you lay it down. Excellent to know for those of you who use a mat on a regular basis.All in all, especially considering the price, I am thrilled with the case. Diztronic even followed up by email after my purchase to make sure I was satisfied. I'll definitely be looking at their products in the future anytime I need a case for a new phone.

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-17: **12/25/2012 Update** I got to say that my replacement case is much much better than the initial one I received. It truly looks and feels seamless now and most of the initial issues I had are fixed. Looks like I just initially received a bad case. All the edges are smooth and feel very comfortable, though overall it still feels rather smooth and "slick" but it's not a huge deal. Clay & Diztronic customer support went above and beyond helping me out with the issue, they were super friendly and super quick to respond. I got a replacement sent out right away and received it in just a few days. This just solidifies my choice of sticking with Diztronic now and in the future. Thanks!I'm a HUGE Diztronic fan. I have Diztronic cases on all my phones and all my families phones. They're fantastic and I really wanted to love the hard shell case, but I just couldn't. The case is super slick and slides out of my hand rather easily. I dropped my phone for the first time picking it up off the dresser, luckily the drop was only a couple of feet onto carpet. The corners where the seams meet are rather rough and are irritating to my fingers. Also there were a few sharp bumps on the inside of the case that left a small imprint on the back of my phone, luckily I have a rear skin on it and it soon worked it self out. The bumps are invisible to the naked eye, but are very noticeable if you rub your finger over it, I'm sure it's just a minor defect in my particular case. And I hate to say it, but I'd rather not have cut outs for the volume and power, I'm not sure if it's just the way the phone is designed, but it just feels slightly "harder" to get your finger in there to hit the buttons, most notably on the power button. I did love how thin the case felt though and it fit perfect with a Skinomi front & rear protector installed. It also felt much better than having the official bumper on, but the flaws were just too irritating to keep the case on. Maybe a later revision will fix some of the quirks, like it being too smooth and maybe making the cut outs for the volume and power slightly larger. I'm still a big fan and will keep the case and try it out some more, maybe it will grow on me.

    2013-03-15: I haven't used a case in years, because I like the feel like cases tend to get in the way and aren't worth the hassle. I have bought and discarded many cases, however, because I've never found one for any phone that I really liked. With the glass back on the Nexus 4 I knew that I'd better get a case. Any drop with this phone would probably result in a crack or nasty scratch. It's just too fragile to leave without a case. I like this case, because it has built in buttons for power and volume rather than cut outs. Cut outs make it much harder to press buttons. This case actually makes it easier to use the buttons. I haven't found that the case hinders the phone's usability at all. It is easily pocketable and it provides great protection. The case doesn't creak like some cases I've tried. The lip on the front of the phone isn't overly obtrusive, but it is raised enough to give some added grip and protection for the screen when dropped. I'm glad I went with a case that has the full wrap around lip, rather than the super thin cases that only cover the sides of the phone. I dropped my phone onto concrete the other day, and I watched it in slow-mo as it bounced off my leg and went tumbling to the ground where it landed face down. My phone had no damage whatsoever. The case lip showed a tiny bit of scuffing, but that's what it's there for. Great case. I'd highly recommend it to anyone.

    2013-03-05: The stock Google bumper-style case, which I also have, leaves the back uncovered to show off the glass rear cover with its "sparkles".Unfortunately I kept brushing my fingers and palm against the lens porthole, leaving smears. There was no cover with porthole cut-out for the lens, to help me index my fingers and to keep my palm off the lens.So I picked this back-covering case up for less than $10 and I am very pleased with it - it is hardshell polycarbonate so it is ultra light and ultra thin. It has a matte finish which makes it a little grippier. The front edge is slightly raised off the glass so you can set this glass-down on a nightstand without worry. All controls are easy to operate and earphones fit in fine. The one caveat is that the top and bottom edges are left mostly uncovered (this is a "tray style" design that clamps on the left and right edges and leaves the top and bottom mostly exposed). I thought there was no logo on the back, but at the bottom there is one subtly embossed. Very understated.If you want slightly better edge protection you will want to get the stock Google case (which is bumper style, wrapping around all four edges) or the TPU version of this case, theDiztronic Matte Back Black Flexible TPU Case for LG Nexus 4 - Retail Packaging. The TPU edition is made of softer, thicker material and covers all edges. It also covers the on-off switch and volume controls, which is both a blessing and a curse - fewer "accidental ons" but more pressure required when you actually intend to operate a switch or rocker. For other devices I have owned both styles, hardshell polycarbonate and TPU, and my preferences shift from time to time and mood to mood - the hardshells always look thinner and better, but the TPU entices with promises of better protection.The reviewer who noted that the bottom edge is a little sharp on his pinky (due to being cut away to a small piece), and after reading his review I confirm that he is right, but I grip the phone slightly differently and for my primary use (landscape mode for internet and texts) it is a non-issue. He and another reviewer (at least one other reviewer) also noticed that there is extra cutout space on the top of the speaker slot, but the bottom butts up to, or slightly covers, the bottom-most portion of the speaker slot. I probably wouldn't have noticed but for their reviews, and while this is aesthetically slightly imprecise, it has no effect on the speaker, which has plenty of uncovered slot to blast through. I have more of an issue with rear-firing speakers on phones (and tablets) that easily double in volume if I cup my hand behind them to redirect the sound forward.Other than that, I'll avoid my usual loquaciousness - this is an elegant, minimalist case that does it's job and actually dresses up the phone.

    Rating: 5

    2013-02-27: I liked this cover very much even though it could be made slightly better.Pro's1. Thin2. Pretty sparkly design3. Tight fit (yet easy to get on)Con's1. No corner protection or buffer built in2. Rear monogram needs to go or at least be moved up

    Rating: 4

    2013-04-17: I bought this same brand of cover for my previous cell (skyrocket) since i obtained a stylish, functional cover and decided to stick with the brand.The nexus 4 is no exception, this cover has a perfect fix, feels great on the hand and looks awesome. as well as my s2 cover, this one seems to offer a sturdy protection which nexus users know they need to have.5/5

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-21: This case is pretty OK. It's slim and provides an acceptable protection bumper. I think the JKase provides better overall protection and the kickstand is a nice feature.I dislike the same thing about both cases though, it requires a very firm press to actuate the power button. I got used to slimmer cases where the power button was either exposed or the cutout for it was excellent.

I love the thickness of this case, it really adds some minimalist protection while still having rigidity. Buy this is you have a nexus 4!

But honestly, it's overlookable, considering what a great product this is.

    Rating: 4

    2012-12-12: I just received it today, I have to say its better designed that it looks in picture. I liked to cut out design on Galaxy Nexus Rev 3, so I was not sure about this Nexus 4 case design. Actually buttons are design with spring action, so its every easy to press, but pop back like TV Remote with no effort. However, buttons are easy to press, I feel they are small, they need to be a tiny bit bigger, not much, just a little bit. In addition, case fits very tightly, and have to make an effort to pull it out. WHICH I THINK IS GOOD, I prefer all cases made like that. I would highly recommend it. GO FOR IT.     2014-07-06: I've tried 3 cases listed on Amazon for my Nexus 4. This one is the best! The TPU feels great and it looks great. It doesn't collect lint from my pocket or anything.     Rating: 5

    2013-02-09: I've used this a few days so far for my Google Nexus 4 and I really like it. I can't give it 5 stars yet because I want to see how it lasts. That aside, this case is somewhat unique. I've used smart phone covers for years and they tend to be either very flexible (even flimsy) when they are made out of silicon or way too hard (plastic-y) and offer little to no protection.DIZTRONIC seems to find the perfect sweet spot. I don't know if it will get loose over time that is my only worry and at $12-13 bucks I was leery but if it holds up and doesn't lose it's shape and tightness than this product will EASILY be 5 stars, but right now I'll say 4 just to see how it holds up. That said, honestly the other cases for the Nexus 4 look kinda crappy and cheap so I would pay the extra couple bucks on go with this one.I do regret a bit getting the smoke color, it makes the case look a little cheaper than it is. It's an aesthetic thing and it was totally my decision, but if I had to do it again I would go with solid black. One last thing, the FEEL of the case is PERFECT! It doesn't fingerprint or (so far) get greasy from natural hand oils like the more flimsy silicon cases do....an update after some time. Peace.

    $B0047ELBOE

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2011-12-27: I don't think this case is useless, but it is of limited use. This comes in two somewhat separate parts, the handlebar assembly and a removable case assembly. If you take the "case" off the handlebar assembly, you have to snap it back into place perfectly or it will fall off quite easily at the first bump in the road.That being said, if you make sure the assembly is secure, it really is secure. It normally takes me a few times of removing and putting it back before it won't fall off. I check this before I ride every time, even though I never take the case off. It seems like if I bump it just right in my garage, it gets loose again. I'm glad my phone has an insurance policy.I can operate my phone somewhat through the plastic, but it is hard to do when you're riding. I mostly wanted it to display my runkeeper stats while cycling, so that's not a problem for me. The ball joint is adjustable so I haven't had a major problem with glare (a little is to be expected).Overall a good case. I wish the case assembly and handlebar assembly were a single piece, but I guess I can see where others would want to remove the whole case when parking their bikes (personally, I just take the phone out).

The case zipper shuts with a flap that covers the zipped part. It has a cross access slit for cables or headphone cable. If you remove the inserts it's large enough to fit phone and small wallet or other small items.     2011-12-01: I read a lot about how the case was extremely hard to get on, and yes, it is a challenge to fit the thing on the phone. Plus I got 6 rather than 5 screen protectors...came in handy considering I had to go through about 3 to get it on without bubble. I recommend Windex to clean the screen to an immaculate level and then a credit card to start from the bottom, and slowly apply the protector with the credit card.

    Rating: 5

    2011-12-01: I'm coming from a D30 case that I bought for $30 from a local Tmobile store.First thing's first though. Putting this case on, you'll find that it fits perfectly around the phone. It fits easily, without actually falling out when you don't want it to. There is also a lifting edge around the screen, so that it doesn't contact the surface you set it on (I think this is pretty standard now).The one gripe I have is that the microphone, next to the usb charging port, is partially covered by the case. This is nothing a razor can't fix, but it's disappointing that it wasn't engineered perfectly!The reason I switched to this case from the D30 was because of the buttons, they were covered by the D30 and not easy to press. Cutouts are a huge plus and make the phone feel a lot easier and funner to use. However, when compared to the D30, the Diztronic feels a bit flimsy and lacking in the protection area.All in all, I like the case, especially for the price! But I may try keep looking as new cases come out (Incipio looks promising).**** EDIT 1/6/2012Changing to 5-star because they listened and made the hole on the bottom of the phone bigger to make room for the microphone. Also, I ended up switching to the D30 for a while, but couldn't stand the largeness of it, or the annoyance of having to press the buttons so hard. I'm sticking with this case for a while.

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-26: I've been using Diztronic for TPU cases for about a year now and I must say they are great! It's a slim fitting case with a great lifespan! I haven't had any problems and it still looks new even after a year of use!

    Rating: 5

    2012-10-04: I used this with a T-Mobile pre-paid Galaxy S2 for a few days and it was great. Since I didn't have phone insurance I wanted to make sure I protected my investment from dents and scratches and I was confident this would provide that protection even though I never did drop the phone with it installed. It adds minimal bulk, is comfortable to hold, and is very easy to remove. I ended up selling the phone and giving the case to my grandmother who got an S2 of her own shortly before I did. If she has any issues with it I'll be sure to update this review. I'd definitely recommend it for the price.

    2013-03-07: Received the, Diztronic Matte Back Black Flexible *Revision 2* TPU Case for Samsung Galaxy S II, and easily slid my phone into it.     Rating: 4

    2012-09-07: The reviews here say it all. Not much more I can add. I have this Diztronic case for my Galaxy S2 and I also have one for my HTC Amaze. They both work and they work well. I like them better than silicon cases because they do not attract pocket lint the same way. They may not be a soft, but it does provide scratch protection. I value thinness and comfort in my pocket over the protection since I'm pretty good with with phone. Don't toss it too much, just on soft surfaces like my bed.

    Rating: 5

    2012-03-01: For the unaware, TPU is a material that is essentially a blend between plastic hard cases and soft silicone cases. It's flexible like silicone, but it's smooth like plastic. The fit is great, it has perfectly cut openings for both the top and bottom mic holes and all the buttons are easily accessible. I'm guessing that the reviews that say that the case covers the mic or has incorrect cuts is for the first revision, but with this current revision (revision 2) I can confirm that all the holes are cut perfectly.As for the utility of the case, it depends on what you're looking for. It will serve perfectly fine in preventing your phone from getting scratched or dinged, but since it's less "gel" like than silicone and leans more towards plastic in that respect, it's impact resistance I would imagine is pretty low. If you drop your phone on concrete, expect a lot of shock to course through your phone (which might not actually damage it, but certainly has the potential to) but your phone will emerge scratch free from the drop. The benefit of having a slicker/harder surface than silicone is that it doesn't stretch (it is flexible enough to apply, but won't stretch permanently like silicone if you play with it too much) and it will slide in and out of your pocket with ease. I always avoid silicone cases because they stretch and catch on the inside of my pocket.Overall a great fitting case and if it fits your needs (read: if you don't drop your phone from large heights often) it will do the job. Only slight issue I have with the case is cosmetic, with this color (matte black) the front half is glossy while the back half is matte. Presumably it looks that way to match the glossy glass of the front better, but I'm personally not a huge fan of glossy in general, and certainly not such an obtrusive color change halfway through the case.

    Rating: 5

  • B009X9ZBRQ

    $B009X9ZBRQ

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2012-12-13: Just got the dock today and I have to say that I was really impressed. This unit was provided to me for review. At first, I thought it was going to be a Samsung Galaxy version of the Bose iPod/iPhone docking station but this is a beast of its own.I really liked the fact that once you dock the Note 2, you have a cute little remote control to control everything. I thought that was very clever. Even without the remote, I still liked how you could control the volume at the base. The whole design of the station is very aesthetically pleasing. The installation manual that you get is straight forward but I had a little bit of difficulty getting it to work right away. I guess this is my fault for not being tech savvy. I even had to contact support to troubleshoot it but they were kind and courteous enough to help via email. The problem I had was to get the sound to play out of the dock speakers once it was in the dock. My fault for not knowing this but you have to make sure your phone is set up properly first (On the Note 2, Settings => System => Accessory => checkmark box audio output mode). Anyways, after I got it set up I was able to get everything to work very quickly.I do have one small complaint about the design though. The cradle that the phone sits in should be changed in some way. The cradle they put on is probably for a S2 cradle so I had to remove the S2 cradle and replace it with the Note 2 cradle (which is provided). However, the cradles seemed so flimsy that I was almost afraid to break it when I tried to take off the S2 cradle; and the way the Note 2 cradle snaps in is a little freaky to me but the phone fits like a glove in the cradle. My personal suggestion to future models is to have a one size fits all cradle if it were possible or to have an exchangeable cradle that slides versus snaps in. It feels like over time if you have to change cradles over time then it would snap or break. I think this is perfect for the person or persons who have the same style phone so you don't have to keep exchanging cradles.The sound quality of the system was great. I couldn't be happier. I was expecting a whiny pitchy kind of noise since the station was so small (like other stations) but quite surprisingly it sounded very full. I went ahead to stream some Netflix movies on there just for the heck of it and it was nice. I even tested the AUX cable and the quality was equally as good as if it was docked. There wasn't any pitchy or crackling noises in the background when it was on higher volumes so that made me happy. I didn't crank it ALL the way up just because I don't like the way any sound system sounds like that loud so I cannot comment on that. But overall, I was very happy with it.All in all if you are looking for a dock for your Galaxy, I think this is it. It sounds great and it's not outrageously priced like other systems I've seen out there; and won't give you that cheap pitchy sound like those lower end ones. A+ for me, just remember to get the settings right on the phone =)FOLLOW UP 12/14/12After a few days of testing and doing a side by side comparison to the Bose system, my wife notices that the sound generated from the gDock is more of a direct sound while the Bose has a more full surround sound effect. She felt that the room filled with more sound with the Bose. I just thought I'd share my wife's opinion because she has a better ear at music than I do. Still, I'm keeping my rating at 5 for the sound quality at the price point compared to other units; design and the functionality of the unit

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-19: Gdock is designed to be used as a docking station for use with Samsung Galaxy phones. It can also be used a speakers for any device if the device is connected via AUX IN port by audio cable (included). I received this unit from manufacture for testing purposes to write an unbiased and honest review. I tested this speaker with Android Phone, our two Android tablets (Nexus and Galaxy) as well as a computer speaker. You will find both positives and negatives I encountered during my testing.Gdock works with AC power source or alternatively can work through a lithium-ion rechargeable battery (sold separately). However, it recharges the phone only when plugged into the AC source. When it operates on the battery it only behaves as the speakers.I am attaching a collage of seven photos numbered 1 though 7 under customer photos that I will be referencing in this review.Photo #1 shows everything that comes in the box: Gdock, cradles, remove control, power cable, audio cable, power supply and cable.Gdock comes with 6 holders for Galaxy SIII, Galaxy Note, Galaxy SII SGH-T989, Galaxy SII GT-I9100 SGH-1777, Galaxy SOO SPH-D719. The GDock comes pre-installed with a cradel fro S III cradle. The cradle can be removed by sliding it up, and replaced with another cradle if needed. Photo #1 shows me sliding one of the cradles into the dock.Photo #2 shows the back of the unit, where in the center you see audio in and power connections. On the sides of the unit you see two bass ports for extending the bass performance.One of the things I found in testing is that the sound is significantly improved if you position the unit in a way that the sound coming out of these port holes has a solid surface to reflect from. The difference was significant and significantly improved my opinion of the sound quality.Photo #3 shows Gdock on the digital scale. It weights in at 3.3 pounds and feels significant and well built.Gdock comes with a remote control, which has the following operations:1. On/off2. Mute on/off3. Volume up and down4. Reset to factory settings5. Bass up and down6. Change audio from Aux In to Samsung Galaxy7. Treble up and downWhen the unit is turned on a blue LED light on the front of the speaker is turned on. This light is a bit subtle, it shines through the speaker cloth and I did not notice it right away. I put a red square around this light in picture #7 to bring it to your attention.PHONE TESTING (USB port):------------------------------To position the phone in the doc the phone is slid into the cradle from the top, through the arms of the cradle and inserted into the micro USB jack connector at the bottom of the cradle. The phone can be positioned either vertically or horizontally on the doc by rotating the docking port.Photo #4 shows the Nexus Galaxy phone I used for testing. Several important notes on the phone. The Nexus Galaxy phone is not officially listed as a supported phone. In addition the phone is normally used with an extra large battery which makes it significantly fatter than a standard battery. Despite the "unofficial" configuration I thought this test would be of interest to people who own this phone model.1) Two of the cradles fit the Nexus Galaxy phone with the standard battery: Galaxy SIII and Galaxy SI SGH-T989.2) When the phone had its extra large battery installed none of the cradles fit, but the unit could be inserted into the USB connection without the cradle. It made a good connection as indicated by the Battery App (see below). Photo #5 shows the side view of phone with the extra large battery on Gdock.Photo #6 show the phone charging. I used Battery App by Elvison to determine the device recognized the charging source. 'AC' status means the charging is at full charging rate. 'USB' status indicates charging at a lower charging rate. 'Discharging' status means that the charging rate is below the power that the device is consuming so it slows down the discharge rate but does not re-charge. The battery app showed that the phone is connected and is charging at USB rate. This is not surprising, since the USB connector has to be a data connector to carry music data to the speaker.Difference between a charging cable and a data cable:Charging cables short the two data connections together (rendering them useless for data transfer), but this fools devices to see them as an AC power connection, and thus accept the higher current of the charging source.SPEED OF CHARGING:Gdock USB source ... 1% charge in 10 minutes(by comparison AC source charges this phone 6% in 10 minutes)Photo #7 shows the phone playing music. However, Nexus Phone appears to be incompatible with the speaker. The speakers did not engage, even though the battery app showed that the phone was connected and recognized by Gdock. Since this phone was not officially listed as a supported phone I am not deducting any stars from the rating, but this finding was a surprise to me and I wanted to share it with other Nexus Galaxy phone owners.OTHER DEVICES (AUDIO IN port)------------------------------The rest of my experiments was using the audio jack on the back of the unit. I tested Gdock with Nexus 7 Tablet, Galaxy 7.7 Tablet, and as desktop computer speaker. As I mentioned earlier the key to getting good sound from this speaker is to put right agaist a wall or in our case a window pane. This really improved the bass performance. The front facing stereo speakers generate crisp and clear sound, the mid-range was very good. With speaker against the surface the bass sound was reasonable.When I was testing this speaker as a computer speaker I compared it (using the same piece of music and two different computers) to Cambridge Soundworks speakers and Labtec speakers.These speakers did not perform as well as my Cambridge Soundsworks but better than Labtec speakers.To summarize:------------------------------1. The mid-range of the speaker was very good, bass performance somewhat weaker but reasonable.2. Charging is at USB rate3. Speaker does not work with Galaxy Nexus phone, the charger does work.Ali Julia review

    Rating: 4

    2012-11-17: I set up this Grace Digital GDock in my office at work a few days ago, and have been enjoying listing to internet radio via Pandora and iHeartRadio apps ever since. Using my company cell phone (a Galaxy S3) and this speaker, we are able to listen to music throughout the whole office and into the back warehouse as well. The GDock comes with 5 different cradle adapters, for the Galaxy S1, S2, S3 and the Note 1 and 2. I use the adapter for the S3 with the GDock, which came with it already pre-installed. The S3 slides right into it, and plugs in at the base. Each of the docks can also be rotated sideways, which in turn sets your device screen on landscape view.The speaker has power buttons and volume buttons on both the GDock itself (at the top) and also on the wireless remote control that comes with it. The remote is small, not much larger than the palm of my hand. It would easily fit into a pants pocket. You can also adjust the treble and bass or mute the speaker, all from the remote. A battery is included, so you won't need to buy one for the remote control prior to using it.The included auxiliary cable plugs into the back of the speaker, allowing you to use all kinds of other (non-Galaxy) devices. We've used the auxiliary cable with several other players so people could listen to their play-lists. We've used MP3 players, iPods, Kindle Fires, etc. All have worked great!The speaker is weighty and feels solid. Not cheap and flimsy at all. It comes with a wall power adapter, and there is also an optional rechargeable battery made for this speaker (sold separately). When your device is plugged into the speakers dock, it will play your music and also charge your Galaxy at the same time, assuming you're using the wall adapter to power it. After reading through the included information, I did see that if you're using the optional rechargeable battery with this GDock and it's not plugged in to the wall adapter as well, it will just play music and not charge your device at the same time. This way, the power in the rechargeable battery is saved for running the speaker for as long as possible.This GDock has been great to have in the office, and everyone loves it. It works well, sounds great and will play music as loudly or as softly as we want it. Even right now I'm downloading a playlist of Christmas music to my phone, so we can have it playing in the office for the holidays on the GDock. I was provided a sample unit from the manufacturer for an unbiased review of its performance. Grace Digital makes a wide variety of nice speaker docks, including one for the Kindle Fire called theMatchStick. I have that one as well and use it all the time at home, having it set up in my kitchen. Because of their versatility and quality, they are some of my favorite speakers and would definitely recommend them to anyone.

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-15: I'm familiar with the Grace Digital dock for the original Kindle Fire. But, while it had a number of great features, it didn't work well for me since the on/off button would not properly engage with the Kindle. So I was very interested to try out their new dock for the Samsung Galaxy/Note.Very pleased! Everything feels substantial, especially the phone cradles. It comes with a total of 5 cradles to fit the Galaxy S2, S3 and Note. I'm using the dock mainly with my S2, but also borrowed a Note to try that out (worked well). The cradles hold the phone securely, and rotate for either landscape or portrait viewing. I found it very easy to swap out cradles (no tools are needed).The dock itself can be flipped so it either rests on its side or on its back. It has non-slip pads on the both the base and the back of the dock to help keep it from sliding. I found you can also stand it on its end without any problems. It's not designed for this, so it's not the most stable position, but it's workable for me (I keep it on a small shelf above my desk, so space is at a premium).The power cord plugs into the back of the dock. I very much like that it does not have a wall wart at the end of the plug, but rather has an inline transformer. The cord that plugs into the dock is permanently attached to the transformer; the cord that plugs into the wall has a conventional 2-prong plug. You still have to deal with a transformer (it's a rectangular box about 2 inches by 4 inches, and about 1 inch thick) but it's not at the end of the plug where it would block other outlets.It comes with a slim remote that controls volume, power, bass and treble. You can also use it to switch to the aux input (more on that later). The remote does not control or interface with the phone - it only controls the features on the dock. It includes the flat battery (CR2025 size) which is a nice touch.The sound quality is quite good. Not audiophile good, but better than other docks I've tried in this price range. I very much like that the bass and treble are adjustable. In fact, be sure to play with them right when you first use the dock - the EQ settings on mine were really out of whack when I first set it up, with no bass output at all. Once adjusted, however, the bass output was much better.It has two 3 inch full-range speakers. Although the speakers are powered with an impressive 16 watts, a full-range speaker is just not going to provide room-filling thumping bass nor ultra-clear highs. If you want that you'll need to look elsewhere (and dig a lot deeper in your wallet to pay for it). But given the g dock's price point I'm more than pleased with the sound quality.It has an aux input so you can plug in anything that has a standard 1/4 inch plug. I've tried it using a Sandisk MP3 player and a Kindle Fire. Works well and extends the usefulness of the dock beyond just a Samsung phone dock. It includes a male/male cord that is of pretty decent quality.It has the ability to run off of a battery pack that is sold separately. That was not included with my review unit so I can't provide any details about it. I see that Amazon has one for the Kindle Fire dock (Grace Digital Matchstick for Kindle Fire Rechargeable Battery Pack) but I don't know if that is the right one for this dock. I imagine it is, but will check with the manufacturer and report back. Having the battery pack is a great feature for portability. Note, however, that the battery pack only powers the dock and will not power or recharge the phone. The dock has to be plugged in for the latter.[UPDATE: The manufacturer got back to me very quickly, and confirmed that the Matchstick battery will work with the gdock]The main misses are with the controls. Or rather, the control indicator lights. The trend in many electronics these days is to have piercing indicator lights that appear much like miniature lighthouse beacons in a dark room. I really hate that! But, ironically, I'm not found of the g-dock's approach of having very muted indicator lights. They are covered by the speaker cloth which makes them even more difficult to see. This is not a major flaw since you can see them if you're close to the dock. Plus the remote covers all the bases if you're farther away from the dock. But I'd still like a more visible power indicator to remind me to turn it off. I also wish it had larger control buttons, and had better quality speaker cloth (or, better yet, metal mesh).But those minor issues aside, I think this is a great dock. Solid performance and nice design touches. Highly recommend.[The manufacturer provided me with this product for review]

    Rating: 5

    2013-03-29: I got this unit a few days ago. Note that the unit comes with a Samsung Galaxy S3 adapter installed. I have an S2. It was quite easy to snap off the installed adapter and install the included S2 adapter. I also purchased the battery attachment. That was also easy to install.First impressions: It looks good on my desk. The phone connects easily & powers up / charges ok. Note: It is not easy to quickly pop the phone out of the dock when a call is incoming. A better approach is to leave the phone attached overnight for charging & then pop it out for daytime phone usage. I'm still working out the best pattern of use. Pop-out directions: Place your fingers of both hands on the top of the dock. Then gently place your thumbs on the lower edges of the phone & gently lever the phone up & out of the dock. This will ensure a longer lasting connection (that being the thing most likely to break on the phone (unless you drop the puppy, of course).I haven't tried the music operation, the remote control, or other features yet. ... I'll add to this review in a week, or so, when I have more time to play with it. Right now, I'm quite happy with the unit. ....Warning: Verify that you have a compatible device before purchasing. It comes with a bunch of adapters, please ensure that your phone is one that this device has an adapter for in it's collection.-----Important Note: After using this dock, I have noticed one thing that you will need to be aware of about it. When the phone reaches a 100% charge, it turns the screen on. This may be a function of the phone, but it is a bit annoying to place the tablet into the dock in the evening, turn the screen off (sleep mode) & then later see that the screen has turned on.-----One other thing: I have been using the unit for a few weeks now & it has a very important (unintended) feature! Here's the scoop: I have seen many folks break/snap-off the USB connector on their cell phones when they connect the USB connector to recharge the phone. This is caused by the slight twisting of the plug as it is inserted. The Grace Digital unit's slide eliminates this. You simply place the phone on the holder & gently push down on the phone & PRESTO! the phone is connected. Removing it is even easier. Just place your hands on the unit, your thumbs on the bottom of the phone & gently squeeze. Out pops the phone. No torque. No stress. No damage.

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-18: Some people might think that the gdock is simply another gizmo that really isn't need, but far from it. If you tried or purchased Grace Digital'sCharging Speaker Dock for the Kindle Fire, and you have a Galaxy S2, S2 or Note, you'll definitely be interested in this dock as well. You can simultaneously charge your Samsug and stream your choice of audio.One of the nicest features is the Aux-in. If you want you can plug in any audio source sources. For example, if you have something special on your iPad you can connect. The speakers have surprisingly good sound and the bass and treble can be tweaked with the small, wafer-thin remote. Mind you, the sound is not high-end, but is high quality and enjoyable.There are several dock adapters, each of which can be rotated in a vertical (portrait) or horizontal (landscape) manner. You can also can control your view angle to either 38 or 50 degrees. I do like the fact that the gdock is not only a versatile device, but also a sleek and attractive one.If you subscribe to "Stereophile" you need not apply here, but if you want a really nice dock that charges your phone and plays audio from your Samsung at home or in your office you'll love it. The warranty is for one year and, as most companies, comes with the expectation that you'll take reasonably good care of the unit. Grace Digital, in my experience, is one of the more highly responsive companies to work with. If I have a question or comment ... they're there.WHAT'S IN THE BOX:* Speaker Dock for Galaxy S2, S3 & Note* 5 phone Dock Adapters* Remote Control* AC Power Adapter* 3.5 mm Audio Cable* User manual (booklet)FEATURES:* Speaker Dock For Galaxy S2, S3 & Note* Charges Phone while Docked* Rotating Cradle for Vertical and Horizontal Viewing* Class D Amplifier with 16 Watts Power Output* Dual Full Range 3" Stereo Speakers* Full Featured Remote Control* Aux-in with 3.5 mm Audio Cable* Portable Operation with Optional Battery Pack**Note: TheRechargeable Battery Packthat works both for theGrace Digital Matchstickas well as this unit (Item model number: ACC-GFDLI). When you are using the Gdock to power your unit, it won't charge the Galaxy.SPECS:* Class D digital amplifier, 16 watts.* 100-240V, 12V 2A switching power supply* S/N ratio: 89dB* Frequency response: 60HZ - 18Hz +/- 3dB* Channels: 2 (stereo)* Speaker drivers: 3" Full range x 2* Dimensions: 13" x 3.8" x 4.3"*Rechargeable Lithium-ion Battery Pack7.4V DC, 220mAh, 2SP (sold separately)This product courtesy of Grace Digital without expectation of a positive review.

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-06: This product over exceeded my expectations. It was simple to put together. My Samsung Galaxy sIII fits perfectly into the holder (there are 3 other holders to fit other Samsung products; Galaxy sII, Galaxy Note I and II, etc... In another review, the writer states that your phone does not fit in the holder if it has "clothes" on--meaning a phone case/cover. However, I own two, thin, Galaxy sIII "skins" in different colors with a flap that goes over the face of the phone for added protection. I did not have to take the cover off to dock my Galaxy sIII. It fit perfectly and docks very easily both inserting and removing--no forceful pushing or pulling.The sound is surprisingly good. My living room is central to the rest of my house, and I could hear the music from every other room I was in--including the basement. Nice bass and treble balance with a remote control, that is no bigger than a credit card, that allows you to adjust bass and treble levels as well as volume.The product itself is very nice looking. Sleek design, and with my phone docked into it with the flap over the face of the phone, you can hardly tell there is another device attached to the speaker system.I highly recommend this product as a mid-range price performance purchase.

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-16: Finally "Galaxy S" or "Galaxy Note" owners have their counterpart to any of the "iHome" or "iPhone" docking systems. This is a beauty. Perfectly sized for the desktop, it is simple and clean. Your Phone or Note fits the proprietary male plug (Micro USB Jack Connector) easily and there are four different cradles to attach to your gdock depending on what device you have.The stereo speakers (3" each) have an arguably better sound (both treble, midrange and bass) than the iHome desktops and I own two. It matches the sound of theGrace Digital MatchStick (GDI-GFD7200) Charging Speaker Dock for Kindle Fire - Portrait and Landscape Modesin that department. There is a wafer thin remote that only adjusts the volume, bass, treble and EQ (resets to factory equalizer setting) as well as the power. The back of the gdock has two Bass Ports and that is what gives it such a strong firm bass. You'll want these exposed in the back and not on the bottom of the unit.The gdock is attractively sleek with a black fabric finish. The docks rotate and lock from 38 degrees to 50 degrees depending on how you want your device to look. You can even choose two positions to set your entire gdock - although it's only a matter of an inch or two differences. The power light is a tiny blue LED and is hard to see unless it is very dark.The power connector is one of those double cables with a black box the size of a cigarette case, but that's fairly minor. You can charge your device and battery when the gdock is plugged into a wall source, but it won't charge your device (phone) from just the gdock battery. The back has a battery door for the OPTIONAL lithium battery which is sold separately. I did not get one, but it is supposed to last up to six hours.If you want to plug another device into your gdock, there is the standard 3.5mm insert in the back. An Aux-In cable is supplied for this.The price is comparable to any other docking units on the market, but I think the selling point for the gdock is the multiple cradles included and the absolutely great sound. Mind you, it's not really loud, but plenty for any room. By the way, if you want an alarm clock, just use your Galaxy phone.Grace Digital Inc. was kind enough to supply a unit for review.

    Rating: 5

    2013-05-27: PROS:average sizegood soundminimal light output3 docking optionsincludes remote and aux-in cordCONS:no clockno AM/FM radio optionwill not fit phone (Note II) with slimline TPU caselarge AC adapter box on the cord...not ideal for small spacesremote is tinyno headphone jackI really liked this dock. Mine must have been defective because it would pop every few seconds similar to when a speaker has been blown. It happened straight out of the box, and since the dock would not fit my phone with the case, and I didn't realize there was not a radio built in, I decided to return instead of exchange.     2013-08-29: I have had mediocre experience at best with Anker. Three bad chargers (so far), and the batteries tend to fall apart.     2013-06-09: I'm reviewing the Anker 5200 mah battery and rear cover for the Galaxy S4 on a Canadian Galaxy S4. I have the blue rear cover that matches my blue phone perfect. This product review took a few unexpected turns as I will point out.First item, after MANY years of buying Anker products because I've loved their quality, I was offered to test and review this battery for free. This will not influence my positives and criticisms of the product!Shipping of the product was very quick. The turn around time from confirmation of shipping to actually receiving the product was 3 days. Very pleasing considering that my stock battery lasted just over half a day. I was eager to get this battery.Packaging and unboxing is above what I've seen from other products. The kit comes in a nice package, not some cheap cardboard box with stuff rattling inside. This is a nice clear plastic package with the warranty info, instructions, the battery and rear cover. Packaging you would expect of a higher quality retail product.The battery is obviously bigger but not anything unexpected from a double capacity battery. The rear cover material felt sturdy but I was nervous of its durability. That was put to rest a couple of times and finally today absolute.The battery fits perfect in the phone, secure. The rear cover snaps on nice and tight with no creaking or looseness. A couple of very smart additions to the rear cover have been added. A port extending to the speaker inside the back makes sound as good as stock. Bass actually seems a little improved but that's negligible. A small bump on the outside of the rear cover located at the speaker may help lift the phone slight enough so when laid flat the speaker is not completely covered. Two small but great additions that show some proper engineering was involved.The slightly increased thickness of the phone actually greatly increases comfort and I personally prefer the shape to stock since it fits the hand naturally.Performance. I received the battery at 57% charge. I did a nasty thing and ran it from 57% charge to empty without charging it first out of the box and it lasted longer then the stock battery when fully charged. (Follow the proper instructions and charge properly) So then I did the full charge. I was blown away. I expected double the life but I've been getting easily better then double. So I decided to turn all the features on. Still over double the stock battery. A very interesting outcome indeed.So I performed another charge and now I've overclocked the phone to 2.2 Ghz from 1.9 Ghz, plus some other go fast CPU tricks. A real battery killer setup I will admit.Results are two full days of use and counting on one charge. Again overclocked and heavy use. How is 35+ hours and 11+ hrs screen on and I still have 25%. Message me for screen shots if desired.Oh and the rear cover durability. I've dropped my phone 4 times this week alone, twice on concrete. Four foot+ drops and the rear cover just today has developed a small crack. To be fair, the phone bezel had gotten chipped and the edge of the screen is now damaged but the Anker rear cover just snapped right back into place and still fits like brand new. The tiny crack is not even noticeable.Would I recommend this. Definitely. I have been recommending, for many years, Anker products because they perform EXCELLENT.Again I've been buying Anker for years before this review and the reason is because I've never had better quality from other products.

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-30: Every Android phone I get, I always get an extended battery. The stock battery just never has enough juice to get me through the day, no matter what! And why should I have to turn off all the fun features of the phone just to save battery? I ordered this and it is perfect. The color matches my white S4 perfectly and the case is a slick plastic. Very nice in my opinion. I ordered a Hyperion extended battery case and it fit this extended battery perfectly. A case is a necessity to me and it doesn't make the phone any bulkier. Battery gets me through the day with HEAVY usage with about 50% at the end of the day. If I didn't have access to a charger I could easily make this last two whole days with heavy usage! Love it!

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-18: Im very happy with this extended battery.     Rating: 4

    2013-10-16: It delivers what it promises, last twice long the stock battery and when I come to my house later in the night the phone still have 50% left of battery. BUT BEWARE, this is not for gaming, probably with this battery you could get straight between 4 yo 5 hours of gaming.

    Rating: 5

    2014-03-06: In fairness, I knew going in that this was a larger battery, and required a special back on the case. I use third-party folio-type cases on my phone most of the time, which provides a bit of protection when the phone is dropped. (Alas, that happens.) The battery works well, but for me, the inability to fit it all into a case is a liability. I don't expect to use it much. We have a regular-sized battery from Anker also, and it is working just fine.

    Rating: 4

    2013-09-18: I'm a veteran of extended batteries and if you go cheap you get what you pay for. This one from Anker I thought I could say was the exception as they are a direct competitor of EZOPower in the alternative power market for cell phones and they make a good product. I'm obviously in error mainly because of the advertised mAh value of 5200.If you are familiar with your stock battery and its performance the first few weeks you'll know that if you download any battery widgets you are rated for roughly 22-23 hours of use by any measure. Actually using the phone degrades this a great deal however, I've tried several widgets and the phone battery gauge. Nothing points to this giving ANY additional power from the OEM 2600mAh battery during the first week of operation.I did notice after it was rated at 100% charged that the phone notated it not being "fully charged" for another hour and ten minutes, which I've never seen with any other battery however the discharge cycle is the exact same length as an OEM 2600mAh battery. That basically makes it an oversize OEM replacement with no discernible benefits other than adding the ability to use it as a bludgeon and I've got much cheaper rocks outside than a $600 phone.Overall it is an utter disappointment and no stretch of the imagination is going to stretch this battery's capacity. I have let it charge for 11 hours and still, even rated fully charged by any of the calculation apps, it is just...the same as the factory battery on a good day. The Seidio is rated for less but likely is at least what it claims to be. I'll consider it next after returning this. I give it 1 star.UPDATE:After interacting with Anker Customer Service and getting another battery to try I can say the performance is much better. I've used it a few days now, going on a week, and while the "Not Fully Charged" phenomenon still persists, the rate of idle discharge is far lower and it easily survives a shift and a half of use in low reception areas (which drains a phone far faster than if you have full signal strength or WiFi to use) and it still charges about as fast as the stock battery (which I do not have a reason for but can certainly appreciate). Certainly a turn around for the battery and I have nothing but good things to say about the Customer Service Representatives who assisted me. I can safely recommend this product to friends at this point. I'll give it 4 stars because it is really nice but I got a bad one to start so take that as it comes. Sometimes batteries are inconsistent.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-11: Having dropped my previous phone (a Note II) and cracking the screen I wanted a case that would provide superior protection for the Note 3 that replaced it. When I discovered this case I had to have one and am thrilled with it because it does everything I want.Foremost, it protects the screen because the case's bumper is slightly raised and there is a protective screen that provides another layer of protection. This is a two piece case plus a plastic holster that clips to a belt. The holster provides yet another layer of protection because the phone clips screen side into the casing of that component.The next layer of protection comes from the hard plastic inner case that has a soft, cushioning layer of material where your phone's battery cover contacts the surface of this case, and an outer cushion of neoprene-like material that will absorb some shock.All of the phone's functions are easily accessible, and the total area of the screen can be used, Even the S-Pen can be accessed, so this will not hamper normal phone operation.The protective screen is not as crystal clear as I would like, but I'll easily trade that for the protection that it provides. Believe me, if you ever crack a screen on a phone you will be willing to accept some compromises when it comes to protecting the screen on your next phone.While this is not waterproof, it will keep some moisture out as well as dust. The major feature, though, is protection in more hostile environments and this case provides that exceptionally well. It certainly gives me peace of mind.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-15: Incipio's NGP material is just like the polycarbonate feel the Incipio Dual Pro only slightly more flexible. As many other users have said taking the case off is quite a challenge but it doesn't bother me. Personally, I hated the feel of the Dual Pro. Not sure why but holding my iPhone with that case gave me goose bumps. I probably should have done my research before buying the OVRMLD but in a way I'm glad I went with it. Since its slightly more flexible the texture feels more smoother than the hard polycarbonate feel of the Dual Pro. Protection is at its max while still keeping the phone slim. It doesn't go scratch the screen so a screen protector shouldn't lift. I have this case and the MobC Oleophobic with no lift problems.Overall, it's a great case with maximum protection but still maintain the slim factor of the IPhone 5. Included you will find a case, screen protector, microfiber cloth and a handy phone stand. Great buy if you can get it under $17.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-01: So to start with the good, this is a pretty sturdy case and fits very tightly and snugly around the iPhone. The case overall feels nice in the hand and getting the phone into it is pretty easy as it form fits the phone and just snaps in place. The bevels around the camera are nicely done.Now for the bad. It's very, very difficult to get the phone out of this case. The material is such that while it bends and conforms around the phone, it's too rigid when it comes to prising the phone out. It took some amount of bending and effort to get it off. It will eventually come off but I noticed that each time I removed the case, the stretching and bending it took to get it out started to damage the plastic, particularly around the the back near the raised logo piece. Also, not sure if it was related to the effort of getting the phone out, but the coating on the case started to peel around the bottom after only a two weeks of use. One final minor bit of criticism is that the ports on the bottom of the phone for speaker and microphone are not actually covered using this case. They are open slots. This isn't really a big deal and it does make sense to have them open to avoid blocking them, but i must say my current case covers them and has holes for sound and I much prefer this as it offers protection from dust etc.

    Rating: 3

    2013-01-14: I received the case today but it does not look brand new, someone has returned it. I can see crack at the bottom. Now, I can see many people mentioned this case is hard to remove. I can see the previous person tried to remove it and cracked the bottom. I returned this case same day and purchased the Incipio Dualpro.

    Rating: 1

    $B0045U4AJI

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2012-11-24: I chose this to use with my I phone, I havn't used it yet because when I purchased it I assumed it would be nice with my phone cover, unfortunately it does not fit with the cover, bling on the phone. I am sure it works well but did not suit my purpose.

    Rating: 3

    2011-12-23: I had an iPhone 3GS and also had the Elago stand for that phone. With that set up you could have an Elago S3 case on your phone AND it still fit in the aluminum stand! Great! I thought, when I bought an iPhone 4S. I got an Elago S4 slim case and then ordered one of these thinking I would get the same fit. Well, they didn't stick to their previous design. This stand will only work on a BARE iPhone 4S. It's my own fault I guess for not digging into it a little deeper but when I bought this there weren't any previews letting me know this anyway.

    Rating: 3

    2013-01-01: Works very well for the iPhone but if you have on a case you will have to remove it to actually use the stand. Overall it's a great product!

    Rating: 4

    2014-01-13: Small things mount Big , this gadget i love it from i purchase it until now , very small & portable i recommended for every one own smartphone

    Rating: 5

    2014-03-21: Did not like this because I put a case on my phone to protect the back of it and the sides and it would not fit in this piece of equipment for the phone.
